title: Transport Fever 2
review: I love transportation games, like openttd, and while this might not be a new idea or have many new gameplay features, it is a huge graphical upgrade loaded with mods that only Cities:Skylines can top. If you use mods, which can be easily downloaded from the Steam workshop but can take a toll on your RAM, you can create a beautiful and fun sort of virtual model railway. I've spent a lot of time on this game, which is unusual for me, because it is so easy just to sit down, put on music or a podcast, and build a railway network.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: If you liked TF1, this is a nice upgrade. Not a great one, but a nice one. Lots of little improvements to it, and much better graphics, though still very much the same game in many ways. I haven't looked into the mod community yet, so that might make it much more robust, but for now I'm very happy I got it - doubly so, as I got it on sale ;)

Then the economic side is pretty bad plus rotating objects is way to difficult. Hold shift and use n or m...
But as a wrote, in the begining, the laying of tracks is so much worse then in the first game. 
For example: When you are laying tracks next too a city and see the roads just smothly follow the surface while your tracks either go up or down as crazy. :D It is insane :D

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
[h1] A game started by the developers, but built by the community. [/h1]
tl;dr: You like modding && you like transporting stuff && Optimizing is your thing? You'll like it.

First things fist: Yes. It feels like every game since TrainFever. Never the less, a little upgrade and added complexity would have made it far more interesting, if you dont only want to build a virtual model railway.

The range of mods and their individual quality are astonishing. Never have I ever relied more on mods than in this game. This is a great achievement for the very friendly, creative and open community. Great job guys! All of you! 

On the one hand it cannot be denied that the developers did an okay job with the vehicles and the cities. But on the other hand... It is just too few to fuel the full game. 

The games performance is okay-ish. But it's not really good. On my 2080RTX with the i9 it sometimes even goes lower then 25/23FPS in late game. Reaching late game with larger maps should not be so uncommon that this poor performance is in any way reasonable. 

Attention. This is my opinion only. Yours might be different, but I would like to feel free to express mine here. 
Rather should they do one thing right then doing three things only by 30%. I would personally have preferred to have a european game with an extensive set of for instance German vehicles. 

After all, my conclusion is: Yes. I do recommend this game, if you like optimising and trains and all the stuff. And of course ... Modding the hell out of it. 
If you dont like modding, it will be boring the second day. Dont buy it then.

[b]The community is very helpful and kind. So please give them the appreciation the modders deserve. Thanks.[/b]

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Great game if you like logistic puzzles and city building. Definitely needs improvements on car transport en road construction. Could also use air traffic waypoints to direct planes away from cities. But most importantly it needs optimization. With a large populated map in construction mode I get severe frame drops to 5 fps with a RTX 2080 Super even with a lot of options disabled and lowered graphics. It completely brakes immersion and becomes really frustrating if you're doing large infrastructure projects. 

Regardless for the money it's a very enjoyable game. Give it a try! Don't spend too long in tutorial/campaign, it's quite boring. Also get some popular mods.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a great game if you are into any games such as Railroad Tycoon, SimCity, Cities: Skyline, etc.   There is much more of a learning curve to this than most of the Railroad Tycoon games, but that's okay because of all the awesome capabilities.

One thing I especially loved was taking some raw material, putting it on a truck, shipping it to a railroad depot that delivered it an airport,  Then a plane flew it across the map, where it was put on another truck, and shipped to a depot in a town.  After it was processed it made another similar journey to it's final destination.

There are tons of great mods and maps available that really extend the gameplay options.  I've tried lots of crazy things that I'm sure the developers never intended, but who cares!

There aren't many cons to this game.  About the only one I can think of is there are some balance issues.  For example in some cases a fully outfitted freight train will run you as much as a small airport, (or more).  But by the time you are building airports the money doesn't much matter any longer.  

The only CTD I have had with this game has come from a mod that allowed for Meglamaniac  maps, and I played on that map for probably 15 hours before all the planes, ships, trucks, trains, etc eventually overwhelmed my computer and it choked.  It was a really huge map.

I highly recommend this game and I anticipate playing it much more in the future.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 feels more like a Transport Fever and less like a Train Fever. I liked the original Transport Fever, but this sequel is definitely an improvement. We now have traffic lights, cargo planes and some other cool stuff that the original game didn't have. 

I can recommend Transport Fever 2 if:
1. You liked the original Transport Fever and Train Fever.
2. You liked Sid Meier's Railroads!, the Railroad Tycoon series.
3. You like modding. There's a very active, creative and friendly modding community behind this game.

That being said, I think that the Transport Fever series are great. Probably the best "modern" strategy/business management games at the moment. Worth a try if you like strategy, business management and maybe even city builders like SimCity 4 or Cities Skylines.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have played 1467 hrs now in this game [and about 2500hrs in TF1]. Although the end result is great and enjoyable to watch and play, getting their can be pure Hell!
Things that didn't work from TF1 have been carried over including bugs that were supposed to have been fixed with TF1! It is really a dlc to make things look nice for TF1!

The modding community really add to the game and do stella work, whereas the devs are lazy and can't be bothered to make the game better!

Will add the pro's and con's later, but at the moment, I am 60% against and 40% for the game. It was a lot higher before, but the frustration with the track laying [which allows you to lay impossible real life track, but not the other way round] and the constant shifting of the catenary masts [I place my own] placement point is a deal breaker for me. You upgrade the speed and they all move. Delete a section of track [as some mods make the distant too far between masts] so you can chose where to place them by redrawing it, makes other masts disappear if they are on elevated ground. 

Routing is stupid in this game. You have to baby step the route by putting numerous way-points in otherwise it makes bizarre detours from the main line. If you alter a consist, it can change the platform number it calls at and the track used. You can NEVER trust it to make an intelligent choice.

Considering 75% of the World's train traffic drives on the left, there is no catering for this [signals], only by mods. Same goes with road traffic. Game comes with very limited running stock, and their should be proper control over how cities expand/grow. There is an option to allow you to change the number of res/com/ind pop, but it reverts back to what it was, so useless! Without mods, you could have villages/small towns with skyscrapers which just doesn't look right and spoils it for me.

Optimisation [cpu/gpu] is poor as it was before. Looks like they were more interested in making a quick buck than really changing anything [bettering it]. 

A lot more needs to be done to make me change my mind!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The AI is just stupid at allocating resources from a factory to more than one line.  It tries to split everything 50-50 no matter what the demand looks like.  It's a bureaucracy nightmare.  There's no way for the player to override.  Example: If there are two lines going to one depot, picking up the exact same item, delivering it to the exact same place, it will only load one line.  So entire factory gets shut down because it won't load cargo from a full cargo dock.  It runs fine for about 10 game years, then shuts down for no apparent reason.  
The game is pretty, but it's a terrible economy simulator.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Great game so far...  I've played TF 1 till I was blue in the face, so this was a nice change.

After 20 hours of play:
Pro: I love the updated graphics and the UI changes, like being able to look around when in camera view. I also love the ability to edit mass information at once on the line and vehicle maintenance.  Sweet. 
Con: Some of the quests are not intuitive at all.  For instance: Mission Paradise, Erace the Traces...   What do we erase?  Does the % show the % of what we have left to remove (100%), or does it show our imprint goal (0%)?  And nothing I do seems to change it.  Another drag is the UI windows..   they are not consistent..  I really dislike how they auto-pin when moved.  Please fix that because we may want to open a few more windows than usual, and just [ESC] out of them.  But we can't if they are pinned.  Also, it would better if the windows were not always bound to the right when opening.  How about putting them in last placement (or near as possible) like TR1?
Anyways..  so far I would recommend them game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I like:[list][*] Beautiful graphics, much improved over TpF1[*] It's like a virtual model railroad, very easy and straightforward to build even complex railway systems that work intuitively[*] Moving cargo is very effortless with infinite combos of trains, trucks, sea and air transport (that is even dynamic - like boxy vehicles can transport most kinds of cargo without telling the game specifically what you need them to do, like Transport Tycoon for example - and chained routes will automatically work together to move cargo as far as it needs to go)[*] Vehicles have really good and effortless pathfinding, and a waypoint system to work around problem areas[*] Editing already built stuff is very easy, and terrain will always default to what it was naturally even if your infrastructure builds automatically terraformed it[*] Campaign is a solid tutorial to the game and it's very easy to complete, with some tougher bonus challenges included[*] Lots of locomotives and wagons to choose from[*] Really good modding scene, not as good for modding as Cities Skylines and not as much stuff is available, but more than you'd expect[*] Cities evolve visually through a playthrough, responding to the passage of time and your actions as the player (you will grow cities by supplying items and providing passenger routes)[*] Ability to adjust (even stop) the passage of calendar time vs. game time is great and very underrated in sim games, but here we have it[/list]Neutral:[list][*] The economical model is not better or worse than TpF1, it's just different, this time it's far easier and more accessible to more people. But it's less challenging for sure and it's up to you personally whether that's good or bad.[*] The progression of time is a primary driver for how profitable you can be. If you start with horses in the 1800s, you make very little money and might even struggle at first in comparison to if you start in the late 1900s, when a fast route with good capacity literally prints money no matter what the route actually does.[*] Performance and RAM consumption has been improved a lot over time with patches.[/list]I dislike:[list][*] Still lacks ships like TpF1 did. There just isn't as much variety as there is for trains or trucks for example. The map generator also doesn't create great ship maps. An archipelago style map is the best you can generate.[*] Road infrastructure is lacking some things you might expect from such a detailed simulation, like the ability to create complex motorway infrastructure or even simple things like smooth motorway on/offramps etc.[*] No construction planning mode.[*] Stats are weak. There aren't enough key financial figures easily available and the graphs are just bad.[*] The map sizes are still tiny considering what decade we're in, the megalomaniac map is still considered "experimental" and honestly isn't that big. You won't be making a proper simulation of a continent or even a small nation here, planes are still pretty useless, and it's tough to find a train route where a high speed train gets to accelerate to full speed between cities.[*] Patching for the game is pretty slow and the dev isn't very active in communicating what they're up to.[*] As you progress through the years and cities grow bigger, you can end up with horrible npc traffic jams. Of course this is something you can try to address by providing better transport.[/list]Overall: I highly recommend it as a chill model railway building game, even at full price.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I found it's lot, lot better than old Transport Fever because it's easier gameplay than older one, I'm happy airport is easier to make profit, however it's still better to build a truck in start of game due cost effective by supply city with goods from  industry rather than any kind of transport, even train/rail is way costly and hardly profit, airplane won't come in and you do need lot of money to cover maintenance and paid off debit from Loan game start (you don't had a choice, it's already loan about $5,000,000.  

So before anything sure as passenger, be sure you find good city with close by supply industry then supply by raw goods that industry need, once you set up, and let city grow, keep doing same for other city with trucking, then work on passenger, even train once you making profit from trucking for industry to support city. I think key for passenger, is that wise not to had everything, but bus limited to one city area each unless you had 2 city very close to each other, then bus would be still useful, then if there is any river that connect 2 city or cargo from industry, you could use that, if you want, I think that is cheapest and early you can do that, but if willing to spent more money on train and track, it's cost lot to set up and lot of planner, ensure not to get in road way or build way while leave more room for future upgrade design. 

Once you got airport, then set up airport share by few city close by, then find very far, far away on other side of map and do same, then set up by train or bus, to help airport from few city close by. But I do had set up airport for one city and very close, but it's not good due take too much space and limited city grow, and emission because airport gave lot of emission, you don't want city to had high emission because it's will limited or slow grow. I think you can't upgrade small airport to large airport, you had to taken down small airport (1911?) once large airport come out in some year later, (I think 1960 or so? not sure), then you can upgrade second runway once you hit 1980, so some upgrade won't be come up till some year.

Key is look at city and industry and understand to prove it by resource on map that linked raw/goods chain, understand this you would make lot of money easy in long terms. That's key to this game, passenger for all kind transport should come last, after you proved city's goods, City had 2 goods that need to be met, after that city grow, then you can build passenger to make more money, so go on. 

Campaign is little bored to my taste, and very old designed, basic they had many map each, one time mission, then all your work is done and gone once you done with mission,
I rather to had stay one map with many mission, grow from there, rather than use map with simple mission, then next one, and so go on. I think this might be more fun that way. Oh well, but This game is main sandbox or know as freeplay, or you can make your own map, but there is some should done more tool sure as add farm (you can add farm but it's won't grow like normal freeplay) but petty cool to had map editor even it's need some bug fix and add more tool like add animal, you might not see animal on map you make, it's seem it's only work in freeplay map. 

I said game is worth it and fun. I don't mind to pay without sales, but depend on people, if you are not die hard fan of transport fever, and are kind of poor, I would wait till sales, but not sure how often sale come up for transport fever 2.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I've spent about a month on TF2 so here are the pro's and con's I've found so far.

Pros:
1- if you like TF1 then TF2 is about the same with better graphics
2-Building train rail systems is loads of fun in this game
3- Map Editor is much improved over previous versions
4- Supports mods (This is probably the saving grace for this game)

Cons:
1- The Campaign missions can be tough to follow and I found a bug in at least one mission where I was unable to use the cargo aircraft even after confirming my transportation line was set up properly
2- The game has less resources to choose from when creating maps now. If you build a large map and causes too much repetitive layout on larger maps.
3- The map editor still needs refining. Just wait  until you try to convert from streets to highways, there are no adapter templates to choose from other than a couple like a clover leaf and T for highway intersections.
4- Map editor has very limited assets to choose from, for instance I was making an Atlantic coast map and wanted palm trees and beach sand for the coast and pine trees for inland. If I choose Temperate climate I get no palm trees or beach sand textures, If I choose Tropical Climate I get no pine trees and have palm trees attached assets that I place on the map and cannot remove. For example I place a forest resource on the map and it automatically has palm trees around it, in the middle of a pine forest.

Overall I enjoy the game, just love setting up my costly train routes and watching them run. Hopefully the devs will address the bugs and give us a more polished game in the future and more options with the map editor.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Well made, plenty of options

That is what I said after playing less than twenty hours.  I have now clocked up almost 1800 hours, so I pause and reflect on TpF2.  It is a beautiful looking game, it really is.  I am slightly tired of mowing down yet another wild animal, but that is peanuts.   I played TpF1 extensively and my regular challenges against the AI was a big part of the game, trying to bend the game to your will building junctions, tunnels and bridges, let alone getting your freight lines working properly.  Then came TpF2.  At first the joy of something looking so good, and it was easy to set up your transport network, the game behaved.  And soon the money flowed, I couldn't spend it fast enough. In gaming terms I had hit a brick wall.  It was too easy.  Where was the challenge? I continue to play but now it is not rising to the challenge of beating the game's stubbornness to comply like its earlier relative, it is in the fine detail you can now create.  At this point a big shout out is needed for the modders (well most of them anyway) for the incredible work they do, what they produce takes the game to another level.  Taking your time once the money is not a factor to create a credible and realistic world (well one that is always sunny and covid free, no masks or distancing on my platforms!) is hugely satisfying, as is spending time to create your own worlds from scratch in the editor.  So this is a brilliant game and i would recommend it to anyone. And for TpF3?  Well the developers have a chassis to take it in different directions.  For me different weather and day/night would be good and if that was coupled with timetabling with a few tweaks a challenging game could result, but hey what do i know! Oh and traffic driving on the left option please!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Having been a fan of TF1 I was so looking forward to the sequel, and even pre-ordered, which I never normally do, but somehow they have produced a game that is a step down from it's original.

Sure it has great graphics compared to TF1 but in every other way it is inferior. Many of the irritations of TF1 are still there like the difficulty getting tracks to join up over rough terrain .The campaign missions are no where near as tricky or fulfilling, it's usually just a case of following some steps and you're done, and there are rarely any barriers you need to work around to be successful, other than bugs that sometimes make them impossible to complete. They have made managing vehicles simpler (no need to go back to depot to sell, no increased maintenance) which I never found problematic before.

One of the things that wasn't great in TF1 was the economy, but in TF2 they have somehow made it even more 2 dimensional.

Graphics are great when you are zoomed right in, but who plays a transport simulator zoomed in? This game is style over substance.

If you have never played TF1 go buy that, you won't be disappointed, but if you were hoping TF2 was going to be a step up you will be disappointed. Maybe one day updates and mods will make this as good a game as the original, but until then give it a miss.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have played Transport Tycoon (TTY) since release (sometime back in the 14th century) and still have it running in Dosbox or via OpenTty. After playing this game for over 170 hours - thanks to Covid - I have to write a recommendation. While the single player campaign game is not all that fantastic, it does cover some interesting points in history and I put up with the bugs and silly requests just to get through it and shake my head at some of the turning points in history. I can say I ended up on Wikipedia a few times just to read up about these events. However, this is not how the game was intended to be played - I think it is added for flair. The meat is found within the Free Game mode - I have not tried Sandbox. 

It does a great job of bringing to life all my favorite memories of TTY. I spend hours building my railway lines, planning roads, watching aircraft takeoff and land (although their piloting skills are much to be desired - especially on the occasion the plane flies through the hill on takeoff) - and of course ships steam along the rivers.

I found the tropical setting the most fun as this opens up islands and creates better shipping opportunities. The locomotives from the different regions are well modeled and the graphics are a huge improvement over the first. I do not have space for a desktop and I am running this game on a lower resolution, with a laptop i7, nvidia 930mx. Quite old hardware from 2016. The game runs fine and the sacrifice of resolution is overcome with turning on a little anti-aliasing. I played on medium settings (even with the warning for the video ram) just so I can see the grass! I have played up to large maps, anything bigger and my hardware starts to chug. Even so - the large maps are pretty big!

If you enjoy transportation games, trains, trucks, buses, trams or ships - it is worth playing. Although you will find trucks and trains are your go to place for cargo movement. 

What could be improved?
1. More vehicles! I understand the developers try to open this up to the steam community - but under these circumstances you lose the ability to earn the Steam achievements. 
2. Bigger ships. I would love to see ocean liners, super tankers and post panamax cargo ships. I think this is the biggest let down in the game. The same would be for locks / canals / waterways - it is missing and something that I enjoyed in TTY.
3. More industry types for the Free Play. The campaign has lots of different types of cargo, I found one mod which opens this up for the freeplay and I must say it adds a nice dynamic to the game. 
4. Improved industry outputs, particularly farms. 
5. The UI is a little different to TF1 and this I think went a step backwards.
6. The tutorial / lack of one - this has had me looking a few times on the internet to solve problems. Like trains stations to accept cargo and passenger trains - it is harder than you think and a little annoying. 
7. There is no mail (which is odd), I kind of miss the mail train and wish that cities produces passengers and mail to improve trade between themselves. Considering the postal service was pivotal in history across many geographies, this is a big oversight. 

I recommend playing on easy - unless you want to really challenge yourself on Hard. The costs are insane on hard mode and this starts bringing out the bad in the game - it is nearly impossible to make a cargo route profitable unless you run 20 trucks on it - at which point the system runs like a conveyor belt instead of a transport game. You just can't make a profit from 4 coal trucks running back and forth to the steel mill - which then forces people to start turning to trains, where, you need something like 16 carriages in the 1800s to make it profitable. It just feels clunky. That being said - on easy - it is quick to succeed and so I have a number of games stuck in the 1900s on millions because I got bored. Hence the hard mode.

So yes, it could do with some variety, more industries, oil rigs, power stations, helicopters, double deck trams (aka Hong Kong), or commerce - like ski resorts or seaside resorts - the possibilities are endless. Without this though - it is a fantastic achievement. I must say that you'll want to find more music and if you owned Transport Fever 1 - this really feels like a remake, not a new game - but worth buying.

I hope they take this all under consideration and proceed to make TF3. Even if it feels like a new TF2 and a new TF1... at that point I just don't care - it will give me another excuse to spend 180 hours moving coal :)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It has taken a while to learn a number of the new additions.
I love how you can modify a railway station from say passenger to passenger and freight, without having to add a completely separate station.
I found you need a separate line added first and then the different type of platform with its associated Freight or Passenger building {all attached in one location} Marvelous.
The only thing I noticed is a little tricky is on the intermediate stations of a busy section of a route is to get the signalling correctly done.
I found the easiest way {so far} to get Goods/Freight trains and Passenger trains on a busy line, is to double track and provide a scissor crossover at each end of a station, so the trains can reach the appropriate platform. No negative issues so far.
The busier the line becomes there may need to be more intermediate signals provided along the track/s between stations.
The road Depots I have found a little more difficult to update. I have not been able to increase from just one pick-up/drop-off to multiple versions.
Love the addition of being able to fly over your landscape by clicking onto the correct version of the bird formation. Marvelous addition.
The Ports are another great improvement, I just love the way the ships sidle up to the port, like in real life and the sounds provided by the port are a wonderful addition.
Being able to download height maps from the likes of "terrain.party" onto the Create a game map are an excellent improvement. I have finally created my first map and uploaded it into the workshop.
It is a map of the area where I live and once had a railway and still has a port and airfields.

I have just noticed the in game vehicles after 1940 includes an advanced model, it is the "Saurer" which has working brake lights and turn indicators and tailgate that drops down.

All in all there are lots of great improvements.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I had a special relationship to Transport Tycoon during my youth, and this is the first game I can confidently say scratches that melancholical, reminiscing itch I was suffering from for many, many years. I really love to see the progression from 1850 onwards, watch the citizens' cars change as the time goes, and nurture chosen cities to a successful boom. Besides a few personal pet peeves (upgrading airstrip to airport? Two lane to four lane road 50% of the time? Anyone?), this is a good game to spend time in, in my opinion. Definitely on a sale, and honestly, even full priced; especially considering the mod support.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Although I recommend this game, I have somewhat mixed feelings about it. 

I love the new Asian vehicle set (predominantly Russian and Chinese, with occasional Japanese vehicles). The new tropical map makes boats a more useful transportation option. And the ability to change the size of your stations bit by bit as opposed to using preset sizes is very useful. Not to mention there's a new, much longer campaign. 

On the other hand there aren't really any new industries outside of the campaign. Speaking of industries it is possible to still make money (albeit less) with them without completing all connections from resource to factory to town, removing some of the challenge from the first game. The biggest issue I have though is that there isn't enough new content/mechanics to really justify this being a sequel. If marketed as an expansion to the first game it would be a great value, but as a $40 standalone, I would recommend picking this up when it's on sale.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: this game is the worst game ever

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The game is "alright". I did get many dozens of hours of unmitigated fun out of this title, even if I may list a few criticisms to this game below.

While it doesn't hit every point that the original Transport Tycoon did, Transport Fever (2) is still a worthy "addition" to the Transportation genre.

The game does these things well:
1. Laying down large amounts of "track / road" at the same time, which is basically a modernization of the original TTD and very similar to what we have in Open TTD.
2. The game is very pretty on "high" settings. Zooming in and seeing citizens and vehicle models is strangely cathartic.
3. Game is *very* easy to understand and get into, which is something it has over Cities Skylines.

The game could improve on the things listed below, perhaps through DLC, but you could also potentially sift through the thousands of workshop mods to find a solution for it. Though I would prefer the former due to the clutter of Steam Workshop, many things that are good mods get buried under said clutter.

List:
1. There are very few industries in the game, you get a handful of primary resources and a few secondary resource (processed), finishing into about 3 tertiary resources, and that's really it. Once the game gets through the first 100 years and after paying back your initial debt, you will start to feel "this is it", and that's not a good thing.
2. The industry upgrade mechanic needs to be clearer, the goals do not seem very responsive to the player's actions (and many times cannot be met due to the nature of randomized materials.
3. There is no way to directly "influence" industries in this game. What you roll at the start is what you need to play with for the rest of the game. Unlike TTD, industries do not get constructed or demolished. This is a huge minus.
4. There is very little realism to the time that passes in this game. At 3x speed a second IRL time passes for about 2.5 days, this is an issue because you will see planes take about 10 days to get from the runway to the departures and then another 10 days to lift off again. Flying across the map takes like a month, which does not make sense at all.
5. Airports need a massive update, when you start building airports, you will clearly see that trains and buses are the "core" of the game, the limited ability to upgrade airports is massively off-putting, and by that I mean there is no way to lay more runway tracks in one airport. Airports in the world often have interesting layouts which you will get no way to explore in this game. There is no way to lay additional taxiways, for that matter.

There's probably a few more points but this is probably too long for anyone to read.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Unfortunately against my greatest desire I have to post this negative review.

TF2 has fixed a number of quirks from TF1, which is great - especially in the management of large networks.  

However, they've also taken out a lot of mechanisms that made the game challenging.  It's now simply a railroad sandbox.  At first I only noticed that you can change your vehicles on the fly (like, you can swap out a train going 200km/hr for a different loco, and/or add/remove carriages...) - this is in place of them upgrading/etc at a depot, or a station if you program it correctly.

But the removal of increased maintenance is beyond me. 
Moreso is that they've removed the entire concept of supply/demand - how can I just keep transporting raw materials to a factory that is not selling goods????
Even the campaign challenges are now superfluous - they literally mean nothing and are just a tick in the box on your way through the level.

I've now played through to near the end of the second campaign.  I didn't borrow money once.  I didn't even need to set up bus and cargo routes in town to ensure I had an income.

..................... Update after round two

So I decided to give a 'free-game' another shot... after first opening TF1 due to my first experience of TF2.  I will give credit that TF2 free-games are seemingly built for more an end-game type experience... in that the player is just trying to get all the towns to 100% +.  The mechanics seem to work quite well, however still the game is just a click-and-forget experience.  There's 0% difficulty.  I've entertained myself during periods where I just wanted to turn off my brain - so there is that. But seeing that I've got transport lines with horsecarts operating still and its 1950 is a bit stupid.  

(I should also note I've played nowhere near what the total time played shows - I have a very bad habit of leaving my PC on for hours with the games running :-D)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I really, really wanted to love this this game... but it just won't let me :/

1) Dumbed down over-simplified Industries.  
2) Ridiculous over-complicated track switching rules (that the game locomotives will often ignore/incorrectly follow for no logical reason) causing endless recurring track blockages that constantly defy most reasonable attempts to fix.  Lack of an 'easy' mode option that would turn train track signaling off and allow multiple trains to run on a single track without collision.  This feature alone would have saved me 50+ hours of frustration (and changed my review to a Positive, instead of a negative!
3) Any game that requires 100+ mods to make the game fun/enjoyable/almost playable is just wrong for a AA title that I bought for $34.99 (or more, at launch with the TF1 discount)
4) Lack of centralized warehouses for regional storage of raw materials/finished products.  Cities seem to have a very buggy notion of what goods they want... and will sometimes not accept these when you tray and ship it to them. 
5) Game often generates terrain too wild for easy track laying, even with mountain/hills turned off.  Laying track tends to create far too common tunnels or logic defying mile-high viaducts.  Game also limits the tightness of train track curves so guiding a semi-path through hills is nearly impossible without terrain editing tools to lower/smooth the grades into something the game will reluctantly accept.
6) VERY SLOW dev patching of critical bugs.  NO significant added features since launch.  Dev's go 3-6 months at a time without updating the community

So much potential here... but too much player frustration for me to deal with any longer.  Returning to Transport Fever 1 & Railway Empire

Yes, there are some very odd objectives within certain maps...some of which may require an online search to determine the answer, but the overall gameplay is top-notch (though not perfect, to be clear).  If you're expecting to be able to tweak roads and rails like you can in Cities Skylines, for example, look elsewhere.  The relating tools to plot down such things do allow for some level of creativity, but not quite to that extent.  

If, however, you get your kicks from organizing a massive network of buses, semi-trucks, sprawling trains, and air traffic, then this game is most certainly for you.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have been playing the TF series since Train Fever, and overall, this is the best version yet. Absolutely I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys transport / logistics management games. This is a game which has given me many, many hours of enjoyment, and which I never grow tired of playing.

The graphics are beautiful to look at, both vehicles and environment. It does feel like a living world you are interacting with, and it is fun just to set your camera at some random viewpoint and watch the world go by.

The new map generators are fantastic. They are capable of generating much more believable worlds than before, with more variety, especially with workshop generators added. I personally enjoy the tropical generator with an islands modifier from the workshop, as well as an Appalachian mountains modifier from the workshop (which happens to be the region I live in IRL).

The goods supply chain works a bit different than in the older versions, in some ways good and simplified, but personally, this is my least favorite change. I liked the way goods distribution worked better in the last version. There are however workshop downloads which improve the distribution methods, and these do a good job, with different modifiers to suit different distribution models. There are also expanded supply chains in the workshop which really add a lot of game play variety. So for this, I would say the out-of-the-box was a step backward, but the community has made good of it.

On the other hand, the new supply chain is probably perfect for new players to learn the game, and with the ability to mod so many aspects of the game, we are free to make it the game we want.

Again, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys transport , logistics, and management type games.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The industry mechanics need to be corrected.  Devs please add individual commodity prices with demand based fluctuations.  

As far as I can tell, the delivery fee is based off of the linear distance from pick up to drop off.  There is no incentive to optimize production of secondary and tertiary goods.  You are rewarded for more inefficient trade routes.

How to win hard mode.
Connect an oil well to a refinery on the opposite side of the map.  Then connect a fuel or plastic producer near the oil well.  Set 100+ wagons to move when full of crude.  Pay off debt.  Replace wagons with large tanker trains when they become available.  Or planes / boats.  Make trade hubs in the opposite corners of the map for maximum profit.        

If you are looking for a beautiful sandbox game - you will have fun.  The technology progression is great!
If you are looking for a challenging supply chain optimization game - you might want to pass for now.

The game seems to be missing a certain game element that makes transport games really fun though.  Combine that with the bugs and I can't recommend the game today.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I played 1000+ hours of Transport Fever 1. With great anticipation I waited for the release date of Transport Fever 2. Now, two weeks later, and 60+ hours of play time, I've founded my first impression. As an enthusiast of the genre, [b]I'm disappointed[/b], but I can see that for new players, TpF2 is a better game. But back to the start.

[h1]The obvious[/h1]
The game looks [b]gorgeous[/b]! The views are impressive. The game looks so much better then TpF1. It is a real pleasure to sit back and watch trains run through the landscape. The developers put a lot of effort in making the game look good, and make it attractive to play with. They succeeded in this aspect.  They even extended the possibilities to modify the landscape, coastlines, add new cities or delete them (in sandbox mode). In all, it good looks very nice, but what about the game play?

[h1]The modular stations[/h1]
One of the major upgrades are the modular stations: the system to assemble your station, and adapt it to the local situation. It is very well done, quite intuitive to use, and for new players it's a big leap forward.
TpF1 started with very limited station configurations, but the latest modded complex station could be bendy, on slopes or underground, varying platform lengths and width, ... The degree of freedom was huge. The new simple modular stations of TpF2 are for more for the casual players, but for the hardened TpF players, the [b]modular concept is a step backwards[/b]. No bendy station, no sloped stations, no underground stations... let's see what mods can bring us,

[h1]Two cargo types per city[/h1]
Another obvious change to the game is the concept of the cargo system. The cargo system of TpF1 was demand based. Every industry delivered the amount of cargo based upon the demand, and this through the entire chain of products. But this system had a problem. Cargo production chains could be very long in distance and time, from primary resource to destination. It was possible that the entire demand of a specific cargo type was in transit, and the mine or farm halted the production because the amount of demand had been produced. The production chain halted, and started to degrade because of the lack of production. 

This lead to great frustration with players, and became a major concern with the developers. So, they came up with a new cargo system. The concept changed from a transport simulation game into [b]a logistics puzzle game[/b]. They removed a couple of cargo types that seemed too confusing, and simplified the production chain. They also reduced the number of cargo types that can be delivered to a city: namely only 2. And that makes a huge difference in the experience of game play.

Some find this a better system, more clear and more "challenging" to solve the logistics puzzle. But many experience this as a dumbed down simulation system. In stead of making TpF2 a more complex and engaging transport simulation experience, they made it more casual and targeted for the newcomers, to make it more accessible for them to grasp and start. But the seasoned players, who have been playing Train Fever and Transport Fever, are mostly very disappointed by this simplified cargo system: a great deception even. But one point in favour of the new system is that production is now steady and more reliable.

[h1]Maintenance[/h1]
Vehicles have a maintenance cost. But maintenance has no direct influence on their breakdowns, nor does it limit life span. [b]They keep on running, even centuries[/b], without any problem. Maintenance has an influence on pollution, but the pollution game is underwhelming. Apart from reducing city growth, there are no other consequences. Vehicle maintenance has been reduced to something that does not matter anymore. What a pity, what a strange decision. But probably all in favour of the casual player who is not interested in deep simulation, the burden of break downs, vehicle replacements and technological evolution. The automatic replacement option has been removed, and trains do not return to the depot after service. The depot has become a mere spawn point for the vehicles. Depots could as well be removed from the game as they are now: they are pointless.

[h1]Money Fest[/h1]
TpF2 is a money fest. Even on hard difficulty [b]it is difficult not to make money[/b]. It is so easy to get rich quickly, that it is no fun, The Tycoon players who seek a challenging game of company survival, investments and grow, will be very, very disappointed. Making money is a laugh, so that it is pointless to play as a tycoon and to become rich and powerful. It's too easy.

[h1]All In Line[/h1]
People in TpF1 had 2 criteria while deciding the route they took to their destination: cheapest or fastest. This was fun, to have trains and buses, ships and planes. The traffic splitted and building an alternative route was fun. With TpF2 all people will use the shortest route. No alternatives. All traffic will use the same route, which results in huge traffic jams. Buses are empty, highway not used, planes are pointless, because all traffic follows the same route, into a same traffic jam. This is a major step backward, and simplification of the code backfired into a transport game of traffic jams.

[h1]Shipping cargo into the void and getting payed[/h1]
All resource industries produce cargo no matter if there is a demand for it or not. The player just ships whatever he can, and all cargo without demand, is thrown away into the void after transport. The player received huge transport [b]profits for shipping cargo without destination[/b]. This pointless transportation of cargo is just to make the player rich, but without any need for the game world of needs and demands. In the end, shipping cargo seems really pointless and meaningless, because the impact and consequences in the world is not in relation. This is a big fail of the game.

[h1]Stopping the calendar[/h1]
A popular mod in TpF1 was to alter the calendar time progression. Some people love to play it slower, and enjoy the atmosphere of certain eras, eg steam. With this mod players could slow down the calendar time progression, without influencing the challenges.
In TpF2 you can alter the calendar progression, and even stop it entirely. The idea was great but the implementation is flawed. If one has a profit of 1 million per year on normal calendar progression speed, then changing it to 1/2 speed, the profits will double!. On 1/4th speed, one gains 4x the initial profit, and when stopping calendar progression, [b]one can earn infinite money![/b] This is totally against the simulation principle, that yearly profits remain the same no matter how fast years go by. This calendar slider might be called the cheat mode slider. It is clear that the developers do not care about the simulation aspect; to try and keep the financial balance in the green. What was a brilliant idea, became a joke due to wrong implementation.

[h1]Smooth[/h1]
To conclude, the game is slick and streamlined for the newcomers and casual gamer. But for the simulation seeker and tycoon gamer among us, TpF2 does not deliver. The game has been developed based upon fear and limitations. Developers programmed to avoid the major concerns and complaints of the players of TpF1, and restricted TpF2 so these complaints would be avoided. But at the same time they produced a limited version, smoothed and slick, [b]beautiful to look at, but with an empty core[/b]. Experienced player will have to look hard to find the thrill and enthusiasm they expected with a sequel that promised to be more complex and challenging in the field of transportation, logistics and simulation. But none of that as come true. It became just a "nice" game, smooth and slick.

[h1]So, the verdict is....[/h1]
I recommend it for the new players, It plays so much better then TpF1. But as a sequel for the experienced players from TF and TpF like me... very, [b]very disappointing[/b].

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
What I liked: This is a true sandbox game with a large amount of things you can do. It takes a bit of planning and forethought to make an efficient transportation network for people and cargo. Players of the original Transport Fever will really appreciate the now modular depots that can combine passengers and freight and the graphics refresh.

What I didn't like: In just about every aspect that I had hoped the developers would touch on and improve over the previous version they seem to have happily glossed over. Something that will really grind your gears is the rail system. As no two trains can occupy the same block of track you will frequently find yourself sorting out train jams even when there is a perfectly viable alternate route available. Some simple A/B decision tree mapping for routing I could have pulled out of my high school C++ book would have helped with this. Another item they didn't really touch on is how to logically block out your routes and vehicles. If you don't add in a naming convention you'll be making some extra clicks to figure out what that vehicle does and ion what route. The intracity vs. intercity transportation routes also need a lot of help. It's generally just HARD to get the data you need to make good decisions.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: This is a wonderful game, for anyone who enjoys the Transport Tycoon style genre I highly recommend. Transport Fever 2 improves on the predecessor with better graphics, AI and more control over your infrastructure whilst retaining the elements which made the original charming. its map editor has been improved and the  generator completely reworked to allow for custom and unique maps to be made with ease. The game flows well and allows you (with sandbox) to edit things in game from establishing new towns and industries to changing how long it takes for a year to pass.  I would advise that this is not for those looking for a city builder, for that check Cities Skylines but if you wish for a great transit game look no further. it recently got its first major update (Which was completely free!) and the game has a large and well supported workshop community!

If I enjoy steam locomotive I can have it for only a few hours than I have to change to electric.

What's more, economic system is not good enough, it don't encourage me to deliver and product and passages, the easiest way to earn is to ship raw materials.

review: I don't leave comments, they need to be. BUT GOODNESS GRACIOUS!!!! WHAT A GAME!!! Is it an FPS: nope. Is it a combat RTS: nope. Is it an MMOS: nope. Is it a racing game: nah. This is in its core a transportation management simulator. But IMHO, this is a FANTASTIC and dynamic game. The graphics are incredible, the animations are on point, the audio is a delight. It's a well thought game and a game for people that likes to think and to thinker around with logistics. I made me feel the same joy when I played SimCity 2000 for the first time. This is not a city simulator (Get the awesome Cities Skylines for that), but the experience and the fun factor for me is there. If I can put it this way: I had the same feeling about this game as an adult, than when I was a kid playing with Micromachines and Lego. Yeah, I'm that old.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Got to say, I love this game. 
It's relaxing, Calming. Enjoyable.
And to be fair, the graphics are pretty great.

There are some bugs here and there.
And although not a bug per say, thigns such as lines not functioning correctly.
And instead of telling you whats the problem it just leaves a generic "line doesn't work" error.
So, I've spent literally hours trying to fix a problem that should have been a simple change track type.

I've also noticed that as you get on in years the game begins to struggle.
I stream the game majority of the time and last night, the game could not longer handle.
It crashed and then refused to open the save game (instantly crashed)
So, I was forced to make a new game.

There are a few things I'd like to see in this game improved.
Engine capability being one of them. 
Additions to the landscape. The landscape has no sense of "life".
You can see the odd bear now and then. But, it's like... extremely rare.
So, more life would be nice. Like cows grazing. Sheep etc.
Weather changes, so it's not just an eternally sunny day.
There isn't a night cycle either. Just something to give different appearances would be nice.
Additional landscape assets. Castles, caves. Just more things to look at.

Perhaps, a drivers seat view. I realise that is a whole host of additional graphics and assets additions
that need to be made. But, front of train whilst cool, definitely isn't as nice as drivers cabin.

Another addition I'd say this game needs is competition. Just thinking back to Railway Tycoon 2.
One of the major things I enjoyed about it was competing against AI companies trying to outdo them.
Maybe even buying them out and taking over their companies. Such fun!
Which brings me to my final point, I realise this is a sandbox but, there's no REAL challenge. Because you can go in debt endlessly until your company just begins to succeed. And whilst there's limitations on borrowing amount which is decent. It still kind of doesn't matter really.

As it stands I'll probably give this maybe 6-7/10.
Overall, the game is pretty damn good. It's relaxing.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I haven't played a Transport Fever game before so I thought I'd give it a go after liking the look in the trailers. I like Cities Skylines and other city builders so I thought it'd be okay, but I wasn't expecting to like it more than the city builder games as I wasn't sure I'd like only having control of the traffic and not buildings.

My expectations were far surpassed, I really like this game, and arguably a lot more than all city builders and other tycoon games I've played in the past! Overall the game is easy to pickup, I only played the first mission and I was set from there. After that, I didn't bother playing the campaign as I personally just like having free will to do my own thing, so I started a free play game.

I've started various save games, each time trying to perfect on a small mistake I made before which made my transport infrastructure slightly weak. It can be a bit difficult to keep track of things once your infrastructure has grown so much, but the game does a pretty good job of telling you where the inefficiencies are once you've figured out what the Production, Shipping, and Transport metrics mean and how they affect each other.

There's one or two things about the game which I think could do with improvement, such as seeing what route some resources are taking - once you've got all your towns linked up, goods might start taking routes you hadn't expected and it gets a bit confusing. Also, I've noticed one or two bugs, like when your train says it has no electrical path and requires reversing in order to fix. However, these issues aren't major and didn't ruin the gameplay at all.

5/5

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game feels like it was made by three different groups of developers. 

The first group made the playable vehicles. As far as I can tell, those are perfect: each one is meticulously crafted, not only trains (which are undoubtedly the stars of the show) but every one from the first coach to the last airplane, and not only do they look great but they sound great as well. An obvious work of love. 

The second group designed everything else in the game and the game itself. They are a rather indifferent bunch.  "A house is a house", they decided, and so no matter whether you play on Java or in Scotland, the houses are all the same, and so are the people. Anachronisms abound: you'll see women wondering around in crinolines at the end of the 19th century and cars from the thirties and forties driving on the roads at the same time. In Syria. - The game is a simple "get from A to B" (or maybe from "A and B to C and then from C to D") affair but, to be fair, I did not expect anything more.

The third group are pure evil, the type of sadists that jump on you in the middle of the night shouting "Gotcha!", preferably with a long knife in their hands. They designed the starting conditions and most of the campaign, especially the side missions that are clearly meant to frustrate you as much as possible.

Because of the third group (well, maybe I am wrong and they are all the same people, just with triple personalities) I long meant to give the game a thumb down, but finally the first group prevailed. So, if - like me - you get an orgasm when The Flying Scotsman or The Crocodile become available and then only want to spend hours watching them and driving around in them, this is the game for you. If not, you are better off without it.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If this game is on special, definitely get it.

If it's at full price, it's worth it... but if you're not into tycoon games/don't like really getting into the nitty-gritty of running a successful transportation company, better get it on sale.

Pros:
- The track-laying systems are sweet. If only Cities: Skylines had this capability to lay tracks one at a time with snapping. It's a joy.
- The system is easy to get to grips with, but difficult to master. It tends towards the easy side though - it's fairly trivial to build up a massive bank balance.
- The game looks pretty good. Lots of detail on the models of the trains and other vehicles. The terrain's pretty nice too.
- Huge maps. You can build the rail and road networks you desire, your imagination is the limit (although, I do suggest getting a few mods - particularly with bridges)
- Replay value: There's tons!

Cons:
- It's not really well-optimised, the total inability to maintain a stable framerate even with a beefcake computer rig is a bit annoying at times. But it doesn't crash (unless you overload it with mods), at least, so that's a bit of a positive.
- Certain late-game trains take forever to get to full speed (like 250km/h+), so you might be a little disappointed expecting them to go quick.
- On the subject of rail and road networks, sometimes you'll find yourself fighting with them at times to get them to go where you want them to go; particularly when building bridges. Recent patches released have somewhat helped with this, though - bridges are still a pain unfortunately - there's a minimum height limit required for them so they won't automatically snap to intersecting roads etc.
- Related to this: if you build on some low-lying maps, you'll find issues with networks clipping into the water level, so this can be unexpected.


I've had a lot of fun with Transport Fever 2, and I've definitely got my money's worth. Do recommend - it's a huge improvement over previous games in the series for veteran players, and for new players, it's the ideal time to give it a go.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A lot of reviews talk on whether it's worth to pay $40 for the improvement over Transport Fever 1.  But what if you didn't play TpF 1?

If you ever looked in marvel at a train passing by, if you were ever fascinated by railyards, if the complexity of a commuter network turns you on, if asdf' "I like trains" song is your morning alarm, then look no further. Get this game.

Basically this game allows you to do virtual train miniatures without spending thousands of dollars in Märklin models and the rent of a garage large enough for your ambitions. 

It's quite fun to design transportation networks and look at everything working together like a clockwork. There is a nice attention to details of vehicles, so train fans can look at their favourite locomotive zooming through the landscape. Passenger simulation is impressive because the game simulates each individual person with a household, a job and preferred commercial areas, plus preferred means of transportation. Quite a lot of depth. 

Oh and tons and tons of mods. Seriously, browse the workshop, it's amazing. 

The cons:

* Campaign feels a bit tedious especially after the first chapter (out of 3).
* Game is very resources-consuming. A beefy computer is needed for large map sizes and/or lots of mods. Luckily the devs have been improving this on every patch
* The game isn't really challenging.

review: Should be great but for me is ruined by inexplicable control design.  It's far from intuitive, lacks basic keyboard controls common to these types of games (e.g. no way to reverse time speed only loop by advancing it, no right-click cancel you have to click on the window's X, simple things like building rotation being impossible to locate - even after checking key mapping options); and the key mapping options are lacking to say the least.  I just can't get in to it due to the bad controls which seem designed for a mouse-only scheme while ignoring the tried-and-true keyboard controls common to this genre.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game is a mess of technology.
- Rediculous slow loading. Doesn't matter when the game is on 800MB/s SATA SSD. Doesn't matter when I move the game to a 2500MB/s M2 SSD.
- There is some horrible on the fly asset loading. Every time you click a building for the first time on every map, game locks completely for 10-15seconds.
- Every time you change any option like sound volume or something, the game needs to restart. Yes I'm serious.
- If you can't find how the hell to turn buildings, it's in the options under "Construction option 1" and 2. Building higher or lower is "Construction option 3" and 4. There is also a "Construction option" 5, 6, 7 and 8 but I have no idea what they do. I wish there would be a label or something for the game to tell me what it does... For fuck sake. There are also 50 different other options for showing and hiding things that nobody will ever use proven by the fact they didn't bother assigning a shortcut key to it.
- There is a campaign where you have to move half your operation because a volcano is going to explode. Once you do the game is like "haha loser. just kidding. you did all that for nothing." I bet because actaully they didn't know how to add some smoke effects and slow moving orange water to make it really happen.

This game is a mess of design.
- No button to place signs spread out over a track anymore.
- Even though this is the second game, the campaign still superglues the tutorial to your hand and locks you out of building freely. You have to do everything exactly as they want it.
- Good luck with the freaking bonus tasks. The game doesn't show you anymore what the task actually is so you have no clue what you need to do.
- There aren't really production chains and consumption anymore. Just transport anything to anywhere and there is always a need and you never need to deliver byproducts.
- When you watch the vehicles on a line, you can't see what they are carrying anymore. You have to click each vehicle on each line to see if you need more or less vehicles.
- There is no way to delete stops on a line. You can only delete everything.
- You have some magic powers making you able to add carriages and upgrade vehicles out driving on a route.

I can't even anymore.
They should have made the new campaigns as DLC for TF1.
But they were greedy. So they made a worse game than TF1, charged full price and aren't even fixing this pile of shit.

Looking at the reviews there are either a bunch of people who never played TF1 when reviewing TF2 (they keep the first game at full price to make sure) that don't mind buying broken products or publisher is heavily redacting negative reviews.

review:
Game looks nice but thats the only positive for me. 
Campaigns - boring, shallow. Many tasks/quests are unclear. You wont know what to do unless you find answer on the forums or on the reddit. Some tasks are just retarded and counterintuitive like have overcrowded stations.
When I'm using two monitors I cant make the game go full screen = playing it in windowed mode.
Having camera goes automatically bug/glitch like every five minutes and it is super annoying when you just need the map to be still and do something.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is one of the best city building type simulation games I've ever played. I tend to be more into the transit themed games than the city building itself. So I've enjoyed games like Cities in Motion (in particular, CiM 2) more than the Cities: Skylines series. This game hits the spot for me.

Pros:

- Big open worlds, plenty of cities and industries to connect to each other
- Challenging transport goals (sometimes one industry needs something from far away)
- Intuitive building system, for roads, tracks, bridges
- Easy to set up lines. You can add a stop in the middle if you want any time.
- Beautiful graphics. Sometimes you'll stop for a minute to admire what you've built, and you'll zoom in, and be floored at what you're looking at. It looks almost real.
- Good tutorial to ease you into it. The way cargo is transported is a bit tricky to figure out and the tutorial helps.

Cons:

- Some performance problems. With an old i5 system with a GTX 1660 Ti, I can do 90ish FPS, but it drops below 30 if I go into certain construction modes.
- Not a lot of people moving. It seems to be mostly cargo moving. I've yet to figure out how to set up an intercity train that's profitable. This might just be my lack of experience so far.

review:
I am still in the campaign with 112 hours played and I have enjoyed each and every one of the 16 missions that I have completed. The graphics and game play are all much improved from the 2 prior versions. Depending on what happens with future support, user content and free play (which I have yet to touch), this game could replace Railroad Tycoon 3 as my all time favorite game. (Sid's Civs are a close second.)

Some of you might know me as Orange 46 from Hawkdawg.com, a  railroad tycoon site where I have numerous maps posted for RT2 and RT3.

Now, at 210 hours I am going to take a break. I continue to enjoy the game, but wish that it's economic model was better. The crow flies model and low track vs high vehicle maintenance costs really discourage running busy railroads, where multiple trains share the same tracks. It's fun to ride a train in other games like Railroad Tycoon 3 or Railway Empire and see all the activity on both the main and branch lines. But, to do that in TF2 you need to play on an easier version, but then you lose the fun of having to make difficult strategy decisions because you have run out of cash. Yes,  TF2 does give you tractor trailers which do run on busy roads, but nothing beats a train.

The best part of the game is  the 18 campaign scenarios. It's too bad that no one seems to be able to develop new scenarios. That's where RT3 is king. Tons of user scenarios. There was even a CD published of 100 user Scenarios for RT2. The RT series map editor used drop down menus to make map editing possible for non programmers (or should I say coders).

Too many user maps have randomly generated cities. I find those boring, but 3 cheers to the map makers who have given us real cities. Just having the 18 campaign maps available for free play (with its hard level) would be enjoyable.

It seems to be easier to manage things in TF2. You can add or delete cars or engines on individual trains without going back to the shed. On hard, you can actually make money on less than perfect routes. Yeah, I know, TF was more like one of my RT3 scenarios, but in TF you can't ignore existing lines for too long on hard before things start to go wrong (at least for me), so slightly easier is a plus for me. The graphics also seem to be better.

It's too bad that my PC won't handle the extremely large experimental maps, as there is a very large USA map with very low population cities (just like in some my RT maps) that I was making glacial progress in that I had to stop because of too long loads and finally lagging while playing - and I had only connected 2 cities by rail and the rest by boat or horse cart from Northeast Canada to Boston.

I still recommend this game at 224 hours and intend to return to it often, especially to see what new maps have been added.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
6 months after release, and no new content from the devs. This is still a TF1.5 and not 2. I now change my review to negative. For a third game (i played the two previous ones) we could expect more content.


Hi!

Here are my impressions on the game as someone who played TF1 and even Train fever and the good old OpenTTD.

-----------------------------------------------------------------
The PRO 

- The vanilla game is in my opinion the best in history. Best graphics, even better gameplay and deeper management which is important in my opinion because it is both a management and contemplation of what you have built game. For newcomers it is the best one.

- A lot of QOL compared to the first one. Station modularity is nice
=> This should be a must have in a few months, see below

-----------------------------------------------------------------
The Average/CON depending on one's sensibility

- Workshop is still very light as the game just released, which makes the game feel not that good compared to the previous one. Not the dev fault of course, and this should be solved in a few months

- Average stability and performance, but still way better than the first at launch. Again, wait a few months. On my I7 9700k with 2070+ and 16+Go DDR4 i can run the large map without issues but a little bit slow with the game max speed in late game and just a few cities/cargo covered. Megalo dont load when they did on TF1 on a lower computer. But large is already very large (is it larger than in TF1 equivalent? not sure)

-  The game is TF1 version 1.5 more than 2 as many have said. you get 50% more asset with Asia and it seems like this is all, and you find your old assets back from TF1 for europe and USA.

- Road and track placement is much much better with elevation. But this could go even further with more choices and a more tolerant collision system which i find a bit rigid right now,

- The little thing i dislike: in TF1 it could be a pain to close the multiple windows of vehicles, and it is solved now, onlyu one window at a time. But sometimes two or three windows would be nice to have, for example when taking a loan to complete a train purchase.

- The emission system doesnt make sense to me. Electrical vehicles dont pollute less than steam and diesel ones, Also, the age of vehicle does not seem to have any influence on maintenance costs anymore which was something i found very logic,


To conclude, i will come back to it in a few months. Should you buy it ? Of course, the developer has always supported their games. It is a good game today which suffers from the shadow of its predecessor. It will be a great game one day, thanks to the support and to the awesome modders we have.

Please developers, keep doing this great serie until I die and dont hesitate to add DLCs with new gameplay. Monorail over road, subway... Remember the multiple level train station mod on TF1? Well the station modularity would make such a thing so nice,

Thanks for reading

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
By far the best and most detailed transport game in town and one my all time favourite sims!

Why you ask ??

Pro's

Trains!
Immersive use of older transport that ages in time to modern day transport.
Track laying and route setting is well cool!
Very satisfying riding your new vehicle with the first person camera.
Mod support is really good.
Map Editor is well made and fun. (was for me anyway)
Amazing scenery.
Trains!


Con's

You can't drive the train or other vehicles (yet?)


This may seem biased but I can't pick off any more faults, it's a truly amazing game and worth every penny, there is no other transport game that I have played that offers the 3D look with all the insides off a complex transport machine.  Thanks for this game, I really love it!!


9.5/10

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Yes, maybe get it. But for gods sake do not bother playing the campaign. It's a buggy, poorly written mess. The instructions are irritatingly vague. "Look for the secret meeting place" How? Who? What? "Move the politicians" Who the hell are the politicians?

You get to grips with the implied meaning eventually, but it's just frustrating and not at all worth it.

The UI is a bit crap too - it's hard to find anything. Oh, and it is a bit buggy - crashes will happen, vehicles will decide to not bother doing their think.

All that aside, it is fun: just don't expect too much, and for gods sake, let me say again: DO NOT PLAY THE CAMPAIGN!

Have to say it has better graphics than previous version, but apart from that it's basically the same game, but imo it runs smoother. Laying the tracks are easy as they were in the previous version. What I like the most though in this version, is that you can create much larger maps with more towns/cities and more industries, plus you have 3 climates too make it a much more appealing experience. The community workshop provides mods that make you game even more appealing, however the vanilla is just as good so far.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A great game and huge successor to the previous! A game that I can submerse myself in for hours and hours and always learn new ways to improve my game play using the vast number of videos and guides available.
A huge collection of content on the workshop to make the game truly unique for you.

A couple of bad points are that some of the colours during the in game experience sometimes appear to blend into one and are not as clear as the predecessor.  
Also once you have really gotten going in the game, it is heavily CPU based and can cause some lagging later on down the line. I currently have an Intel i5 3470 with 8gb RAM and a GeForce GTX970 in my PC and once my cities get to a decent size with multiple lines running throughout it the CPU can struggle to keep up, this is however after many, many hours dedicated to 1 map.

I would highly recommend to any fan of the tycoon based game 

8.5/10

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
First impressions of this game is that this game reminds me of Chris Sawyer's Locomotion (which was released over 20 years ago if I remember correctly), but with far better graphics (although duh a game released in 2019 would obviously have better graphics than one 20 years ago).  I haven't played many city or transport simulation games (and at the time of review, I also haven't played this game for long) but if anyone did enjoy Chris Sawyer's Locomotion, I'd recommend this game.
I'd say the only thing missing from this game are AI controlled competitor companies.  I remember sabotaging my competitors in Locomotion by sticking a train car in the middle of their single lane truck route which then blocked their entire supply line.  Fun times those were.  I hope the developers of Transport Fever 2 add AI competitors.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is, quite possibly, the greatest transportation game ever made. Think Cities-in-motion on steroids. It is beautiful, and it's mechanics are so complex. I love the game and every aspect of it.

*If you remotely liked the transportation in Cities: Skylines or have played/enjoyed Cities in Motion, you **must** try this game.*

**The focus**
The game gives you the option to "focus" on one aspect of the game and truly excel at it. These are:

**Cargo**: Ship cargo, help manufacture goods, and earn money from it.
**Passengers**: Make money by getting people from point A to point B.

Both of these let you expand cities, to continue to make even more money. They are entirely different paths, and both let you have tremendous amounts of fun.

Some details on the methods of transportation:
**Road**: Build roads. Build depots. Make trucks/buses go down roads, to make loads to cash. Not much to say here.
**Train**: Build train tracks. These are actually really neat: They snap to the sides of roads, tell you what the speed limits are, and have optional canaries for electric trains. You also aren't forced building pairs of rails: Every rail is built individually, and will snap to each other if so so wish to have them next to each other.
**Sea**: Build docks, and a shipyard. Again, not that complex. If you have bridges, make sure to keep them tall for boats to go under.
**Air**: Radically expensive. Get from point a to point b with minimal building, but be careful doing this outside sandbox mode.

General Pros:
 - Absolutely **beautiful** map generation. Every time you run it, it makes maps on par with cities skyline's. This alone almost wins the game.
- Pretty good pathfinding
- Intelligent trains

General minor issues:
- You can't choose which route a train/truck/ship takes to get from point a to point b.
- There are some rare pathfinding bugs which are game-ending.

In a nutshell? 9.5/10 game. Buy it now, or on sale. It's really good.
