title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So i'm through part 1 and 2 of the campaigns and ready to pass on a few comments on the game so far.
I will most likely update when the game receives updates.

Me, i have played this genre of games since Railroad tycoon 1 on the Amiga.
Until a few years ago i held Railroad tycoon 3 as the game to match in this genre.
Then, some years ago, we got Train fever and later on Transport fever 1, Railroad empire arrived and coming along fine is Mashinky. So it is a great time for the genre.
Transport fever 2, Railroad empire and Mashinky all have a different take on the genre and therefore each have their bright points and less bright/bad sides.
By the way, basicly i recommend all three games :-)

Since this is about about TPF2 my comments for game:

This game has been changed/optimized since it's origin in Train fever and come some way.
The graphics is nice and work well. There are some minor negatives though, not really bad, but a little odd that buildings are used freely between the 3 continents. Also as an example cargo stations in 1850 has electric light posts and euro pallets....

The game has well working mechanics to manage your transport empire. Signals work well.
One could of cause always wish for more.

The game could use some better more detailed track/road building functionality.
But what is there works okay.
However i don't understand why a double track feature has not been implemented. It would be such a time saver.

Keyboard and mouse controls work well and are 'responsive'.

Motor vehicles have issues, but are in line with todays standard. Specially i get sad when seing that vehicles don't overtake slower ones and just pile up on multiple lane roads. But this is something other games also struggle with (cities skylines..). 

I do wish though that it is should be possible to zoom out further. On big maps the zoom level is not enough.

I miss that the developer has not included some well made quality maps to play.
Except for the campaign, the game relies on the map generator and what people publish in the workshop.
It would not be out of order to expect some nice quality maps handmade by the developer.
The map generator just creates random generated maps with no clear logic in where industries a placed. You have all types industry placed random amongst each other which makes no sence in 'the real world'.

I enjoy the campaign. It is good at teaching the game basic elements.
There are however campaign goals that seem rather odd and not very well explained.
It would have been nice if the campaign maps were available to play in free game mode.

Late game for cities shows issues. The game could use some better road tools and the way the game auto generates the streets and the growing cities are not easy to align with good traffic flow. The game developer really needs to focus on this for future updates or a TPF3

The game has bugs, but the developer is active on working on these.
I haven't personally found anyone that are a deal breaker, only rather annoying.

I also wish they would implement some higher graphical settings.
I 'love' going into the FPS view for the vehicles. But the graphics doesn't do all that well with textures pop ups in the near horizon and shadows. The drawing distance really need to be higher.

Overall i recommend the game.
My biggest let down with the game is that the developer has not included some quality hand made maps. Besides that the whole city growth issue is also a rather big concern.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 has to be one of if not the best simulation / management games i've ever had the pleasure of playing!
        After I played the original Transport Fever I was immediately hooked on the gameplay style which is super easy to use and understand and not to mention the map editor which allows you to pretty much create a world from scratch which is great fun. When Transport Fever 2 came out on steam you can bet I bought it right away and let me tell you that is was one of my best purchases i've ever made with its jaw dropping graphics and new vehicles to play around with that the original Transport Fever lacked. Not once have I ever played and stopped because I was bored and on that topic may I add that i've never actually ran into any parts of the game that i've found boring except building long lengths of railroad track but that's about it. Whats awesome about this game is how much you can micro manage if you so desire such as being able to see the names of every single person in your cities / towns and how your able to paint any car, train, bus, tram, etc. whenever and wherever you want. A very similar game City Skylines which I also own pales in comparison to the high detail and polish this game has and you can bet Transport Fever 2 has many more vehicles and variety than City Skylines as well. 
         The only griefs I have with this game are as follows...
1. The games high level graphics make it impossible for a good ammount of gamers to experience the game to its full potential however I found running the game on medium graphics works just as well with some minor lag spikes at times as cities continue to grow. 
2. Sometimes placing track and road can become slightly tedious and on occasion can be frustrating to use but I found this only when going near or around mountains and very slightly off leveled terrain. 
3. Vehicles don't automatically upgrade as years go by so you must replace all supply vehicles and buses in all cities to make sure they have the best carry weight and speed. 
         Besides my small griefs with the game I believe Transport Fever 2 is the perfect example of how a vehicle simulation game should be made and played and I urge that if you like simulations and you like management games to get this absolute masterpiece of game!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you are a fan of Transport Tycoon, OpenTTD or TTD; this is the game for you!
Clearly the developers have also played these games too as they have improved on many aspects; trucks are actually useful, you can build in cities (no local councils), replace/edit/update vehicles without sending them depots, financial stats on individual lines/vehicles, the list goes on.
The graphics are superb; you can even see the indicators on the trucks as they drive through the city when in third person mode! 

Like all games there are some minor issue; building bridges can be tricky (see tip #1), naming of lines could be automated, campaign is a bit ... odd. But Free Play is just like good old Transport Tycoon, slowly build up a network and expand; before becoming a super power with lightning fast trains!

Here are some tips for new players; I have more but they are fun to discover for yourself:
#1 - bridge building. I found it easiest to build the up-ramps at both ends first (you need to click the little arrow next to the tick and cross), then build the bridge spanning the gap. If the word 'collision' appears or the bridge starts connecting with objects below your ramps aren't high enough. The same works for tunnels, obviously use down-ramps ...
#2 - deliveries for cities. I found that some of my lines stopped making money. Checking the Secondary Industries that fed the city the demand had dropped off completely at my station; not because the city didn't want it but because as the city had grown the industry had moved away from my station. Lower demand here meant upstream industries demand had also dropped off. Moral of the story make sure you stations catchment covers the industry you are shipping to.
#3 - station connectors. Train station (or any other station for that matter) cannot just be randomly build near industries or cities like Transport Tycoon, they need to 'connected'; by this I mean a little path needs to connect them. This simplest way is to build a road from your station entrance to the industry or city in question. If all goes well when you have the station selected the industry or builds within the catchment will highlight white.
#4 - do the first Chapter of the campaign. It is frustrating, I had to Google some of the quests. But ultimately it does teach you how to play the game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Like others, I find some of the missions (especially the bonus ones) in the campaign frustratingly confusing. For example, there is an early mission in Russia where you bulldoze 3 specific buildings in a city. You are supposed to be able to identify them with the zone overlay, but I ended up saving the game, bulldozing the entire city to find them, reloading and just bulldozing the three buildings.

Despite that, I have really enjoyed playing this.  I am working through the campaign and when that getting a little too frustrating, I go over to a Free play game. Free play is more straightforward, but still puzzle-like. How do you connect all the producers and consumer efficiently? I have built some routes out and then had a better idea, so I go back and rebuild it all. The rebuild is just as fun.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a hard one really. I wish there was a third option, maybe, for rating rather than just yes or no. 

It is a good game. Not great, good. Looks pretty and can be quite entertaining for many. If you are completely new to the genre, it might even be great. It's got detailed models of vehicles, it has simple logic what to do and how, move stuff around. Easy. It might challenge you, it may not challenge you, depends on you really. But for a TPF1 veteran like me, it's boring. 

Somehow, it lost its magic on this upgrade and after around 60 hours, I find myself going back to the first version. Only 2 cargo items per city is not a deal breaker here. It gives you a bit more challenge and you have to think more, that's fine. But refunding your build errors? Restoring landscape after deleting tracks etc? Limited city sizes? New emissions mechanism which reduced the max population in relation to emission amounts in the city? Sure, but why don't i have any way to reduce them? The miniscule differences between vehicles makes no difference. Maintenance or lack of it affects couple of points. But that's it. That's all you can do. Does your truck do 71 or 68 on emissions makes no difference. So why bother? 

Also, since the upkeep cost for vehicles doesn't go up over time and the emission effect is minimum, only reason to repair or replace vehicles is cosmetics and capacity / speed. Where is the fun in that? 

There is some nice additions too, like how you can now edit individual vehicles or bunch of them, replace all buses on couple of clicks etc. But that doesn't make up to what was lost. 

So, if you are new then maybe this is good for you. Maybe you'll enjoy Transport Fever 1 more. I know i do, as do many other "veterans". For a TPF1 veteran, this probably isn't for you. You'll like it for a while, but eventually you'll find it boring and start looking back into TPF1. 

Also, even after 6 months out, this doesn't seem that have that many good mods compared to TPF1, especially American / USA vehicles. Looks like people who made large chunk of them are still with the old game. I know i'll be there too except few occasional visits to this when i want some eye candy.

It's not yes, and it's not hard no. It is a solid definitely maybe :)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
For those that did not own the original Transport Fever, this version is just as good if not better than the earlier version.
The user interface is clean and crisp and there is more information at your fingertips. Graphics are better also.
They have added all sorts of new features in this version, the best being the editable stations and cargo areas. Some features have been removed but as you did not own the first version, you will not miss them.

For those that DID own TF1, there are some good new features as mentioned above, but......why did they restrict the industries to certain towns? I preferred it when i had to supply every town with every type of goods. Yes, it was a challenge to do, but that's what i want, a challenge.

What I do not understand is the way the terrain reshapes when you delete a rail track or road, like you were never there, you never saw a thing, there was never a railway here! What's with that?? I can build a track cutting a mountain in half, with a steep bank either side, then delete the track, and the cutting disappears like i was never there? What if i wanted to use that cutting again in the future? I have to pay again to do it...

Don't get me wrong, I like this version, but I miss some aspects of the old one.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I really wish I could give two separate scores for this game. The campaign is ABSOLUTE TRASH. I don't know how to put in words the absolute loathing I feel for this campaign. But the sandbox mode, absolutely nails it if you have that logistical management itch. Unfortunately, unless you are buying this purely for a sandbox simulator, I don't recommend it.

Seriously -- the campaign will genuinely kill your will to play this game. I've had to take several breaks because the missions are that irritating. A lot of them deliberately have you play in a way that inconveniences you simply for the fact of doing it (e.g. don't travel X distance by rail, don't have vehicles here, etc.). And a similarly large amount of missions have completely obtuse and obscure goals with poorly written pseudo RP objectives ("Find a weed in the mountains!" = use the demolish tool on random vegetation). I swear to god, if I could fire the entire campaign design team I would do it a million times over. I absolutely HATE the campaign.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I am used to play the much much older Transport Tycoon Deluxe game and its open source clone. This game has quite a few improvements over the old game but I don't think it is worth the heavy price tag.

Especially frustrating are the campaign levels (havn't played the sandbox yet) where I constantly have to look up how to finish tasks because the instructions aren't clear at all. For example: In one campaign you are asked to transport "pomp" to a building site. When looking at the map you'll find the pomp factory. What it doesn't say anywhere is that you have to transport people somewhere over the map to generate pomp. Congratulations to the person who actually figured that one out.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I think its a sound time for a review and more so after I watched the latest episode of Colonel Failure mainline series; he was half way through the episode and then went into a review of game.

I agree with all he said, the game graphically speaking is steps above TP1, however is that enough to hold my attention or the game players?

He spoke about the emissions, when he mentioned this, I was like, oh yeah, the game has emissions. It seems to be an add on in which adds nothing to the game play, the towns grow no matter what, emissions or no emissions it doesn’t stop a town, this game play could have had so much extra level detail, but it missed the point.

The area I believe its missed the point massively, is the economy, playing against another company or online people, meh, its hit or miss, however when you are playing TF1, you had to think out lines, think out what you’ll do, and replace trains when they get to their end age. In this version nothing, you don’t need to replace the trains/trucks/boats, they just look like rust buckets, but the profits still role back in. If an update from the developers was done, this is the one thing I am requesting they install back in the game, costs for transport increases as the game gets older. 

The economy could have also been tweeted, why does it cost the same to build a line in 1850 as it does in 1990 – surly the game should have had a built in CPI that increases every year or 10yrs, even if it’s only 1.5% increase, it would then add complexity to the game, or a level of hardness that TF1 had.   

Which bring me to the biggest issue with the game, in the scenarios you have a range of wonderful goods that are required to be delivered to the towns. In free mode, the same as TF1, why wasn’t it changed in TF2 to allow a user when they created a map for themselves to have an endless supply of goods they wanted to transport? This would have created a greater play through and also add some major complexity to supply lines. Towns could still have 2 products, which is fine, but make it more random. 

Overall a great game, that has brought many hours of enjoyment, but the developers as much as they went forward, also went backwards with the game. Fingers are crossed that updates to the game bring some hardness back to the game and most of all curved stations. I doubt a developer will read the comments by a little Australian on the other side of the globe, but thanks for a great game, now can we just define it with a great update? 

I give it 7 / 10 – graphically awesome, game play good, just needed two more months in development to get the news part correct.

Crashes on startup with a stock ubuntu install (3700x+rx580). Only launches using a workaround. Game is plagued with graphical glitches, hickups and horrible framerates. The UI and controls are unintuitive, which wouldn't be much of a problem if the tutorial was any good at explaining it.
I love the idea of a more-detailed, 3d OpenTTD, but this doesn't hit the mark. If you can put up with it's faults the rest of the game looks like fun, but I've asked for a refund.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is my favourite game in its genre. In my experience, it surpasses both City Skylines and Planet Coaster, both high quality games at the top of their respected fields. The reason for these games inferiority over Transport Fever is simply down to the differences in how the game operates.

In both City Skylines and Planet Coaster, you start with nothing, where the aim of the game is to correctly organise a bunch of parts to where you have one, large, profitable entity at the end of the game (e.g. the city or theme park). In Transport Fever 2, you start off in a world where there are already pre-built and positioned components. The aim of the game is not to place a bunch of parts to form a single entity, but to connect these already existing components to one another in an organised and efficient fashion to produce a collection of interconnected systems that work together to produce as high a profit as possible. At the end you are left with many small connected entities which work totally independently rather than one, mass functioning entity. It's for this reason I like this game so much.

To conclude, I would highly recommend this game to anybody interested. With its unique game mechanics and super satisfying gameplay, all other construction and management games feel inferior! Though what do I know, since, realistically, it is all down to personal preference :)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Hmm, somewhat torn about this one. Fundamentally a grafics update with an overhauled UI which is kind of nice once you get used to it... but made some steps in the wrong direction as well.
Also a lot easier on Hard mode compared to TF1 as your vehicles only lose value and produce more pollution once they get older instead of being more expensive to maintain. Also you can now edit trains while they're on track. Or tell a vehicle to drive back to the garage to be sold, only that now it's sold on the spot.

The one thing that makes me give a thumb down is that there is no overtaking of slower cars. Which makes multiple lane roads pretty much redundant. In my case i had a long range bus between two cities on a highway and a more recently truck line to provide grain to a factory. 3 lanes, but all private cars and trucks getting stuck and forming long lines behind the slower busses. That completley killed immersion for me. I guess you can simply not use these roads and focus more on trains but why are they in the game in the first place then?

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Hi there, 
I was waiting long time for TF2, and when it arrived I played it for approx 40 hours (scenarios, free games) and... I finally de-installed it. Have now re-installed TF1 in which I play the free games (not the scenarios) again and again. It is just so much more fun with being allowed to build a much more complex and thrilling economy. Also the reality feeling of TF1 is so much better. I think it is mainly the proportions of the trains, cars and the distances between cities. Also the maps feel somehow more real and the overall game complexity is much higher. 

I am so sorry for TF2. For me personally it is a big disappointment. I will wait for TF3...

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Fantastic game and developers. Loved the first Transport Fever, and this feels like a real sequel where they have iterated, incorporated feedback and improved the overall game in meaningful ways such as graphical quality as well as performance. Such a relaxing yet engrossing (and sometimes thrilling, in a way) experience to sit down with. Yes, there is a learning curve involved and I am still climbing it - there are plenty of great youtubers out there with let's play videos and guides to learn from. The modding community is always coming up with amazing wonders in the form of new vehicle assets, maps, functionality mods and things you wouldn't ever have thought of. Creating an interconnected group of cities, with a functional transportation system between them is so satisfying and pleasing to sit back and watch. A real gem in the genre of train strategy games.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
To be honest I love this game. I love the process of planning out the transportation routes and watch the cities grow over time. And I hate to leave a negative review. Yet this game is so poor on optimization and performance. This game lags heavily after mid-late game and crashes frequently. I hope the devs would test their game better instead of rushing it out to the market. Without patches to fix the game, it would be literally unplayable for a lot of poorer or more casual gamers. Wouldn't recommend to buy the game at the current status.

TLDR: poor optimization; don't buy before the game is fixed

[Edit: I can edited my review to reflect the fact that the last major update largely stabilize the game (although late game still is a bit sluggish). The devs will actually improve the game instead of leaving it in a poor state.]

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game is very addicting and enjoyable!

If you like cities skylines for the transport aspects of the game, then I can not see why you would not enjoy this game. This game does not contain the same level of customisation that games like cities skylines and planet coaster has. This is focused on the day to day operations of a transport company. You are required to ship products in Industries and passengers between cities. This is focused around the use of trains, but ships and road vehicles play a large role too. Also, I can imagine aircraft's play a similar role, however I am still in the late 1800's ;) I do love the progression trough time, as it makes the game feel like you are developing your company with the technology available.

All in all, you should buy the game if it is within your spectrum interest as it is a great experience :)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever (1) had a lot of niggly bits and pieces that made it annoying to play at times - those have all been eradicated in this version and some new ones were introduced to replace them. That said, this game is very engaging the - One - More - Click - syndrome is strong with this one.

Performance seems better than the old version as well, something that always annoyed me was the end-game stage where the PC would crawl. I'm playing on a considerably better machine now though, so not sure if that is true in general. 

The modding community is brilliant - some really nice assets out there, do use the Workshop!

Would recommend for those of you that are (still) looking for the perfect Railroad/Transport Tycoon replacement.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Well let's start on the performance of the game and quality. Trouble is the performance of the engine to utilize memory controller and CPU but it is demanding to the V-memory (e.g uses 7756/8196MB) I cannot get anymore assets or mods that uses more v-memory. (e.g uses 7756/8196MB v-memory and 1424/2396MB s-memory) it's really like Cities Skylines with the memory usage. other than that the game is amazing.

Graphics - 6/10 Score
Game Engine - 2/5 Score
Anti-graphics - 2/5 Score
Controls - 9/10 Score
V-memory capacity - 8/16 Size
S-Memory capacity - 16/64 Size
Gameplay out of city's 8/10 Score

Gametime 4/5 Score
Recommendation 3/5 Total

title: Transport Fever 2
review: After 100 hours on TF2, coupled with several updates since launch, I can confidently say that TF2 is marked improvement over the first Transport Fever (in which I played over 500 hours). There is nothing the first game does that the second doesn't do better. If you want a refreshing change from Cities: Skylines, this is it: you focus on the movement of people and goods, and let the cities build themselves organically in response to your choices. Tip: the campaign makes for a good tutorial, but where the game really shines is the free game on the Megalomaniacal map in Hard mode starting in 1850.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: As I just passed the thousand hour mark, I thought it would be fitting to give the game a rating. This, and it's predecessor, may be the most magical and wondrous games I have ever played. Anyone who enjoyed OTTD, TTD, or Chris Sawyers locomotion will be enchanted with this game on first playing. The few minor issues of the first game have almost all been fixed, and the challenge and beauty will never leave you bored. In addition, there is an absolutely wonderful community surrounding the game, constantly producing mods, guides, and recommendations. In short, if you like logistics, building, and beauty, this game may be for you.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So, I figure after a while (154 hours) into the game I can finally review it.
Overall it is good and, especially if you never owned Transport Fever, worth buying.

Now, saying all that, there are pros and cons between this and the original.
The pros are quality of life features - especially the station editor which makes a huge difference if you don't think it is realistic to build maximum length stations from day one. It is also prettier and performs better. Trams also seem to run better. There are also many more useful stats - it is much more obvious why things do and do not happen.

The major con, in my view, is that logistically it is even easier than the first one. In Transport Fever you had six things to  deliver to each town to make it grow. Now it is just two. Saying that the two seem more important for growth than the six were before.

Generally, like TF one, once you figure out how to make money it is pretty much free-form train set building. It is fun, but not exactly a challenge. Saying that you can make some great train sets with a little road support for certain things.

To be honest, once past the early years where trains are just not profitable in hard mode, it becomes a train game with everything else just there for variety.

Still it is fun - which is the main reason for the recommendation, if a little qualified.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have put over 3000 hours of game time into this franchise across the years. For this reason, it is with a heavy heart that I must do what I do here. But I not only cannot recommend this game, but feel I am obliged to actively discourage anyone from buying it.
The TL;DR version: they broke it. And did so because they have implemented a "feature" which had previously been handled by a mod, but the developers did so in a way that was so badly done, they massively unbalanced the game, and ruined it.
The longer version: in earlier incarnations, time in the game could be dilated (slowed down) or compressed (sped up) with a mod. Note: this is completely separate to changing the speed of the game. 
Changing the game speed (which has always been an option in the game) merely changes how fast things happen. The day goes from a being a second long to half or quarter of a second, and all the mechanics such as maintenance, revenue, cargo generation - they all happen at the same rate per game day/game year etc.
In earlier versions (Train Fever, Transport Fever), the mod that sped up or slowed down shifted how fast or slow things happened *within game time* so a game year might be longer but the maintenance costs/revenue per unit of cargo/rate of cargo generation was similarly slowed. This made longer routes, or less frequent routes, viable.
In the implementation of this feature into the heart of the game for TpF2, the developers did not factor these changes in the financial aspects of the time compression/dilation, and because the time multiplier can be changed *within the game* (unlike the mod which, once active, could not be turned on and off at will) they have massively unbalanced the economic side of the game, making it unplayable.
As such, I urge you to not spend your money.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After worrying that the first Transport Fever might be better than this, I've decided not to spend a dime on this. Until today I decided to give it a try and refund if I didn't like it, to my surprise.. this is SO MUCH better than the first one. Not just graphically, the mechanics and UI have all been totally improved. I suggest you all to ignore whatever reviews bashing this being not "fresh" enough and see what have been changed/improved by yourself, that is if you've played the first Transport Fever of course.

For new players, this game is so worth your time, both learning and playing it. I went from not knowing anything to making mistakes to being a millionaire in 20 hours of non-stop grinding. You will never see the day again.

This [b]IS[/b] one of the best management games I've ever played.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Later Edit (some 100h+ later) So the game looks pretty and nicer maps, better customization. Mods are more and more but game lacks big time. Towns still refuse to grow on max population beyond 2-3k no matter what! :// Furthermore if you set great public transport (e.g. Trams/Buses) in towns they become Ghost cities. Nothing else is moving in town except your bus/tram lines vehicles. 2k town pop with no people walking on the streets. With the rare ocasion of a car coming to your city and vanishing soon after.
And to top it all found the best "money cheat" in game. If you play a map on mid or large and set a Air Cargo route your set for the rest of the game length. No more worries with cash flow whatsoever.... I bet this works on small maps too. And it works regardless of the size of your cargo planes.

So where is the fun then if you get unlimited mountains of cash as soon as you can build an airport and service a cargo line? ...

Air cargo if you ask me should only satisfy the demand of a product/good and as revenue to just offset the transport with no profit.


---------------------------------------------------

TF1  Was awesome! I have over 900h played. The Free mods made it better and better by every addition. But sad to say that TF2 atm feels more like a UI DLC + some extra features. Some sort of Transport Fever 1.5. 

One of the best mods in TF1 was curvy stations, bendable ones. TF2 does not provide one.  The grey overlay when your looking at data layers is not appealing at all, hard to distinguish between features. Also the colors representing the  layout in towns are very pale and sometimes hard to spot a green in a sea of yellow or a yellow in a sea of green buildings.  POV camera on trains has issues as you can look from under the map ...  The street conections between the train stations and any road only link it as tiny foot paths, what is that @Urban Games?! Looks unreal and ridiculous. You should be able to connect a full road to a train station and not a foot path! All in all so far TF2 is an disappointment.  But in Urban Games fashion as they listen to their customers things should be fixed in a future patch (very soon i hope). Until then stick to TF1 for a real challenge. 

P.S.  Many, many people complain on Streams in regards to the towns population size. I had in TF1 towns over 7k constantly. It seems here that in TF2 that number cant EVER be achieved as the max number is preset no matter what you do. Please fix this. For me is a huge drawback :S

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Grade B+
This is more like Transport Fever 1 HD, than an actual sequel. Mechanically, the game is identical to 1 and just as solid, with some tweaks here and there but nothing that will really make you lose your hat. The biggest change is the graphics and that grass really makes a difference. Maps looks much better although now I am waiting for Transport Fever 3 to make the trees and grass sway with wind...

Biggest let down for me is probably campaign and general mechanics which does not really make you feel like you are an entrepreneur especially the bonus missions are still goffy and silly. It has its charm and some may like it but not my cup of tea personally. Mission also have bad tendecy to have poor goal descriptions making me google all the time. Man I miss Railroad Tycoon campaign where it really felt like you were running a business.

The now added ability to create a combined Freight/Passenger train is really a godsend, the terrain gen has also improved, with adding Tropical type gen, (as someone who lives in that Climate that is a added bonus) which can be a challenge if not in sandbox mode.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Very good game regarding transport type game. Highly recommended to try. I got addicted immediately, older fan of TDU2,Sim city etc... games.
Game is lacking end content but with mods you can get some better experience and by that i mean expanding cities and lines you don't get much satisfaction because you don't have any end goals other then your desires. No natural disasters, no inovations, researchs anything to keep you engaged like Cities:Skyline.
Even on hard mode i get so much money that after some time i can't spend it no matter what i do even if i have the most expensive trains, planes.
One big downside for me is the perfomance issue that you get when you start playing games on very large maps no matter how good are your PC specs.
Game is just not optimized by developers because once you get big transport lines, passengers going everywhere game begins to stutter.
So for example you start new game in 1850, 16 cities , everything looks smooth, you start decorating cities, lines, you become very satisfied with your city, become proud of yourself that you managed to make big transport lines and then advancing through years 2000-2050 you start realizing the stutterness when clicking through cities, adding new stops, rearanging lines etc... so you start surfing web on how to optimize game, your PC but all that goes to waste because no matter you do, game will stutter after some time and it will kill your gaming experience and you will probably become bored with it like me... 
I just don't have anymore desire to play free game knowing that after 20-30 hours invested in game, the experience will be terrible.
Devs please fix something about perfomance, add quests, some variety through the game, not just relying on modders to fix the game for players.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The best part of any city builder game? The infrastructure! 

For TF, Cities and industry are present at the start of every game and grow organically based on the connections you create. All the models (buildings, cars, trains, planes, ships) are detailed and distinct, and the time and tech progression feels natural. This is the closest spiritual successor to Railroad Tycoon around (though you can play through without building any rail lines if you want to). Highly Recommend. 

Not present vs RT3: Competitors, or stock trading.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I was wary of buying this game. Its gameplay might be repetitive, but the fun of the game isn't the big picture for me, but the little details. Is this station to far? Will this cause pollution? Where do passengers want to go? 

It is a breathtaking game graphics-wise. It has a one noticeable rendering glitch, where multi-segment vehicles will be separated during u-turns but otherwise its is pretty refined. 

It is interesting witnessing transport history unfold. Where dirt roads gave way to highways, and the little village turns into a city. It shows the need for infrastructure, something that I always adore. There always has to be demand. You might not make highways until later on (maybe never), if you don't need them, but you probably will to use trucks to there maximum potential. 

I'm no history expert, but the realism in this game is more than any other game I've played. I don't know what else to say, but if you are into this genre, and the little details in games, this is for you.

PS. The wildlife on the map have easter eggs. Be sure to click on them!

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After amassing over 150 hours in TF2, I can finally say I'm ready to give a proper review.

Pros:
- Significantly improved performance and memory usage (especially after the last major update)
- Largely similar to TF1, but a lot of small refinements that make the game play better as a whole
- Modular stations add a significant amount of realism and flexibility that was missing in TF1
- Ability to significantly adjust (aka stop) time progression. My one complaint about TF1 was that time moved too fast. It took you sometimes a decade to properly build a line, when in reality (especially the early years) entirely networks were built in the span of a few years.

Cons:
- Railway AI could be improved from TF1. An element of dynamic reaction could be implemented that would greatly improve operations and greatly reduce the need for duplicate tracks in areas. Case in point: two track line with slower freights and faster passenger trains. Freights (if being followed by a passenger) could take a siding and hold for the passenger to pass. Otherwise, the freight would carry on. Or if you have two trains meeting on a single track at a siding, the first train takes the siding and the 2nd one sails through unrestricted, rather than trains in the same direction always taking the siding because of signal placement.
- Signalling could use a significant spruce up. Currently signals display two indications (regardless of the mod): clear and stop. Some mods add a time delay so show yellow, when the signal is really a red stop. And signals do not show routing either, which I feel is an element of animation that would go a long way, especially for systems that so visibly display a routing (thing British Rail semaphore lights). If Locomotion can show this kind of information, surely TF2 could.
- Bridge pier spacing makes no sense. Sometimes they're close, and sometimes they're not. There should be uniform spacing of bridge piers no matter what, with the only time piers go absent is for longer crossings of waterways, for example. We should also have an option for "no bridge piers" but the bridges length is severely restricted (basically long enough to go over a road or maybe 3-4 railway tracks). This would be beneficial for overpasses to avoid the  random single pier on the side appearing, or constant collision issues with short bridges.
- Ultimately this feels like a reskin of TF1 with some operational improvements, but those improvements go a long way to avoiding this being a failed second version of a game.

Wish list for next time:
- Two additional categories for trains: Great Britain and Asia. While Europe can cover GB, there's a significant following and a character with railways in Great Britain that is more unique than the whole of Europe, and having a separate category for not only it but Asia as well would help to categorize vehicles better and allow for a specific set of vehicles to more accurately be played in a game (i.e. British vehicles only, rather than everything that's run in Europe).
- More advanced signalling. Even just give us the next two signals (so you can accurately display a green, yellow and red signal) as well as show switch indication if there is a switch within the next X distance ahead of the signal. For the basic game signals, this could mean the top signal is fir the straight route and the bottom signal is for the diverging route. This opens things up immensely to showing a wider variety of signals in the game as produced by the modding community (British colour lights with semaphores, multi-aspect searchlights from North America, etc)
- The ability to yard and store cars in a depot, rather than fixed consists. Say you have a train between points A and B. Sometimes you need to haul less than a full train. So the train would actually leave however many cars at the depot and just run with the full cars, rather than running empty (thus slowing the train down, thus incurring increase operating costs, etc). To do so would mean a yard would need to exist, and this could be nearby the station and cars simply appear or disappear (fade in/out) as they are needed. This could be further expanded to warnings such as "Train X has been full the last 4 trips. You should make more cars available and expand the trains length".
- More flexible/realistic/visually appealing truck depots. Simulating trucks having coal or ore dumped into them, rather than magically filling up would be far for appealing. Or for trucks being loaded with goods, have them reverse to a loading dock or a crane lift crates onto the flatbed. While the TF2 truck depot is very flexible, it is visually un-appealing and to be honest, I avoid using trucks because of it.
- More uniform and generic bridge types by default. Still to this day, no one has created the single through or deck girder bridge with either concrete piers or steel trestle towers. These bridges were all over Europe and North America, yet they remain missing in the game. Some styles have come close, but don't capture the flavour.
- Railways in the street. Very common in older towns around the world. Would allow access to industries without the need to demolish entire districts. Could be heavily speed restricted (15 mph-20 km/h) and single track only on wider roads, but very helpful for some. And further to that ...
- Tram Tracks not in the road BY DEFAULT. It shouldn't have to take a custom mod to have tram tracks that aren't in a road. This is how many modellers (including myself) make rapid transit networks in our cities. And, to further that, allow tram tracks to be built within railway stations.

Ok, I think I'm good now. Back to playing the game ...

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
For the money its not great. I would have refunded but hours in was still trying to give the game a chance...

Visually the game looks great and has a great feature of allowing you to have a first person view of any vehicle - Maps can be pretty huge but look quite generic through the random seeds/settings.

The issues though:
- A poor, unintuitive UI that for example wont let you to sell a vehicle from the profitability/management screen - instead you have to open the view on each vehicle or highlight a bunch in the routing screen.
- You have to sell a whole train and rebuy it if you say want to change a single carriage
- really clunky track laying and road placing 
- The campaign has really repetitive "missions" that involve you clicking the big hovering question mark in the sky again and again as if doing this was gameplay.
- The clunky rotate and minimum size for stations means you may need to demolish half of a city just to place a one track station
- There are just way more features (like cargo delivery time/pay and competitor AI or multiplayer) in OpenTT and that is free  [Transport Tycoon now 20+ years old too so no excuse for having LESS gameplay than that old game]

In summary:

This is a game for people who want to play with a model train set and admire the beauty of the 5:45 Trans-Pennine Express rather than play a "game" as such. The workshop is like 90% people just uploading art assets for their 'special' train or favourite lorry logos etc - if you get a boner over the look of some obscure Canadian freight train this game may be for you.

Save your money though and play OpenTT if you want a 'game' - this is way way overpriced for a 6/10 game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
April 2020- Games has returned to being unplayable, saves don't load, maps don't load. Avoid

March-2020 - Ever had a train set as a kid, sure u did. Now follow 170 years of transport on land sea and air. As a studio known for train games, the train is still king, but connecting the rail to the road is the route to fantastic wealth. Essentially an re-issue/expansion of TF1, the game looks gorgeous, has a mission based tutorial and has an ever growing workshop but remains a very chill game. Ships and docks remain under developed and still some weird UI decisions, but now recommend. Choo Choo! 

THE REVIEW below is now out of date thankfully, performance issues have largely been dealt with and the game is mostly stable (march 2020) and the devs are posting on the steam discussions page. 

Feb 2020 -The game works for some people for other its unplayable, including me. Loading times can be around an hour then the game plays terribly. There are issues for laptop users and seemingly nvidia owners. There is no support forum and no activity from the devs on the discussions page. CTDs, freezes etc don't seem uncommon. 
AVOID until fixed.

Otherwise the game seems to be an upgrade to tf1 but essentially much the same game. Tis v pretty if it works though.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It has a few errors in some maps I think they may have fixed some of those but I was being kicked out a lot in Japan campaign randomly until I finally finished it.   Other than that no really any huge bugs in this game other than busy maps like that one. 

The rest of this review is mainly for those who played Transport Fever (1) not 2.

They took away some things that I really liked being able to limit stockpiles and having many types of products between cities is now reduced to simple two.  The developer claim that it makes it more difficult I think it just makes it more boring.  I am not able to do what I want any longer many cities request things that make no sense and many cities request nothing at all. The bigger city may not need anything at all.   

The other issues are some items within maps are confusing to what to do or even work unless done exactly like developers request for example a STAR pattern is made by me yet not done exactly like developers want hence I have to try combos many different ways waiting to finish it.   Also many items such as delivering to TRIBES makes no sense how to do it try building various buildings nothing seemed to work as what developers expected I guess.   Joining the Nazis or Allies makes no difference in any way far as quest seems you just don't get one of achievements if you do one and not the other.  

 I liked the original and besides new city changes with stockpiles the overall rest of the train system is much easier yet they said it would be harder with only two cargo types.   No it's much easier since you got more tracks per node yet less freight types to deal with sometimes zero freight but only passengers.  The advantages in the new one is more trains per node which old one limited you to only few so made choosing what to put on a train or truck more difficult to choose what could be dropped off or loaded.  Now so many trains can be added per node also you can edit the nodes seemly easier than prior since typically dealing with only 2 freight types it's not difficult it's simple to move only two items from a city prior could be many items.  That's another thing that made old one harder to manage freight in old one verses now before I had to disable pickups or drop offs on a node nope not anymore.   I do like that they added more ability with nodes and ability to edit and add more train lanes but simply stating don't like the request from a city to be either 0 or two.

 I already played most of scenarios, I still don't get what the difference is with the different buildings added to the station CARGO / PASSENGER I can see they are bigger but seems I can not make sense of them other than waste of space. There is zero indication what these size differences do in game.  The length of cargo / passenger docks obviously allow more freight but far as Connections to street buildings with small or giant cargo buildings make no difference from my experience.  You think the bigger ones would create more passengers or give more freight space or cause some of the missions for passengers to not mind waiting hence longer but none of that is happening.

review: It is a unique challenge. Being able to choose map seeds that cater to your preferred style is a very nice feature that I'm glad exists. The downside is that its not nearly as dynamic as it could be. (There is a lot of potential to Rockefeller or Carnegie your way to the top) there's also not a lot of logistic challenges as far as needing to buy materials for your railroad's maintenance costs... (this could be a very exciting and challenging part of the game but its undeveloped) as well as the potential to get into tiffs with competing AI driven transport companies like sabotage, contracting, mergers, stock market options etc. The pros of what is  there, however, outweigh the cons of what is not. I look forward to seeing this game grow even more. (and I hope it does)

review: While I would recommend this game, it does come with a few drawbacks. The game feels empty. Its almost like they released it without being finished. After you have reached year 2020, there are no new vehicles. This was extremely disappointing. Where is my train that reaches 500-800km/h or the plane that does 2000km/h. You will also need to add the functionality to add remove stop signs, robots as well as adjust arrows on the streets. Factories should not really have a limit on how big it can get, but it might need a limit of growth over time. Having a factory produce only a small amount is ridiculous. They should be able to grow like towns do and keep up with towns. You won’t be disappointed at buying the game for this price, but it is half a game – not a full game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: This game had me hooked in about 10 minutes. Once i figured out what's what I was away. This is a grand version of Transport Tycoon. Superb visuals and game play. It's a cinch to lay track, roads and buildings etc. You can click on any vehicle, person or a bird flying in the sky and you have an immersive first person view.  I am playing the campaign and it is the most fun i have had in ages. I am running a high spec machine and there is a slight problem with popup trees and the like and occasional pauses but I imagine they will be sorted out quickly. This is a quality game and I have no hesitation in recommending it. You will not be disappointed.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: It's evidently the same engine as the first one, it still has some of the exact same issues at it's predecessor (track laying doing weird things and bridges/tunnels having a mind of their own to name a couple, but really there's loads). Though it's also clear they did a lot of work on the graphics, physics and models & I love the modular train/cargo stations. On the bigger maps after you get fully going it still runs like hot garbage, it's optimisation it questionable, that's on a 2700x, rtx 2070, 32gb & m.2. It's probably worth noting as the game loads every single vehicle, player & renders them into everything it's a very CPU heavy game. Stick to smaller maps if you pc/laptop isn't decent otherwise you can look forward top stop motion game play. Though, jokes aside, the game is absolutely great fun, there's a lot of better features, more polished menus, much much better graphics & overall it's more immersive. I deeply enjoy playing this & love the modding community for the amazing work that goes into some of the models & scripts.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
As usual with Transport Fever: what could have been fun experience is ruined by bugs.
First, the campaign. They give you the outlines where you have to place your buildings, but the building always have to be connected to the road *before* you place it. Which results in suboptimal placement. They also don't let you place new roads. Sometimes the outlines where you have to place your buildings are already occupied by your buildings or infrastructure -- annoying.

With the sandbox... Well, if you try to build the lines with a few hops, Road to Train to Road again or something like that, sometimes the shipment just does not want to go out, no matter what you do. Sometimes the line that was working fine just stops working for no reason whatsoever. I don't even have that much time in this game, and I've already encountered this enough times to be pissed.

Overall, the game is playable, but I don't see much new content compared to TF1

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A lovely game to while away some hours; definite improvements over TPF1, though it has to be said there's still some elements I find frustrating - in that it could have been improved by changing certain gameplay details without compromising development time, but it just seems they took some odd decisions here and there.
Still, perfectly happy to give the development team my money, as it's by far the best Transport Tycoon-style game out there at the mo (for fans of the original TT) and the more support they get, the more they're able to improve it in future iterations!
I can easily lose myself both in the detail of the game (which arguably is actually over the top, graphically, for what is required in a transport management game) and the overall immensity of the systems you can create. Definitely worth a try, and top marks also have to be given to the realms of extremely talented mod-creators who have contributed to filling in some of the gaps of the base game  :)
Thanks Urban Games for finally giving me a game I always dreamed of when I was younger - some improvements can be made, but I've every confidence they'll be changed and upgraded in TPF3!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
[h1]A good game but spoilt by instability[/h1]

I've enjoy the game so far as I can play it. I experienced a few random crashes whilst playing but now I've hit a barrier and I'm unable to progress the campaign due to regular crashes. Reading the many comments regarding 'crashes' in the Discussion pages, it appears the problem is 'ping-ponging' between application and system causes. My PC meets all (or exceeds) the stated system requirements for TF2 and is capable of playing some heavy duty games without incident. So in summary, a good game but be prepared for random crashes and some frustration due to the instability.

Updated the review after playing around with the graphics settings and finally being able to progress the campaign - if you are still experiencing crashes after the March 2020 update, I suggest lowering your screen resolution and restarting; repeat until stable. The game memory management is such that most rigs will struggle and crash on higher settings. A recommendation to the developers is to introduce an automated graphics configuration utility, like the ones adopted by Eugen System (and others).

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It is a good game overall but I was conisdering giving it a thumbs down. I'll try to break it down why.
First the positives:
+ it is a great transport game, in my opinion the best out there at the moment
+ the best features of TF1 are still here, especially mods
+ a lot of annoying mechanics from TF1 were upgraded, like station upgrades and multiple vehicle upgrades
+ graphics were improved visibly
+ new Asian environment with own vehicles is a plus
+ you don't have to deliver every product to every city, hallelujah!
Now the negatives:
- it's not that big of an upgrade, feels more like TF1 DLC than stand-alone game
- apart from new region number of new vehicles is disappointing
- industry was simplified, not what I expected
- maps are still too small to make late fast trains and airplanes resonable in most cases

Overall 8/10

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Having now spent over 100 hours playing this game I now feel in a good position to be able to review it honestly. It would definitely be hard to find a more pleasing game in terms of both its appearance and game play, just boarding any vehicle, being either truck, train, boat or aircraft provides such a realistic journey, one that any game would find it hard to surpass. The game play is solid and the campaign is excellent although I did get stuck on the 13th mission (Japan high speed loco's) and so moved onto the free play element which also provides a really good challenge. If there is one criticism I would make it would be that there could be a few more different types of product on the map to move around and that towns maybe required more than just the two items (excluding passengers) to satisfy their demand. Other than that though this is a great game that you will get hours of pleasure from, that's of course if you're into this type of transportation game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 hits the sweet spot between never ending optimization possibilities and beatiful model railroad aesthetics.
I find myself switching constantly between just looking at my lines working like a clockwork, establishing new lines and optimizing old ones.

I stopped rather frustrated a while ago because the performance was getting worse (especially in train station configuration) and existing lines where cumbersome to manage. Luckily this changed with the latest updates by improving performance and providing some usability features like editing existing trains (just to name one usefull feature).

The campaign on the other hand was well narrated and fun for the first few missions but became quite repetitive fast. Many mission targets also took just too long to complete. I would wish for some scenarios where existing networks have to be optimized to remove congestion/improve efficiency or reducing pollution in a city to a certain minimum without cutting the ressource supply.

Overall I'm really happy with the current version of the game. However a few more statistics about my lines would be nice. Curved train stations would also be nice to have again.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It's a good game. I've not gotten through the campaign yet (though the campaign is actually just an extended tutorial from the look of it, to cover all the mechanics so you're ready for sandbox).

Conclusion:

I like that it's real-time, like a Paradox game, you can get on with stuff and the world will move on, so you always seem busy with something.

But:

After having played Anno 1800, I really appreciate being able to zoom in and see interactions going on between different objects in the game, and a really well drawn and animated world of people. This doesn't do it anywhere near as well, but there is a certain satisfaction from watching vehicles moving around.

EDIT

I've also discovered playing this game is like JAVA PROGRAMMING 10 years ago! So infuriating when you click "execute" and nothing happens. There's a problem with a line but the devs just haven't bothered to invest a bit more time and put some realistic voice over to tell you what the problem is. So it can be incredibly infuriating when stuff just doesn't work but you have idea why.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I've been using Steam for a few years now and a couple hundred games. I can't recall ever leaving a review even though there are games I love and games that are meh.  But this game is so unstable that I had to leave a warning.  It started off crashing about every 30-40 minutes, after a few hours the crashes became around every 20-30 minutes.  After about 7 hours of game play (that's a lot of crashes and restarts) it got to the point that the 10 minute auto save never got a chance to save in the last 3 times I tried playing it.  I have a fairly hefty machine, in fact that's the only thing that allowed me to keep trying as long as I did was the fast reload, so it not lack of hardware.  And I have no issues with any other games or software.  So, you've been warned.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The game is beautiful, but it is absolutely easy. To earn lots of money, regardless of the scenario, just start with routes where you can earn both on the way and return (usually fuel) and that's it ...

There is little variety of goods. I had to add a mod that expanded the number of products to have a challenge and even so, it was still very easy, even in hard mode, with a map full of mountains and water.

After a while (when you have about 100 million in cash) it becomes impossible to go bankrupt.

Our luck is that we have the modding community to improve the game, otherwise we would not have a challenge ...

Besides, I have nothing to comment on. It's a beautiful game ...

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 feels more like Transport Fever 1.5.  Why?  Basic game play, in-game economics & workflow are largely unchanged from Transport Fever 1.  Also some of my desired features for a game of this type are missing.  I have a feeling that the developers are relying too much on modding community to take up the slack.  However, there's really not much modders can do when it comes to core game mechanics.

That said, I still enjoy playing TF2.  The graphics and level of details are amazing.  If you can look past the lack of automatic placement of train signals, lack of AI ability to pass slow moving vehicles on multi-lane highways, lack of distinction of fast v. slow freight types (i.e. PAX v. coal), the core game mechanics are rather solid and will suck up hours and hours of your quarantine time.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: A very good engrossing simulation.  The only thing I would suggest by way of improvement is more intuitive cargo facilities.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'm a Transport Fever 2 convert. The game has gotten much better and continues to improve. I used to be addicted to Railroad Tycoon 3 and I was sorely disappointed with Train Fever.  This game is fascinating and is certainly enjoyable to play but still has a way to go. 

Railroad Tycoon 3 was getting a bit "long in the tooth" and I was hoping for an upgrade.

Transport Fever 2 is  pretty; prettier even than Transport Fever 1.  In the main screen both are far superior to Railroad Tycoon 3  in terms of prettiness but there are some functional aspects that Railroad Tycoon 3 still does better. 

Transport Fever 2 uses signals which were not a feature in Railroad Tycoon 3 and they are an improvement. Unfortunately water towers and fueling (maintenance) sheds are absent from Transport Fever and would make for a more interesting game. Growing up in a railroad town spoiled me but I'd also expect a turntable.

Transport Fever & Transport Fever 2 requires returning empty freight cars for re-use (although they seem outrageously priced). I criticized Train Fever when coal hoppers and iron hoppers weren't interchangeable and for the most part that sort of issue is fixed in Transport Fever and Transport Fever 2

Railroad Tycoon 3 had a robust economic simulation game with 30+ commodities in 1, 2, and 3 deep production chains. Transport Fever & Transport Fever 2  has maybe a dozen commodities. and they've limited TF 2 to requiring only two commodities in each city. It would have seemed more realistic (and NOT all that tough to program) for all basic commodities to be required by all cities and for growing towns to require more advanced commodities. They also missed the chance to just allow for a falling rate of return on transporting "glutted commodities." 

Railroad Tycoon 3 had the ability to buy stock in your company and learn about the benefits (and dangers) of margin buying - an opportunity completely missed  in Train Fever & Train Fevers 1&2.

Transport Fever 2 (as of the last update) is finally getting the cost of laying, bulldozing and re-laying track right. 

Railroad Tycoon 3 had 66 Historical Locomotives rather than the 45 offered in Train Fever. But with Modders able to create and share these things in the workshop that's not really an issue anymore.

Railroad Tycoon 3 had debt (by issuing 500,000 in bonds) that changed as to rates making refinancing something that needed to be contemplated. Transport Fever and Transport Fever 2 are more simplistic with NO bond market and the ability to borrow from the bank (at a fixed 1%)  They DID fix Transport Fever 2 to charge interest monthly rather than only once a year; a bug/exploit which allowed for folks to borrow funds and then repay them to avoid a year's interest. 

Railroad Tycoon 3 had AI Competitors that sometimes required that you buy them out in certain scenarios. There are NO AI competitors in Transport Fever. [b]Making this a multi-player game would certainly solve that. [/b]

Railroad Tycoon 3 had AI Competitors based on real world people who played roles in the development of the Railroads. You got a bit of history with your gaming. That's missing here. 

Railroad Tycoon 3 had economic cycles that affect supply and demand. Nothing like it exists in Train Fever 2.

Railroad Tycoon 3 had 20+ MANDATORY scenarios that really encouraged you to explore the intricacies of the game . Transport Fever & Transport Fever 2 have OPTIONAL Campaigns that sort of serve this function or you can elect to play in  sandbox mode.

Railroad Tycoon 3 had overview maps that made spotting industries and resources (and the demand for them) much clearer than anything offered in the "Fever" games. In fact it's pretty much impossible to zoom "all the way out" on any large (or bigger maps)  There's also no mini-map to aid in navigation. 

Railroad Tycoon 3 had well laid out Train lists that show at-a-glance status information that you cannot see as easily in the "TF" games. The Transport Fever Vehicles list HAS gotten much better than it was in the original Train fever game and keeps getting better so I'm hopeful. 

Transport Fever & Transport Fever 2 is a great game. I just wish that the developers paid more attention to what had gone before and incorporated some of the "things that worked" into their game design. Every time I play I'm reminded that it could have been so much MORE than it is. 

[h1]Checklist of original complaints[/h1]

When I reviewed the Original Train fever I posted a list of things that they could have done that would have gotten them a better review. Here's an update on that list:

1) Track laying - Same day undo - allow any track laid to be demolished (on the same day) at no cost. This would somewhat make up for the lack of a real in-game track planning mode. Done! 

2) Enable ESC as a means of bringing up the main loading menu. The current method wastes time and screen real estate. 
Done! 

3) Make it easier to reload a saved game. I'm not sure whether this has been fixed in Transport fever but it required actually quitting and restarting the the game in Train Fever. Done! 

4) Options should also be available via the escape menu. If one wishes to turn off the game sounds or something similar one has to quit Train Fever. Why was music the only one that can be silenced in-game? 
Done! 

5) If you're going to do windows DO WINDOWS. Windows should be resizeable. Scrollable left and right as well as up and down. Cut and paste renaming should be enabled as well. Allowing for longer names would be good too. Default names suggested based on terminals would be great. 
Partly done - Most windows are now resizeable & scrollable (Though not left & right) Things ARE renameable but no cut & paste

6) Put a confirm on save game deletes. It was far too easy in Train Fever to delete the latest save game if one generally deletes a few saved games at start up time. 
Done

7) As with any simulator with economic aspects, graphs would be nice. Or even improved statistics on trains. 5 and 10 year running averages of revenue expenses profits, passengers. The graphs are now there but no multi-year running averages and there is PLENTY of room for improvement in what is graphed. 

8) Signals are important in this game. They should be easier to see whether zoomed in or out. 
That's still problematic and holds true for pretty much ALL icons. None are scaleable though they can be turned on or off. 

9) The Manage lines window should be sortable on Time, et. al. 
Done!

10) Station list should be sortable on cargo 
Done, sorta.

11) A button for next on line or next should be available in the vehicle details window 
Still not done

12) The Mouse zoom feature should be more granular (more interim steps) 
Done!

14) A Trainopedia feature would be great. 
Done! 

15) Towns list should show Goods needs supply and a few more details that are now only viewable in the city windows 
Still not done

16) Commodities should be easier to see on a fully zoomed out map. 
Still an issue

17) If this game were look more like Railroad Tycoon III as to GUI features, it would be great. The GUI is getting better.

[h1]Wishlist for Transport Fever 3 (or any update really)[/h1]
1) Change the word Supply in Town Screens to Demand
2) Change the word Transport to Delivered in the Industry details window
3) Start New Freeplay games on Pause. - One needs to study a map before doing any building. Every time I start a new game I remember this only after noticing.
4) Change the Display of Income to NOT include Investments - Use the term Net Cash Flow for the total with Investments subtracted.
5) Allow some customization in "Ride along" view and/or add Date Cargo Profits for this vehicle
6) Coal, Iron, Fuel, Bread icons all look too similar to other icons. They should be rethought and/or allow user to choose size of icons
7) Remove the cost of maintaining waypoint markers they are often used to correct AI pathing "errors." 
Many more but no more room

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
9/10

I originally wasn't super impressed with this game. It has a bit of a learning curve if you have played other management games but not TF. I'll probably write more as I get more time in. Overall, it's a lot of fun. Naturally, trains are my favorite part. Setting up a big system of raw products, refined products, and final delivery to consumers and watch it all start to work is a lot of fun. The trains can bit a bit of a learning curve. I came from Factorio, and I'm used to my strategy of one way trains only. This game doesn't have that option. I mean, you could, but it's not really set up to be like that. So getting used to having one way in and out stations connected to a main train takes a little practice, but once you get the basics down of how to signal to control the trains, it's super fun. Basically what I do is I normally run 2 land tracks everywhere with signals every so often so the trains can run closer together (signals form a block that a train will not enter if there is already another train in there). I'll typically connect inline stations to these, ensuring there is always a bypass option for trains not stopping there. Before and after every station or terminus I do a crisscross system so that every platform has access to both directions of the track. Signal the entry from the main track to splitter. The trains are smart enough to know if they can get to their platform even if there is another train on a different one within your signal area. So you get a lot of cool automatic action with very simple signal work. Definitely worth a shot.

I really tried to figure it out and it seems that there are no mods to change the background color, and it seems impossible without recompiling.
I urge the developers: please please please, think about us with color blindness / eye sensitivity / not perfect screen and allow mods for layer background color or an option to disable it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
They messed it up! 

1: in nr 1 it was possible to choose the specific cargo in wagons, now it is auto - which means sometimes trains decide to drag resources from a factory back to a supplier for some reason.

2: whenever you are configuring the modular stations, the game lags like crazy and if you started in 1850 on a big map, you have to change each friggin' component of each friggin' passenger station to more modern versions... while the game is lagging! 
I had a 16 track station, which by the way to make, you have to basically rebuild the entire station... Because the devs made the basic stations off center by 1 tile, which means if you just go from a max 8track station or whatever station, and  try and make a max size, you will end up with 2 tracks on the sides where 1 has no platform. So if you are planning on making a max station, build a 1 track 80m one, and just start from scratch by finding a corner of the area.... 
took me 1hr just to build a station for 16 tracks in 1850... then it became 1980 and the fancy modern stations became available...

Nope! I quit! I am not spending an hour upgrading 1 station, only to know I have 16 more to go...

braindead devs... braindead!

++TL:DR Very good Succesor from the Predecessor with smart new Features and Ways to solve Problems, also the changed Balance "2Goods for one Town not all for all". Also the Animation and the Love for little Details are impressive. The new Towns rock and its great Fun building your own little World and improving on your 1850 Railways. // They fixed the Performance and it seems that its now worth to recommend. Currently i recommend everyone that wants to play this Game, to wait. Without any Performance Patches its never gonna be Fun at all. Making it just frustrating and depressing building a huge Station just to get crashed before a Autosave.

no english native

AMD R9 390,i5-4460,8gb ram,dual monitor setup, every single current Game runs without any Problem whatsoever and Drivers are up to Date.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I love the game. It;s fun, with bright graphics and a real opportunity to be challenged. TF was on my wish list for years and small side projects like law school kept me from anything but adding games to the wish list every few months. TF was joined by TF2.

When I finally had some time, I skipped TF and picked up TF2. In a short amount of time I have:

Finished the campaigns
What was interesting quickly became a bit mundane. then my own goal to pause, pre-plan every thing, then hit start time. It was interesting to watch missions pop up and close very quickly. But that's done and isn't a repeatably part of the game.

Off to Free play
Plain vanilla, to start on the STEAM Achievements. In a few hours of play, over 50% are earned. A few others I could snag by cheesie play with lame stunts to buy, change time, and race to complete them. Not earned in my book, but hey, you do you sunshine.

CTD
And this is why the review is not a good one.
On a top of the line PC less then a month old, plain vanilla, no mods, basic campaign and basic free play maps, CTD's are a normal occurrence. Autosave is your friend, and also a contributor to some CTD's.

Dev's pushed on an update, and yet CTD's still happen.
This isn't some indie project in a basement with the entire family finances on the line.
This is a major sequel to a major game.

And it crashes like I wrote it.

How much worse is it going to get before it gets better?

Mods and Workshop
They look awesome, but since I'm still in Achievement progression, I haven't used any.
Add the CTD's and I would have to look for passive content like a vehicle skin type mods only.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game [/quote]

A second new fever is in the works, it's called Transport Fever 2!

Not really... 

Transport Fever 2 is a sequel to the first game developed by Urban Games and published by Good Shepherd Entertainment and it's mostly like the classic Transport Tycoon Deluxe and OpenTTD, only... it's not as good

Transport Fever 2 is a fun game to play, although I don't know why they just called it Transport Fever 2 as you can also add buses and trams but anyway, however, the game is very clunky and sometimes annoying.

Another thing which bugged me was the level of difficulty. The game is not easy and you would end up bankrupt immediately if not selective. Of course I understand that the game has to have some challenge but you can fail instantly if you muck up something

When placing the train tracks especially, the game's framerate chugs like hell, so much so, I have to stop and wait for the game to regain the framerates to make it even playable. Also, the game freezed for a couple of seconds to autosave which can be annoying

However, the game does have a fantastic level amount of detail. From the trains, to the house, people and cars and landscape, this also includes the sound effects, especially the train sound effects. The music on the other hand, isn't that great

Transport Fever 2 is a mixed bag when it comes to purchasing, I am in the middle when it comes to recommending it or not. I highly suggest that for this game you check out some reviews and gameplay videos before considering purchasing, but overall, Transport Fever 2 isn't that bad!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

[b] REVIEW SOURCES: [/b]
[list]
[*] None

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A very fun game, but lacks polish in several places: most notably spelling errors and hard to understand tutorials/introductory campaign levels that don't adequately explain the game mechanics. I've also had a few issues with crashes, but the autosaves have kept me from losing much progress. Definitely worth picking up if you enjoy transport games, but could use some more updates and bug fixes

Edit: After playing the game further, I'm still having a lot of fun, and the recent patch added some much needed QoL features; however, it still lacks many things one would expect. (Parallel road placement and auto-replace are the first things that come to mind).  The game also gets very laggy when you have a lot of water and water routes on the map. Any action which affects navigable waterways takes several seconds to calculate. It's so bad, I am abandoning one of my island saves because of it.
