title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Definite recommend. Another great addition to the transport tycoon cadre of games. Graphics are really good for this kind of game. All four modes of transport have their own usefulness and are all very pleasing to the eye, especially with the cockpit camera feature. The streamlined industry system is a big improvement in clarity, although it probably lowered the difficulty of the game. AI traffic is a bit finicky but can be meticulously fixed and customized ala Cities: Skylines. The modding community is extremely active and the developers are updating the game diligently. From my experience with TF1, expect dev support for at least the next few years - and the game will only get better from there.

Do note that this is a very resource-intensive game (much like Cities and TF1), especially when using modded Megalomaniac-sized maps. Although the devs will work on optimization, there definitely is a floor to how good your processor and GPU have to be to play on anything bigger than Medium size or modded maps.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game features a campaign that covers the history of trains and transport. One of the campaign missions features the construction of the Trans-Siberian Railroad, an incredible engineering feat of its time. You, the player, are tasked with building a series of smaller, non-notable rail lines to supply the construction of the actual Trans-Siberian Railroad, which the game ultimately builds automatically at a set point in the mission. In a game that's all about building railroads, you don't actually get to build one of the most ambitious and impressive railroads in history.

Besides that, it's fun enough. 6/10

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Have played all previous games, Train Fever to Transport Fever, i give this a thumbs down solely because of the instability of the game. The game crashes randomly at random moments, while clicking on objects, creating a line, buying trucks etc. Save Game loading is more a lottery at the moment than anything consistent, meaning save games are not corrupted, but still only load until 60% finished and then just ctd without any notice. This applies to vanilla as to a modded game. I also read that AMD users experience problems. Again complete Bullsh*t for all AMD users. When the game gets fixed and stabilized, i will propably edit my review, until then, if you can bare with inconsistency, buy it, if not wait it out. I have 38h now and will stop because it is to frustrating to play a game from 1850 to 2020 and cant load the game anymore when it was last saved without any chance of the options or anything. My system is more than Capable to run the game, Ryzen5 1600 CPU AMD RTX580 8GB and 32GB RIPJAWS RAM. The future will show how the game evolvs and it has the potential to be a great game, big part being the modding community.

EDIT 08.03.2020
As stated, i revise my review. Figured out that the instability was a mix between the game and my system, and fixing all related issues, i am now willing to give this game a thumbs up and a recommendation. It wont be 100% stable in a modded state, but it is far away from the previous instability.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a great game, but still has issues. 

They removed the auto-replace line feature, which can be fixed with changing maintenance, but I don't like that change.

Also, there are still some crashes and bugs. The dev team is pushing out a lot of updates though, so I changed my review to positive.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Really enjoying the game so far. Game has been really stable for me until the update on March 6th. It's nice to see a new terrain/area to play as well as the models from both Train Fever and Transport Fever returning with upgraded textures. The new industries and delivery mechanic is interesting and I'm getting to like it plus it is great that we can now transport raw materials as well as finished products by aircraft. The new models introduced in to this incarnation are really nice. I would have liked to have a few things in the base game firstly, more British designs in the base game, more Diesel Multiple units then just the single car and British style stations to be an option in the base game when it comes to configuring stations. Apart from the issues with the March 6th update I've had no issues with the game and would recommend you pick up this game if you enjoyed the first Transport Fever game

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
english/deutsch

this game is great. problem is: most of the side missions are plain stupid or wtf? the game would be better without them! for a completionist like me, a nightmare.
second, there are a lot uf useful functions hidden within the game, for example the ability to tell your vehicle exactly how long to wait for how much cargo. this would be usefull early on, instead having your trains and trucks aimlessly driving around the landscape and waisting valuable time. 
all you have to keep in mind is: the game will automatically deliver all necesary goods to where they are needed - as long as your routes (can be from trucks to train to trucks again) are closed and your vehicles are cabeable of transporing them - keep this in mind, because if something doesn't seem to work, it's almost always one of those points ;-) trust me with this!

Dieses Spiel ist eigentlich toll. Die Nebenmissionen können einem jedoch echt den Nerv ziehen und laufen auf "Trial and Error" hinaus, weil selten klar ist, was eigentlich zu tun ist - oder sie sind einfach banal. Das Spiel wäre besser ohne sie! Auch werden einem viele nützliche Funktionen, speziell zur exakten Tour- und Zeitplanung  eurer Routen, welche einem das Leben schon im ersten Kapitel erleichtern könnten, nie wirklich erklärt - oder vom ersten Teil vorausgesetzt!? 
Alles was ihr wissen müsst, um den größten Stolperstein im Spiel zu vermeiden: das Spiel wird alles was irgendwo verfügbar ist und irgendwo anders gebraucht wird automatisch auch dorthin bringen - SOLANGE ihr einen geschlossenen Transportweg dorthin habt (kann z.B. LKW-Zug-LKW sein) UND(!) eure Fahrzeuge auch in der Lage sind, besagte Güter auch zu transportieren. Ihr könnt mir vertrauen: falls eure Güter nicht transportiert werden, solltet ihr ganz genau diese Punkte checken! In 90% der Fälle ist das Problem dadurch gelöst ;-)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I came from Cities Skylines which is a truly amazing city builder. However, as my cities got larger, and my transportation networks satisfyingly grew, I was starting to get a little tired of (zoning, add fire, police, school, medical, garbage, mortuary, power, water) just to keep the fun part (transportation) growing. 

When I first tried Transport Fever 2, I went for the campaign as I felt it would be a good place to learn the game as the campaign has a built in tutorial. However, starting off in the 1850's and using really small maps, I was underwhelmed and was ready to give up on the game. 

I decided to give it one more try using one of the randomly generated maps. That's when I realized the maps can get REALLY LARGE! I love the challenge of figuring out logical and profitable ways to connect cities and cargo and watch the cities grow without having to constantly provide all the services in Skylines. 

Finally, after establishing some train networks, my favorite part is going along for the long train rides.

If you crave just building transport networks rather than constantly providing city services this game is for you.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Was so excited to get this.  Used to play Transport Tycoon, and believed this would be a modern version of it.  THIS SUCKS!!!  Interface is EXTREMELY non-intuitive and sloppy to work with.
Unfortunately, I left the game on "pause" yesterday while going out for dinner with my wife.  Thus, upon returning, even though I had only played about 40 minutes, the game showed I had played several hours.  This morning, upon actually spending time with it, I discovered the MASSIVE FLAW!!!  It does not allow you to easily auto-upgrade trains.  In fact, if you replace a locomotive, you QUITE LITERALLY suddenly LOOSE the entire rest of the train - all carriages!!!  

Searched forums and helpfiles to no avail.  This is how it works.  Now I am so bummed I left it on pause, because now I cannot refund to steam.

IF YOU PLAYED TRANSPORT TYCOON IN THE PAST, AND THOUGHT THIS IS A GREAT NEW MODERN GAME THAT IS LIKE, AND BETTER - DO NOT BUY!  IT IS NOT.  IT IS NOT EVEN CLOSE TO THE DECADES OLD TT.

review:
I didn't play TF 1, but I'm an experienced tycoon player with strong sentiment towards Transport Tycoon. Transport Fever isn't a bad game, but I was expecting it to be more engaging. After 30 hours the game didn't have much more to offer I'm afraid. If you have very (VERY) little time to play or you are new/casual tycoon gamer - you should be fine and it should keep you entertained for quite some time. My mistake was to buy it before Christmas, so I had waaay to much time to spend on it.
From technical perspective - the game runs absolutely fine on mid settings on a 4 year old laptop without any issues (even at the later stages). Graphics are nice, UI is really friendly.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I cannot recommend the game even after I have spent a few hours in it.
You play on a completely isolated map with no interaction or anything. There is nothing to react to. The hard mode is an absolute joke. Game mechanics are extremely easy to exploit. So it is possible to get the 300 km/h archives by simply bringing the train to 200 km/h as quickly as possible with 6 locomotives and then simply editing them out while driving lol. Depots absolutely useless. You only need one to buy trains. The trains never have to go to this depot again. There are no complex signals. In a game with trains. It would be nice if trains in a game with trains would behave like trains, too.
Funny is cargo that will be teleported around but passengers don't. 
The game is supposed to be an economic or management simulator, but is actually an interactive paint with very little content. Relying on the modding community here is more than lazy and no explanation for that little poorly optimized inconsistent content.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
There is not much I can say negative about this game, if you like empire-building, strategy, economy, etc. games, do not hesitate to get this. I just got it the other day and man I have a hard time going to bed at night. I try to stop playing around midnight but I always end up going to bed an hour or two later! I've already put over 30 hours into it just within the past few days. 

Pros: 
   - Easy UI
   - Big maps
   - Very customizable
   - Great graphics and camera movements
   - Choose between campaign or sandbox mode
   - Balanced economy (Income/Expenditures)
   - Great modding community
   - Track-laying is intuitive and simple
   - The Cities grow as you supply them! 
   - There is always something to do or improve 
   - I love making millions of $

Cons
   - Airports are not very customizable (Maybe I didn't get far enough yet), but I wish I could edit the runway length, add another runway/taxiways, etc. 
   - The in-game music is sh$t, I usually just turn it off and play my own background music
   - Airplanes approaching need a little more realistic landing approach, ex: there are trees at the beginning of the runway they can fly through them. Runway hazards are the a big topic in aviation, so airplanes in this game need to take into consideration any obstacles like trees, buildings, etc. when landing and fly over them, making their landing distance longer. The player needs to recognize these dangers and remove tress, or extend runway length. 
   - Adding to the approach, airplanes shouldn't be landing halfway down the runway, they land near the beginning of the runway, especially on shorter runways like in this game. 
   - The cars travelling on multi-lane highways don't have very smart AI when it comes to switching lanes, they will stay stuck behind slower vehicles and create a huge lines even though the other lanes are wide open. Switching lanes shouldn't take driving around the block. Vehicles should move a little more freely around the roads, maybe even throw in some drunk drivers and emergency vehicles. The world ain't perfect. 

In conclusion, absolutely an amazing game, if you like these types of games you will love this one! 
Now back to putting in countless more hours into TF2!

review:
So this game is a game I would recommend as an extremely casual game.

Cons:
I have spent most of my time playing freeplay so I cannot say how difficult the campaign is, but I can tell you that freeplay is not difficult whatsoever. I have been playing on hard and only using trains and its been really easy. All you have to do is set up a line and make sure its profitable and anytime you are low on money you just go afk for however long youd like till you have enough money to keep progressing.

I dont know how it is for anyone else, but my game crashes randomly and frequently so I have it autosave every 5 minutes.

Pros:
The game looks really good, gameplay is like having a model city set. Its enjoyable to set everything up and then just watch everything do their jobs. For me this is a huge part of why I like the game and personally cannot see anyone that doesn't enjoy this aspect of the game being interested in the rest of it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game is beautiful to look at even on the lowest graphics settings, but as a transport/city building game it is both frustrating and wonderful. 

Frustrating because it challenges you to figure out just what it was that you just did wrong (be it a broken line, catenaries that look like crap because you did not make your four track switches correctly or you failed to make sure the ends of your tunnels were lined up correctly. (Get into the game and you will know what I am talking about).

Wonderful because you can decide what you want to do to make an exciting network moving people and products around with too many mod options already to make your network look as gorgeous as you want to.

I can't put this game down.

There are railroad modelers who would have to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to come anywhere near the shear joy of this game.

Highly recommend!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
My first foray into business simulation games started with Transport Tycoon. I fell in love with it as a child, and I've been addicted to this genre of games ever since. I occasionally play the rewritten implementation of it - OpenTTD - to this day. When I saw there was finally a game studio that wanted to take on the challenge of making a transport focused business simulation game I was very excited. I couldn't wait for it to be released.

I felt the same about this game when it was announced. I pre-ordered it thinking there would be no way I wouldn't like it. And technically, I do like it. I could forgive the shortcomings the original Transport Fever had, given that it was the studio's first game that included all types of transport. There was nothing else like it for me to compare it against, other than maybe the (at the time?) shallow transportation mechanics in Cities:Skylines. When I first launched this game it felt very familiar, maybe too familiar.

I jumped into the campaign with no expectations, and I'm sad to say that I came out disappointed. I didn't play past the second mission of the second campaign; it wasn't engaging, and the pretentious narrator had me pulling my hair out. With all due respect, narrator, but I know that 50 metres of track I just laid is not exceptional in any way regardless of what you tell me. 

During the campaign, you're constantly being held by your hand and the game tells you what you can and cannot do; for instance, you may not build a train that is longer than what is required by the mission, and any shorter will not complete it. You may not extend an existing station which would allow you to build a train that could complete the mission in 1 trip, you have to do it in 2 trips. The game is not rewarding you for exploiting the game's mechanics or for being clever. Besides that, some of the missions are incredibly vague which left me clicking and zooming around just to see if I had missed something.

After that wild ride, I jumped into a free game; the meat and potatoes of the game. I played with the European set and a tempered landscape, and later I tried a game with the Asian set on a tropical island. The tropical island didn't offer anything different from the tempered landscape, so in the end I didn't even bother with it.

Apart from the UI, it's apparent that a lot of the game's content had been copied from Transport Fever. The engines are mostly the same, the cars are mostly the same, the tracks are the same, the roads are mostly the same, the way you lay tracks and roads is the same (albeit with less "slope too steep" warnings), the way operating costs are calculated; you guessed it, the same. I'm particularly irked by the fact that they did basically nothing to improve roads. Not even the rule sets were changed. Highways still have sidewalks (why... why...?). Still no way to put highways parallel to each other without mods. The game does look better, but in terms of features, assets (ignoring the details) and the tools that you use, it's basically the same.

The economy isn't very interesting. I don't remember what it was like in the original game, but it seems like there is no reward for delivering goods or passengers faster, so it usually boils down to buying the cheapest and slowest engines and cars you can find (because of how the operating costs are calculated). They could have added cool features like random events where your company gets a subsidy for using a certain engine or certain route. Factory growth is artificially limited rather than being limited from not being able to physically grow, for example. Let the demand or lack of resources be the reason why a factory can't grow any further. There's so many things that spring to mind when thinking about what they could have done with the economy.

Ohh the UI. I've made a whole forum post detailing what I would change to make it less cumbersome to use. Too many tabs; too many duplicate information windows; too large; not obvious what even is and what isn't a window; weird and confusing button placement; you have to click around so much to get things done; still making use of useless bar charts.. the list goes on. It's usable, but it's annoying to use. I do believe they added a way to build prebuilt structures though, so that's nice.

Performance is better than the original game. I still drop to 30 fps or lower when zooming into cities, and from what I can tell the cities are smaller (or at least harder to grow) than in the original game, but they (and the lands around them) look nicer; you win some, you lose some. I do get the occasional crash when I zoom into a city or try to upgrade something attached to one.

Sound design is nothing special, it doesn't stand out as good or bad. Except for maybe, the diesel trains which are pretty good and the airplanes also sound cool.

There are still new things to be discovered and things to like: I do believe the developers said they added more detail to things. There's some new road vehicles. There's new aircraft. There's new vehicles from the new Asian set. A very nice addition compared to the old game are the modular stations. They feel fleshed out and they work intuitively, and they work for every transport type. I love the aircraft in this game, you can't help but smile when you see one take off. There's a bunch of animals around that you can click and even go first person on, which is cute. Some of the overlays are pretty useful. And in the end, there is mod support, which will make sure there will be more than enough content and tools that will make people's lives easier. 

To conclude, I feel like the developers didn't learn much about who buys their game and what their needs are. Maybe they did, but they couldn't work things out internally, or they figured the people who mod their games will sort out their problems. In any case, for returning players, I can't recommend this game unless you *really* want what are essentially quality of life improvements, some new vehicles (of which you probably had more already because of mods), and a more visually pleasing world. This is basically Transport Fever 1.5 rather than 2. For new players, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game, because those players won't know that this game could have been much more.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a great little strategy/builder/management game, with a lot of depth. 

It's surprisingly complex, and there are infinite ways to proceed. The graphics are great, and it's a lot of fun to just zoom in and watch things develop through the years. Watching my little towns become big cities, with a slow progression in the types of vehicles on the road and the options available to me is really interesting and fun. Riding along on my very first cruddy little airplane was great. I love the boats, too. Actually, I love most things in the game.

My only criticism is with the UI, which can be a bit odd to figure out at the beginning. It also needs a bit of streamlining here and there. 

I'd like to see a bit better (and longer time-wise) spreadsheets and charts of your progress, too. 

But overall, this is a fantastic game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: TpF2 is just...rough, and non-intuitive. For a game which requires working with large numbers of objects, most of the operations on the objects seem geared to working on single objects. Laying track and placing signals is awkward and tedious. Placing stations in proximity to industries is awkward. Oftentimes, basic information is buried deep in dialogs if available at all. Lots of graphics artifacting on both AMD and Nvidia hardware. Extremely slow-loading, even on fast SSD's. Finally, there are no tools for helping one determine why a given flow of material isn't working. This all combines to make for a less than pleasurable gaming experience; it just isn't smooth.  Your mileage may vary, but on the basis of the above, I don't recommend it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you enjoyed the original Transport Tycoon and OPENTTD, this is for you, and I don't say that lightly. Many games have tried to live up to OPENTTD in the last 20+ years and all of them have failed for one reason or another. Even this game's predecessor had serious problems that stopped it being the new standard - excessive difficulty, a clunky interface and a vague and confusing economy system that didn't give you enough information to make decisions. But those are fixed here, and as such if you like moving stuff around a sandboxy map and making money, this is finally the game you've been waiting for. The difficulty settings are flexible enough that you can use it as everything from a tough business sim to just a giant model trainset with pretty graphics and nice sound. The interface is much improved since the first game (although it's still not perfect, especially when you have a lot of lines to manage), but improving the interface seems to be a priority from the devs in recent updates and a lot of the initial confusing/weird things have been fixed.

I am the first to admit that whilst I love this game to death it's very niche and not for everyone. There are some downsides that mean it might not be your taste. No multiplayer or AI opponents, some people have reported optimisation/performance problems (I only get issues on the experimental map sizes, especially after the last patch but ymmv), a lot of TPF1 diehards don't like the simplification of the economy system, the vanilla selection of vehicles is a bit odd/limited (in the Europe setting you get a locomotive that can go 90mph in about 1930 but you only get coaches that can go 90mph in 1981!), but this and some of the other problems have been fixed by mods. I didn't like the campaign missions or the music, but that's not what I (or I suspect most people) play these kinds of games for anyway.

Overall this is a fantastic time sink for people who want a Transport Tycoon experience with modern graphics and quality of life improvements.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It's a rehash of TF1 with uninteresting and poorly thought-through scenarios that require literally nothing aside from setting up a line, setting it to speed 3, and waiting. I kept waiting for the tutorial to end. Chapter II is, I guess, where they are trying to "challenge" you, but I would have had just as much fun watching a playthrough on youtube, at least then I could skip to the end.

And aside from the scenarios, there is no point in playing TF2 over TF1. The few UI changes are not all good, especially the idea that you manage the same line through two different windows, which is such an elementary level of design screwup that I am confused how this is a company that makes games.

As an added bonus, the early scenarios are kind of insane: play as a Dutch governor of a Caribbean island, an American government-issued dominator of the West and enjoy the narrator explaining to you how the natives are too stupid to understand work, or play through another scenario where you are implementing a "socialist experiment" until the end where the game tells you "oops! haha! socialism never works!" and you literally have to bulldoze all of your tracks and buildings as a lesson. I think they thought this would be a funny twist but why the fuck would I be playing a building game if I wanted to bulldoze everything? Besides the kindergarten level politics I was just mad about deleting my work. This is an idiot's sequel.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Having played nearly all of the campaign and some free play (48hrs played so far) I have to say I was hoping for more of an improvement over the original Transport Fever. The graphics are a big improvement but, that is to be expected with a new release. Station configurations are nice but, don't add a lot to the game overall. Having the ability to fully alter the terrain is also great when needed but, this is something that should have been included anyways in the original game in my opinion. The campaign has more missions with multiple objectives but, some objectives are not clearly defined and many simply require you to click on the map somewhere. Ultimately, playing a game is about having fun. I had just as much fun, if not more, playing the original Transport Fever game than Transport Fever 2. Unfortunately, I don't feel that much enjoyment playing this game over and above the original. Because of this I cannot recommend other people purchase this game based on my experience right now. Which is a shame because I love the developer's concepts and the original game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A really great game for transportation simulation players.

+ Separation of industrial and public transport
+ Steam Workshop integration is seamless
+ Modularity approach for station design is really useful
+ Modularity approach of railroads makes laying track a lot more flexible
+ Campaign mode is lengthy (~50 hours) and based on real historical events
+ Free mode allows you to play procedurally generated worlds, technically unlimited maps to play with
+ Different means of transportation with its unique pros and cons
+ Separation of regular trains and high-speed trains
+ Three different types of regions (USA, Europe and Europe) with different terrain characteristics
+ Different models of real train based on the type of region
+ Models of different vehicles will change its look as it deteriorates

- Poor optimization, not utilizing all the CPU cores
- Very few vehicles to buy after the present time (so far I have only unlocked one)
- In the campaign mode, you need to manually save each map to save its progress. 
--> Explanation: Each save you made in the campaign mode only saves the progress of the map you are playing now. If you forget to manually save a map and move onto another map, you will lose all the progress of the unsaved maps. My original intuition is one save will save the progress of all the maps of the campaign mode so I just save all my progress in one save. Now I need to start from scratch to earn all the medals for each map.
- Some people complain that the game is too easy, although I think it is reasonable
- Minor rant: You can only lay down one track at a time and it is kind of annoying to build 2 railroads for each direction

Overall, I think the price (HK$188, ~24.22USD) is reasonable and I can guarantee that you will have a great time managing your transportation empire in both the campaign mode and free mode.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I must say that i am not liking the direction they have taken with the game.  The limitation of goods to cities of only 2 per, feels clunky, unrealistic and unpleasant. I had hoped for a larger diversity of goods for each city so you could build more intricate networks of delivery, but now, the only thing one has to think about is getting the 2nd factory up, for each of the goods, for a city when it has grown over 900 population. 
I am also not liking the "maintenance" system that is in place for vehicles.  I personally am not liking the idea of making things more expensive to run, but be able to run them till the end of times. If it was only an increase in lifetime, sure, bring it on, but as it stands, it's not my cup of tea.
Should have a change to "Lorry Fever 2" since a lot of the time and especially on higher difficulty starting with an intricate network of trains and even a simple one will not work, the maintenance fees for buildings and tracks will run you into the ground.

All in all, they have messed a bit too much with the TF1 recipe trying to go for a new game feel and they kind of messed it up in my opinion. I would have liked better a TF1 with more vehicles and better functionality, than this.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game in his current state at day one release is definitely a disappointment if you are an old fan of the serie. However, with mods and a bit of refinement by the Devs, I'm confident enough that it will improve over time.

You would expect that the Devs would have known better at this point, after two other games of the same kind (but this is more the same game that has got improvements than a completely new one), but no, they managed not only to bring over into this several flaws and missing features  that already afflicted the previous two games, like the lacking of a proper planning tool to build the tracks (that almost all the other similar games have), but they also were able to worsen the UI and the economy, and to suppress some of the features that already were in TPF 1.

However, the MAP EDITOR is great and almost makes up for all the flaws.

______________________________________________________

CONS 1:
 (flaws that were already in the previous games)
______________________________________________________

- a proper tracks planning tool is still missing, so that building tracks is still made by "trial and error", and can be very frustrating.

- a game minimap is still missing too, despite players requesting it for years (since the previous games of the serie) and despite being a very useful feature and quite easy to implement. The most frustrating thing is that you can't even zoom out enough to see the whole map in game, so really there is actually no way to see the whole map that you are playing.

- there isn't any official game manual, not even in digital form. I guess that newcomers will have to rely on players guides when they will come out.

- the ships and planes economy seems to be the same of the previous game, that was really not focused on them, but more on trains and trucks. So you'll have an hard time to make any profit with them, ships particularly.

______________________________________________________

CONS 2:
(missin or flawed features that were present or were better implemented in TPF1)
______________________________________________________

- the game is incredibly more easy than TPF1 was, even at hard level, because they removed the raising maintenance costs for old vehicles, halved the loan interests, and also dumbed down the freight economy, so that now it's not required anymore to complete a production chain before the cargo becomes available,and  you can simply tranport cargo from an idnustry to another and earn a lot of money. My suspicion is that they wanted to appeal more to casual players, but veteran players are not happy with the current lack of challenge.

-  you can't use anymore drag&drop to change train compositions in a depot. It's still possible to change train consists, but it's clunkier, less intuitive and more time consuming than it was in TPF1.

- the very useful curved, sloped and underground stations are now missing

- The new UI is clunky, cumbersome and confusing. It's true that I'm still new to it, and you need a bit of time to adapt to the changes, but if all the vehicles micromanagement needs a lot more clicking than it did in the previous game, and it's exactly the case here, this is a big red flag for me. 

- The economy also seems definitely off. Dumbed down products chains and raised difficulty by making tracks maintenance cost a lot more only makes for an unfunny cocktail if you love to build freight train lines.

-Vehicular traffic is already insane in 1850 and can't be changed in options (however it can be changed if you mess around with config files).

-The new maintenance system is bad. It has been designed poorly and implemented even worse. They removed the useful and realistic increase of the maintenance costs for old vehicles, that made sense and worked, especially with the useful vehicles autoreplacement option. But what they introduced is a new system where you can raise the maintenance level to very high and the vehicles will become brand new again after some months (it will cost you so much that almost all routes won't remain profitable during the time that you set this maintenance increase). What a pity that this system doesn't work at all. 1) The vehicles become as new again but their value is near zero, so you can't sell them. 2) You can still replace them instead of raising their maintenance, but it's a nightmare if you have a big fleet, because they removed the automatic replacement option, and they also removed the "memory" of the last vehicle/train that you have built, so you have to redo it again every time for every single line. But the most weird thing is that the only consequence for not caring of old vehicles at all is that their emissions will increase a bit, slightly affecting the towns population. Basically, the new emissions dynamics is pretty broken too, so you can safely ignore both maintenance and emissions, and your vehicles will continue to make money, with the only caveat of some annoying popups that  from time to time will inform you about how old and crappy your vehicles are.  

-The campaign first 4 or 5 missions are boring and repetitive for expert players,they're more tutorials for new players than challenging missions. But even if the following missions then become more fun, they are ridded with bugs and generally they are extremely easy and not challenging.

-There are very few bridges to chose from and with very limited speeds, They removed all the old wooden and iron bridges from the game (they are now available again thanks to modders porting them from TPF1).
______________________________________________________

PROS:
______________________________________________________

- The visual aspect of the game is generally very pleasant and improved from the previous game.

- There are some new interesting vehicle models.

- Finally they separated the game time from the game date, great idea, so you can now set it to run as before, with the years passing by, or you can simply remain to play in a particular year and enjoy the vintage vehicles as long as you want, or a combination of both.

- They seem to have improved a lot the terraforming part, so you finally got rid of that annoying "collisions" messages that were constantly bothering you in the previous games.

- The game is more modder friendly than ever, so I expect it that it will improve a lot over time, when the mods will flock to workshop (however there are some core mechanics that can't be changed with mods, and the Devs will have to do it).

- To be fair, there is a really big improvement from TPF1, that makes up almost completely for all the missing features, and it's the map editor. It's really great, albeit not so user friendly. Also, the terrain editing tools in the editor could benefit from more radiius than the maximum one they have at the moment, that is frankly too small to edit fastly a big map.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: If you want to make your own transportation network with a wide choice of modes of transport, this is the game for you. The game is still quite new so of course a lot of issue would hopefully be fixed in the future, but here a couple that bother me the most. Stations by default are 320m long and can be expanded to 480m (I think) by using the station config tool. High speed trains constantly drop speed on long stretches for no reason. Horse carriages block traffic, and the cars don't change lanes to avoid congestion. Again, this game is still new so I'm hoping the issue will be fixed, but don't let this discourage you from getting this game. It is the most addicting and the most fun game ever to play. Here is an example, it's 2:00am and I just stopped playing.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Pros: 
- Worthy successor to TF1, maintaining all the pro's from TF1 + some extras, like:
- Islands/Asia is a good extension, new map creation tool is awesome
- Building tracks and roads is improved and the new station editor is probably one of the best new features
- Path-finding seems better too

Cons:
- Mega maps are very memory hungry
- Only 2 difficulty levels which just adjust cost (hard is not hard enough, just like TF1)
- Very limited number of stock vehicles, which forces you to go through the workshop and search and find

Couple of other changes, such as consumer and industry demands (1 of each per city), vehicle maintenance and replacement and some adjusted supply chains (fuel and food most notably). Still a few bugs here and there (just today I could just M a track on a steep hill upwards until it became a roller coaster.. lol - was only $980M).

Would've loved some extra features to configure wait times / headway better to fine-tune complex networks.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: This game has huge performance issues and is massively unbalanced as of now. Place a handful of cities and industries on a large map and it already lags to an extend that makes it unplayable before even having one line in operation. My system is decent enough to play titles like Red Dead Redemption 2, Cities Skylines with more than 5000 mods installed and similar games without any lagging so the problem cannot be on my end. I really hope there will be a patch to fix this, until then it's a big no no.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
3/5
A decent game ruined by frustrating to understand mechanics. If somethings not working in your supply chain, good luck finding out why. 

The bonus missions in the campaign are a complete waste of time in the current format. I'd recommend googling them instead of trying to work out what bizarre thing the developer is trying to make you do. The biggest gripe I have with these is that some of the bonus missions ARE helpful if you're trying to learn the game, whether it be by teaching you how to read the elevation height of your cursor or another semi-useful bit of knowledge not really required to play the game at a basic level. But the execution is so poorly done it makes you dread completing each an every one of them.

It's too easy to make money, you don't really ever have to worry about running out.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Update: 2/3/2020

[i]Well - It's been a while since the original review below was written. Been playing TF2 off and on since day 1 of release now. I just can't put my thumb on what's wrong but there's something very wrong and very different about TF2 from TF1. TF1 was/is fun to play. TF2 isn't fun at all. 30 minutes into a play session and I'm at a point where I'm throwing my hands up in the air and thinking to myself - well - that's 30 minutes I'll never get back.

Why isn't TF2 fun and TF1 was/is fun? Wish I knew but for me that's the case. Sad - TF has so much unrealized potential.[/i]

1. TF2 is essentially an upgrade not a whole new game. Some things like freight, for example, have changed some like it better than TF1 (like me) and some don't.
2. IMO the game was built on a premise that everyone has a very fast CPU because TF2 is CPU limited. Users with the latest and greatest and fastest GPU's available are seeing FPS numbers down in the dirt if they have CPU's older than for example an i7- six or seven thousand series.

If TF2 gets optimized graphically to a much greater extent (and it doesn't take a year like it did with TF1) and the devs figure out how to optimize the CPU load to take advantage of multiple cores (which it currently doesn't do very well - NOTE: the fanbois really freak out over this making excuses and being apologists for the TF devs) and that doesn't take a year I will come back and change this to a solid recommended.

I sincerely hope that the devs can eliminate or at least improve on the issues noted above.

Tip: Lay down the road framework for your city, then populate the city in the middle of it.  A deeper city builder than any I've played before.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I had hoped that this would be an improvement to the previous Transport Fever 1.  And in many ways it is.  It is prettier, more polished, etc.  But the minimum stated requirements are

MINIMUM:
Requires a 64-bit processor and operating system
OS: Windows 7, 8 or 10 (64-bit)
Processor: Intel i5-2300 or AMD FX-6300
Memory: 8 GB RAM
Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 560 or AMD Radeon HD 7850, 2 GB VRAM

My PC, though not the best meets these 
Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-6300HQ CPU @ 2.30GHz
Memory: 8192MB RAM
Card name: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960M    
Dedicated Memory: 2010 MB

Only just, but that should imply that you can run the game, though perhaps not to the endgame.  However that is not the case. Even with all graphics settings turned down to minimum, so you lose aall the added prettiness of the upgrade. The game still cannot load EVEN the smallest map, with the least amount of towns, industries or other assets, without MAXing out the GPU and the memory overheating the pc and the game runs like treacle.  So Zero option to actually play the game.

Strange, that the actual "tutorial" campaigns DO actually run acceptably. So that suggest that the Freeplay mode is in some manner bugged.

It is a shame that Urban Games could not have been more honest with the Minimum Requirements.  Clearly this game needs more.  GPU speed and memory, and RAM and also requires a decent sized SSD in order to be able to load at an acceptable speed. It also needs to be optimised considerably.

VERY Disappointing.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: A great game and if you have played TF1 basicly similar except the way the resources work is different but that you will learn quick. The major improvement is graphics at all levels even if you play at LOW so you laptop/pc copes. Great to see improvement on shipping and air transport both of which I use alot in TF1. The mods coming in cover up some holes there so you can use some of the short range aircraft on small airports too  which is what they were designed for (NOT ONLY large airports note devs ie Avrojet and  Bombadier Q8). We  could do with some really short haul aircraft like the Twin Otter and BN Islander  with 5 to 5 pass and my biggest gripe still no Civil Helecopters with Helepad!  Please work on that devs. As for Shipping wonderful except still no Ferries  cars ot trains can load onto.  This game is a long haul game so I play it over weeks at slowest speed as I love to see it grow. For New Players start with the simplest and cheapest  either a passenger route (1 train 4/5 coaches expand to another set if route goes well) on flat land between  3 towns with bus routes in those towns and wait or go the goods  route connect as a Farm to Food Production factory and then a  nearby town using any mod eof transport you can afford to start and let the town and your finances grow, Then slowly expand but always have 1 million in reserve. If you get through the first 10 years and use money wisely you are there. Do not do any expensive project until you reach 20m: ie tunnels , bridges and damn expensive trains until you are sure the investment will pay off.  And when you do SAVE before you embark on it so you can return to that point if the prject goes pear shaped.

review:
I had a lot of hopes for this game, unfortunately its came up short as it is right now. 

Positives are it looks nice graphically and the HQ is a nice addition as well as the platform configuration.

Negatives outweigh those by a tonne. UI isnt as good as the first game, not being able to send goods to any town is a big no in my book, AI decisions are bordering on stupid just to name a few.

Game developers need to realise we want freedom and choice in a game not to be given limitations or being told what can and cannot go where, first game didnt do it so why on earth do you think we would want it in this one? stop fixing things that arent broke, if you have no ideas that improve the game rather than hinder the player and take away from the fun, either dont make a sequel until you do, or make the same game with better graphics and less bugs. Either be better than what is done right now. 

If you want a game like this buy TF1. better game and cheaper than this game as it stands right now. or wait until if and when this games fixed.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Great game, however, after spending 20+ hours on one map, going from 1850's to 2010+, building pretty much everything, there is a massive lack off content late-game. Best example being Bullet trains/Shinkansen, there is only one, and its a fixed train, no customization to it. And the highspeed track (300km/h), is there but no train that can really utilize it fully, not even the _only_ Shinkansen in the game that only reaches 220km/h. Now, it's not only a "train" game I get that, you have access to all types of transport, but even the other types lack diversity late game.

There is also a severe lack of options for prioritization and min/maxing in the goods chains, it works, but it's a really dumb system, which also shows when you try and deliver goods to their final destinations in the cities. You can't really make "effective" routes for goods, you have to spam and make what could only be described as "Cluster F**ks" of serveral routes all over the city.

Speaking of the cities, they only have 2 "needs" and allways will, which lowers the challenge of the game overall, would really have liked to see that after a while, they would require a 3rd or even a 4th.
It's also (as a side note) annoying that you can really focus on one town and after a few in-game years, you notice that other town's which you have not interacted with at all, grows more then the city you actually are working on.

All in all, the first playthrough's are amazing but it gets old really quick after that.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I am a fan of the Train Fever / Transport Fever games, but I cannot yet recommend this version.

The game is a sidestep, it has some graphical improvements, changes to industry  and some nice features, but its all too little and overshadowed by non intuitive user interface/experience, lack of information when you need it, terrible mid game performance that is worse than the previous titles (which also suffer badly from performance)

The simplification  of industry (although I have modded that) was a let down, a more complex industry chain is needed, not a simplified one, even compared to the prior titles.

The dev's are also fairly quiet which is strange, the game is still in its infancy, you would expect a lot more comms, but nope, silent other than a few patch notes which are generally posted by users in the beta branch before the dev's (and by that I mean days before, not 5 mins)

They are bolting stuff on to their engine, without fixing the fundamental issues that already exist.  Performance / Long pauses / Lagging and User experience / UI have been common complaints since Train fever and they still exist today!

I run a 9900k, 2080ti, NVME SSD and 32gb ram, yet I also get 30 second pauses when building/modifying anything or even just smoothing the terrain.  Reported this fairly early on but whether they have the ability to optimise/fix this variant of the game is yet to be known.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:

Did you play transport tycoon? Then get this.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Really fun game to pass the time with. My few "criticisms" would be that even the largest map is not of a truly epic scale, and cities are a bit too small, plus the road system should evolve over time even without player input (local authorities or something). There are also a few glitches I encountered, especially relating to bridges and tunnels - when there are two rails collapsing into one at the base of a tunnel or bridge, sometimes your trains visuals seem to go through the wall or electric lines. But overall, it's a really fun transport game, I really like it and would recommend, UI is easy to figure out and understand and well thought out, vehicles look great.

Possibly the biggest criticism at the time of this review is that as soon as you run the game on a less tip top computer, it tends to crash a lot, but I read that the devs are taking steps to fix the RAM usage issue, so I am hoping this will be fixed soon.

I had a fun experience in the hours I've played but you will quickly realise that there is not many built-in challanges to overcome. Once you are past the first hour or so of setting your company up you will have a money-printing machine and the rest of the game money will not be a factor.
The system in place that automatically determines which commodity goes where is good and easy to use, but it takes away some of the gameplay that is fun to do in this kind of game.

The graphics are not very good for a game in 2019, not a big issue but for this price I would expect more.

Edit: after playing some more hours I've revised my review. The game is very fun despite the negatives mentioned above. Upping the difficulty to hard makes for a longer period with the game being a challenge. The game has drawbacks but overall I am having a good time while playing it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
For the people that blame the TF2 for the lack of features, hear this. If you only care about a advanced UI find another game, this is a game both based on UI and complex transportation systems PLUS great graphics, and finally animations and sounds. I mainly like TF2 because its a open sandbox where people can publish for free content for everyone, allowing full customization. Its a new game and I think it needs some time to be polished and for new features to come out. This game's goal is to be a optimized open world sandbox for people to customize it the way they want, and for this, it does great. 
Great graphics, improved animations, but very bad sounds ( doors. buses. and generally ) 
Lack of graphic settings, I would like advanced things so I can disable things I don't care about ( shadows etc.)
good UI, but some features are missing ( automatic vehicle replacement at X lifetime or Y condition as it was on TF1 ) So after a line is set its automated forever
In conclusion, a way better version of TF1 in terms of graphics animations and UI design  ( for now ) in the near future, I think we will start noticing a huge difference compared to TF1 NOW

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Good upgrade rather than a big change.  Looks better and does things better than TF1 but you could argue not enough to warrant the price. title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TL;DR - yeah, get it. Use mods to enhance everything, it's fire.

Now listen, you can sit here and tell me that this game is too similar to the first. You can tell me it's not worth the money just to lose out on all the mods the first has. You can tell me a lot of things about this game, but I don't care. I have played it nonstop since I bought it the other day and it's really strange.

I liked the first game a lot, don't get me wrong. I just feel differently about this one. The first game I saw as a sandbox train set experience. I never really played a free game without unlimited money, at any point, for more than 5 or so hours. I would just download cool maps, fiddle around with some nice trains for a few hours, and start fresh again a few days/weeks later. This time, it's different. I haven't even done a sandbox game yet in TpF2. I've actually played the game, on hard, and succeeded so far (1850 - 1950ish so far). Maybe I've finally figured out some of the systems, maybe the game is just straight up easier. I don't know and I don't care though. I find it very enthralling, especially with mods. Mod support already is insane too, I just wish I didn't have to sift through the dozens of maps sometimes. That's my only real complaint so far: stop uploading your poopoo maps, people.

I also want to highlight the map editor. The first 5 or more hours I spent with the game was simply generating a cool map I wanted with every thing that I liked. It was very hard for me to want to make a custom map in the first game as there wasn't an easy system like there is in TpF2. However, this editor is insanely fun to toy around with. Again, there's mods on the workshop for it to even further expand your horizons.

Final thoughts: Buy it if you liked the first, buy it if you like tycoon-esque games, buy it if you enjoy trains or whatever mode of transport you fancy, buy it and make sure to please thank the mod creators and support them. Vanilla, I'm sure this game is fantastic but the modding community makes it a joy to come back to day after day. Truly one of the best modding communities on the Workshop.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have played a lot of this, and enjoyed it despite its performance issues.  

- Is it a new game?  No.  But it's a nice upgrade - but just re-uses a lot of the old vehicles.  You see very little different to TF1 in early years, but modern cities do look better.  If you can forgive 10FPS.
- Is it much better than TF1?  No.  The UI seems harder to use and being restricted to one pop up at a time is restrictive.  Mass replacement of vehicles is now a nightmare.  Auto replace is gone. 
- Is it worth the price?  No - wait until they fix the performance. 
- Do you need a beast of a PC?  Yes.  I have a decent rig (4 cores and a good 1080) but anything beyond small map is a stutter fest once the cities get busy.  Even small maps with busy cities are stuttery. 

If you want a version of Transport Fever with slightly improved graphics and a better camera for viewing vehicles, this could be for you.  If you want a whole new game, a complete change from TF1, then give it a miss.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Fantastic logistical simulator.  Highly recommended for fans of the genre, but if this is your first shipping tycoon game you should start somewhere else as there are very easy things to overlook and cause frustration.

Highs: 

- Graphics are nice, audio is fantastic
- Early to mid game performance is great
- Mod support + Map editor

Lows:

-Campaign was largely disappointing with many side quests that exist simply to have you try out all the world building tools, or camera controls.  When you take time to complete said quests, there is no reward other than a 'gold star' rating on the mission.   I would have preferred putting all of those into the first mission, and then focusing on the core elements for the rest of the campaign missions, instead there are these little annoying missions all over the place.  I gave up on mission 5 or 6.

-Game runs at a solid 144 fps until you get four or five busy routes, then it starts to degrade to sub-60 fps by the four or five hour mark.  This is not uncommon for games in this genre, the simulation is quite complex, but I'm always hoping that some update will alleviate this stress.

review:
Definitely an improvement on the original title. No revolution, it's still the same excellent transport tycoon game, but offers a few new features and updated graphics. The campaign is much more interesting and enjoyable now. The mechanics of the free mode changed a bit as well, putting more focus on growing cities and balancing the deliveries to all of them.

Overall, I'm really happy with this game. I played 120 h so far and just completed all steam achievements, but it's definitely nowhere near the end of my adventure with the game. The original game feels like "the good old TF1" now and I don't think I will come back to it, TF2 is fun!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Disclaimer: I bought this game with my own money and it was not given to me in any way shape or form. The review below is my own opinion on the game and there isn't anyone profiting from it, except from when I paid for it.

Transport Fever 2 is basically Transport Fever 1, but prettier with all kinds of quality of life improvements. I've had loads of fun with the first game and I never regretted buying the second. Even though there are a few negative points, they aren't really negative points at the same time, because I knew in advance that it wasn't going to happen.

See, I had been hoping that the second game could possibly have one of these maps that are technically endless. That and A.I controlled companies to making your life a bit more interesting. But like I said, neither of those two were going to happen, so it isn't really a negative point aside from the fact that they would have made the game a lot better.

Now, I'm not sure why I only have seven and a bit hours registered, since I played the game a lot more, but let me say that I know the game very well. If you're hesitating to buy the game, I would advise you to just watch a let's plays. Colonel Failure is a well known YouTuber, so take a look at his channel.

When I write a review, I always try to give a non biased opinion. I try to look at it, from the eyes of someone who doesn't like the game and then I try to go from there.

From that standpoint, there are a few things that come to mind. The first thing that comes to mind is that it can get boring. If you just start a new game without playing the campaign, it takes awhile to figure out what to do. It happened a few times, that when I was trying to get a chain going, that one part simply wasn't there. Oh, and while I'll admit that those times weren't mod free, the mods I had active had nothing to do with it.

Now, once you figure out what you're supposed to do, you really need to think about it. Watching a few lets plays will help trying to decide how you want to make money. By road, by rail, by water or by air. But once you do get a profit, you can basically let the game do its thing, wait an hour or two and then come back to have a small fortune to spend. A small fortune, you can then spent, wait until you're sure you're having a small profit and then let it go for a few hours again.

One thing I also like is that you can 'freeze' the time period, you're playing in. If you like to play way at the beginning, the 1850's, you can 'freeze' it at that time, and even though time still passes, you still make money and all that, but you'll never get newer vehicles. So all it really does, is that it prevents new vehicles from unlocking.

Another thing that also helps a lot is the amount of helpful mods people have already made. There are mods that are blatantly cheats and then there are mods that just make your life a bit easier. Or they're more easy going on your ears, by deleting the bulldozer sounds.

One thing that I also noticed is that there's been some copying and pasting going on. In the first TF you laid rails, roads, bought trains, bought vehicles, connected them to a route, you deployed them and eventually you make a profit. That's basically the same in TF2. That's not really a surprise, but if you ignore the improvements, then you have basically the same game. Prettier perhaps, but basically identical.

Now, if you enjoyed the first Transport Fever? Then you'll have loads of fun with this one. There's no doubt about that. But if you went 'meh' with the first TF and didn't really play it all that much after purchase? I would give this game a pass.

campain:
The campaign of the first game had a lot of humor to it. It had also only a single voice actor. TF2 has a unique voice actor for every campaign. But ultimately, I like the campaign of the first game better. It was just more amusing to play. That's why I wouldn't bother with the campaign in the second game. It sucks and there's no real connection between missions. Which is a shame. It would've been fun if you could have 'transferred' the money you had in the bank to the next mission.

CONCLUSSION:
I've already said this before, but it's really too bad that it's either YES or NO. There is no in between. If you already played the first game and you enjoyed yourself? Then YES! Buy it! If the first game bored you after a few hours, then NO, don't waste your money on it. But if you know the kind of game you're looking at, and you watched enough video's so you won't have any unpleasant surprises, then my ultimate conclussion is:

YES! Buy the game. Just make sure you know what you're getting yourself into.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a pretty neat sandbox transportation and economy game.  It's fairly polished. Just a few things you might need to know:

- There are no AI competitors. There is a challenge mode, but in sandbox you will need to make your own goals
- There are some occasional crashes during loading and play
- The game takes a lot of RAM, almost 8GB. If you have a PC with 8GB or less installed, you will probably not be able to run it. I hope this will be fixed in the future.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever is defently one of my favorite games! And i'm not gonna lie! I just bought this due to the improved graphics and details on different objects in the game, but let me try write a okey review that might convince you that this game is worth it more then just for the graphics.

Postive stuff:
- They added most of the previous items from Transport Fever to Transport Fever 2 + add extra objects etc.
- (i'm not a modder so i might be wrong on this) From what i seen the modding community have it way better with making mods for this game then the last one! + Now you can have signs on buses, trains etc that can say what the next station is and say what line this also is (i don't rename lines as i am used to seing numbers on buses etc instead of names)  Also you can now have Glow emission from what it looks. This makes it possible to have such amazing mods. (I highly reccomend the night mod!)
-AI improvements + Roundabouts and a functioning Highway, Ship and plane improvements.
- AN AMAZING CAMERA UPDATE! If you don't wanna bother with the controls in spectate mode on a bus you can always click escape and it still follows ur bus until u move your camera + You can then zoom in and out and use the middle mouse to rotate the camera around the bus, Those controls in my opinion are better then WASD and Arrow keys in spectate mode
- More customization before you start a free game + Improved stations with customization where you can go rampage with the settings, make a weird looking station or make a huge one. Pretty sweet.
- More customization on lines etc.
- Tabbing in and out of the game is working better

Negativity ish:
-This is techniclly a DLC. But i gonna be honest, as a DLC it would not make sense to have these graphic updates. so i do understand their reason for making it a brand new game due to improvements i believe had to be done.
- Don't have much negative to say about it!
- Takes high pc rescourses :( 

I forgot the rest i wanted to type :3

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
There are quite a few disappointments like only 2 cargo needs per city (like get real!), adding entrances and exits to truck stations usually makes no difference since the trucks ignore an added nearby exit and go toward the shortest path. Whole truck stations can be backed up to enter or leave by one entrance or exit when there are 6 other entrances or exits free. Trucks stop halfway on cargo pads and back up everything. Mod available to correct this. Modding can add 6 cargo needs to a city. 6 lane highway, vehicles move to one lane forever and jam traffic even when alternate routes are traffic free. (Not AI traffic by far!).  Trucks are insanely stupid and pick wrong cargo and need to be micro-managed but with mods, the game is still very addicting.

Willbe addictive after you get the right mods and learn the games non-AI systems and how to overcome them. I am still trying to overcome the lack of  some needed AI.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Best classic style transport tycoon game currently on the market - Worth the buy in for the "free play" mode alone. Between the campaign, free play, map editor and steam workshop, virtually endless replayability.

Pros
- Graphics
- Hugely customisable
- Virtually endless workshop content
- Immersion (very easy to lose a whole day in)
- Complexity (can essentially be made as simple or as complex as the player desires)
- Easily the best transport tycoon available

Cons
- Still a little glitchy at times (however it hasn't been out long)
- UI can be clunky until you get used to it.
- For the life of me still can't figure out reversible trains.

Overall I'd give it a solid 8/10, It's a particularly good choice for any vehicle/transport or tycoon fans.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I don't think I've been as disappointed in a version two of a game in some time. 
-Scale is very different than V1. I feel like I'm playing a weird toy version now.  Cities are exaggerated in size.
-resource depots are larger than some towns but the distance between them is very small (often the same size as a depot).
-iconography seems like its geared towards children
-weird maintenance mechanic that ties back to the environment (don't update the vehicles they make more pollution but no one seems to care)
-trains work illogical
-planes make far to much money for the cargo they carry.
-boring without much challenge
-design may or may not appeal to you.

I feel like I'm playing a children's version of TF1. I would return if I could. I hope it gets better with patches.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I loved TF1 but was bugged by a few of the bugs, track laying in particular but TF2 has polished out those bugs and made a very good looking easy on the eye transport sim.  The graphics take it up a notch, I love the sitting in the train watching the world go by and the scenery is fabulous, the flexibility in building stations by expansion of modules and combining passenger and goods stations all make this on paper a great upgrade, so why am I left underwhelmed?  I can't really answer that,  I've added mods, removed mods, played the base game and I'm just left each time feeling a bit, well, bored. Others have said its easy, even on hard and it is.  In TF1 you'd get games that were a  bit boring but others that were just excellent depending on how things developed. In TF2 I just find I get a mediocrity that is underwhelming. I can't really say what is missing as it does all appear to be here,  its not a bad games, I'd even go so far as to say its OK (!) but its not a great game - yet?  So I've decided to take a break from it until the next big patch comes out and we'll see how it plays then.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I LOVE this Game... But (ain't there always a but), it's really two games: One is building rails, roads, bridges, airports, ports and watching your Vehicles run from either a God-like view or a driver's view or free cam. That's fun for most people and the game doesn't force you to do the second.  The second is like a course in accounting:  Hundreds of tedious set-ups, routes, financial judgments... hours and hours of details and tweeks just to get it running smoothly... for a while, then it grows, becomes a monster you need to attempt to tame all over again. But this time you have lots of money so it won't be as hard... no, more money gets you in trouble faster than a limited budget... there's some real-life lesson to be learned here, I wish I could figure out what it was. But what's food, a house, a "real" life when you can play this game?  :)  If you love it, it's both difficult and rewarding, if you don't, it's torture. Me? I love it.  (I've played the first version more than this 2nd one, the original one is almost as good. )

review: This game is really great. I used to enjoy Railroad Tycoon back in the 90's, and this is the first transportation game I have enjoyed since then. The way the game scales is particularly nice, and you can really see how transportation changes dramatically especially from 1850-1930. Routes that were difficult in 1850 become simple by 1930. The graphics are also very detailed, and you can zoom in to every detail of your transportation network.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: super fun game

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
[h1] Initial First Impressions Review, Subject to Change [/h1]

My system isn't exactly top notch, but I am having a right pain to get a decent framerate.

Win 8.1 GTX 970 4gb i7 4790k @4ghz 16GB DDR3 ram 1080p

Lots of instability on empty maps, of different sizes, climate, and generation settings. Never had this in the first title, only late game when you have a massive network spreading across the map. At this stage I should expect a constant 60 (which I lock to). Yeah... dropping to 12-30 with shoots to 60... too jarring.

Ingame settings don't seem to make any difference, neither do some NVIDIA CP tweaks. At this stage it is only the prospect of the modular buildings (that I have yet to tinker with) is keeping me from refunding this iteration.

Also, I was expecting a lot more modern railstock. I am a huge fan of huge American based maps, those long diesel cargo trains are just too fun. But took a quick look at what is available in 2000 on a US themed map. Three diesels. Three. No wellcars at all. Iconic American cargo railstock just... non-existent in the stock game.

I was sort of hoping for a wider range of equipment, but it seems I will once again be relying on the awesome folks at the Workshop to bring me what I'm looking for.

Very disappointing out of the box though, would I refund it? I don't want to, not really, but seeing how poorly an empty map seems to run I have little hope for how a built up map will handle.

Unscored at this time.


[h1] Update: Put in refund request [/h1]

So disappointed right now. Nicer graphics and some decent features does not make up for the games shortfalls. Poorly optimised, lack of new content, no groundbreaking improvement over the original... feels very much like a update to the first game than a sequel.

Will consider rebuying after lots of patches, some more FREE content, and will give the chance for the wonderful Workshop Modders to convert their stuff from TPF1.

Will also need a deep, deep sale for me to reconsider TPF2. I'll stick with Open TTD until I can be bothered to reinstall TPF1.

Do not believe the hype, seriously. I'm actually quite disconcerted about how some really quite popular content creators are lauding this game. At this time, as of release day, this is not worth a buy.

Refusing to score/10.

[b]EDIT 2[/b]

I rebought the game 'cos I caved, and I got the same TF1 owners deal. But it is awful. Laying tracks literally makes me seasick, and in a Railroad Logistics game you tend to do that quite a lot.

The new features are thin on the ground, ill-conceived and need balancing. Plus, the game needs more content [b]stock[/b]. At this point TF1 offers just as much, and that is before all those wonderful Workshop mods. 

I'm hoping TF2 gets some major love over the next few months, but quite honestly, the team behind this title needs a majorly stern talking to. The first title puts this one to shame.

If TF2 looks interesting to you, pick up the first game instead while on sale. It is the better package at this time.

[b]EDIT 3[/b]

How this can be reviewed as "Very Positive" on Steam I have no idea.

Performance is awful compared to the previous title, money is just thrown at you even on the hardest of settings, you have to be [b]incredibly[/b] stupid to go bankrupt. You can now edit a consist on the fly, no longer need to send to depot, [b]realism much?[/b]. 

The Modular Stations is so underwhelming and poorly used. I was under the impression that the extra add-on buildings would actually have a use; expanding the capacity of the station, processing goods/passengers faster, that sort of thing. But no, purely aesthetics. Aside from the ability to easily add in new tracks the feature is worthless.

It is fine for those that have not played Train or Transport Fever, but for those who have, do not upgrade to this title. [b]It simply is not worth it in the slightest[/b], TPF1 gives such a better and more realistic experience, I would even steer new players away from this one and towards the predecessor.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I would give this a neutral review if I could, but to literally interpret Steam's question of "Would you recommend this game to other players", at the moment my answer would have to be no.

The learning curve is a bit steep, but this isn't why. Most new players that go in blind will probably go bankrupt, but looking up a guide can solve this very easily. Why I don't recommend it - even with multiple highly-profitable lines in operation, it takes a long time to build up cash to do anything. As in: Put the game on max speed, go cook something or tab out for 30 minutes and come back.

Then you fund a new project, which is interesting and fun for a time. If the result profitable, repeat the AFK session above. If it's an experiment that proves unprofitable, well... you might be AFKing to make up that lost cash a mite longer.

You are discouraged from working on projects piecemeal because you pay maintenance on all infrastructure - so you don't want to start until you can fund it all the way to the finish. There is no intermediary gameplay while waiting for money for projects.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TF2 has superior graphics to the previous incarnation, superior environments, city growth reaching skyscrapers and an excellent map editor. Unfortunately, some valuable features of the previous incarnation aren't present, leaving the game feeling unfinished. There are no logos, no company name displayed on the equipment, lines don't show ticket prices, pedestrians don't display speed/price preferences, the player can't choose a color for all vehicles at purchase despite that all vehicles can have their color changed manually in the vehicle management menu, and vehicle maintenance costs no longer increase with age but instead that mechanic is replaced with an environmental impact mechanic. Some improvements that I expected the next incarnation to have aren't present. "Too much slope" is still a problem while laying track, one still has to upgrade each track/road section at a time as opposed to upgrading all track/road along a line or all track/road in general or all track/road in a given area with a single click of a button, all rail signals still can't be replaced with a single click of a button, bridges still can't be upgraded but must be demolished and replaced manually, and laying straight roads is still difficult and time consuming.

TF2 is overall superior to its predecessor but falls short in some areas in which TF1 did not, may not be the sequel you were expecting, may have lesser character and spirit, and you may not invest as many hours into it as you did TF1, but it's an enjoyable game and you won't likely go back to TF1 after playing TF2.

The complete lack of loco diversity is also a really stupid decision. The base game has got like 20 russian vehicles on the asian subset yet not a single japanese SL? The base names for asia also takes names from asia-minor and russia, which I really don't think it should. 

If all you want is pretty graphics this game might be worth it to you, but in my mind the game lacks appealing features that keep you playing with your friends through multiplayer sessions, and completely bizarre decisions when it comes to train distribution.
Open TTD does everything this game tries to do better and cheaper, although in a less appealing package.
