title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The crack cocaine of the transportation simulator world just got a little purer.

Yes, you should buy it.  No really.  Don't wait to read the rest of the review, get it in your cart and buy.  If you like this kind of game this is the only one that is essential to own.  Do it now.

Bought it?  Good.  Now relax and read the review.

The game is about using transportation to deliver goods and passengers on maps.  There is a campaign and a sandbox mode.  In the original Transport Fever the campaign was unplayable, but in TF2 the campaign is as important as the sandbox mode.  Business is less important in this game than good layouts, an understanding of the number and type of vehicles on each route, and an understanding that mass transit must be 'fed' from smaller arterial routes.

In many ways its the same as Transport Fever with quality of life updates, a new campaign, slightly better graphics and performance tweaks.  Most of the old frustrations, such as track-laying issues, still exist.  You still need to lay the track piece by piece, you can't undo what you lay without paying a fee to bulldoze, and you can't tweak a 'blueprint' of the track before you commit to it.  Also, signals are still hand-built, one at a time.  Its so last-decade.  Yes, there have been many competitor games that have done a better job of track laying, but none of them are in the same league as this game overall.

On the plus side, the campaign is a genuine, enjoyable, sensible set of missions designed for the people likely to want to buy the game.  The original Transport Fever had a campaign that was utterly appalling.  TF2 learned their lesson and the new campaign (I've almost finished it) has a better balance.  Its not perfect, but its acceptable.  You don't have to exploit the game engine to complete the missions as you had to do in Transport Fever, which is always nice.

This is largely a game about trains, but that does do it a disservice.  The Miami campaign has no trains on it whatsoever, and it shows what can be achieved with the other assets.  But the trains are the most enjoyable part of the game, and honestly the other transportation feels underdeveloped.  Boats are always very close to being useless, and aircraft carry such small amounts of passengers and cargo they also feel weak.  But they do add some options, and they have been creatively used in some campaign missions justifying their inclusion.

The types of vehicles available without modding are limited and strangely chosen.  There are a lot of similarly-priced steam engines with very similar performance and price that seem to have been added to appeal to the Chinese player.  I've seen no British trains (yet the UK invented the locomotive), but a large number of nondescript Russian models, some quite weak Chinese types, and an eclectic and baffling selection of electrics and diesels.  There's no sense or theme it seems to what locomotives get included in the game and what are left out, whether from a gameplay viewpoint or general coherence.   Its not a deal-breaker, but choice is lacking.

I haven't played the sandbox mode yet.  Some people have criticised this aspect of the game, but I can't comment on something I haven't tried. 

Graphics are somewhat nicer that Transport Fever, and the physics engine feels as excellent as ever.  The sound varies, and the samples feel very repetitive after a time.  But presentation is good and the overall feel is solid.

At the end of the day, this game is a masterpiece.  That's why you need to buy it.  Criticising individual elements of gameplay is like commenting on rough brushwork in the Mona Lisa.  Just accept you will have to own this game, you will enjoy it, and the failings will be addressed to some extent by the astonishing modding community.

Enough reading.  You've bought it.  Now play it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
As per usual with this developer ( train fever > transport fever > transport fever 2) this is more of a refresh with some good ideas and improvements, rather than a quantum leap. 2 steps forward 1 step back kind of stuff. Graphics are better, but should have been even better in my opinion.

The maps are nice but have these bizarre white rocks scattered about to create a sense of change in the scenery, that needs improvement and we need multi biome maps. Maps seems smaller and industry is reduced, but I do feel like you are more pressed into creating multi layered networks that rely on each other and feed each other. Planes and ships work better but need far more choice in terms of vehicles.

I found myself getting bored a little quicker than TF1 but that said I can't go back to TF1, and am patiently waiting for all the mods to be ported across.

I do hope the dev decides to add a expansions/DLC this time to improve the game (day night cycles, more industries and such).

I like this game and it's very relaxing, but I wish there was a bit more challenge to it, I'm a gazzilionaire already. I do wish they had competing AI players like transport tycoon, but I realise that would be super hard to code. Maybe one day.

I recommend if you like this type of game, if only to watch your stuff doing their thing.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game does alot right and is highly enjoyable for people who like trains, city managment and have alot of time to kill.

Although it does have it's faults

Pro's

1: Very large and detailed maps
2: a Wide variaty of different trains, trucks, buses, planes and ships to use
3: 3 Different regional styles/themes
4: 3 Different map styles
5: a Campaign which is more like a glorified tutorial
6: Modular stations
7: Start as early as 1850 all the way into 2050
8: The ability to pause the dates while keeping the sim running

Cons

1: No variety in ships or planes throughout the 3 different themes
2: I have not played TF 1 but, It has come to my attention that USA and Europe themes are almost identical with very little new stuff added
3: No variety in station apearances, which looks the same in all 3 themes
4: No day/night cycle or any weather effects
5: Unable to move/buldose industries in "Free Game" mode
6: Consumer and Supplier industries sometimes spawn lightyears away from eachother

Suggestions

1: Allow the ability to move/buldose industries in Free game provided they are replaced within a small radias of their original location, this will allow more freedom in "Free Game" without allowing players to cheese the game by placing industries right next to eachother
2: Day/Night cycle (Purely asthettic reasons)
3: This one might be harder... weather and weather effects, having seasonal weather changes and then in turn having them effect transit I.E it's harder to drive in snow etc. This will provide some additional challenge to an otherwise fairly easy late game
4: Get some variety in aircraft and ships regarding the themes, it get's boring real quick when they look the same for USA, Europe and Asia

All in all I would still highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of this kind of sorta mellow sit back and chill managment titles

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Edit, 126 hours in, still having a lot of fun, still agree with what I've posted below...

I have over 500+ hours in TPF and really enjoyed it, and this one is fun too, but that being said, this is an early review, which I know can be incomplete, and my opinion could change past the 40-60 hour mark.  Also, I’ve been watching Youtubers for two weeks, so I didn’t go in without seeing quite a bit of gameplay.

Keep in mind, I play at 4K, but have a mid-ranged PC setup, but 16GB of RAM, game runs pretty well.

The Asia map gives the game a different feel, while the temperate one still feels close to TPF with an improvement to graphics that is noticeable, but the Asia map really feels different.  The Desert map I could take or leave, I'll need to play that more to see what I think.  

Ships are profitable (currently on medium difficulty) and are rather fun this go around, I've made three maps so far; a river route, islands, and a desert.  

When running trains, it feels a lot like TPF, so at times, I'm not feeling like there's anything new there, but replacing vehicles and the new maintenance options are different.  Also, modular stations are cool, and I really like that we can combine passenger/cargo stations and linking across different types of transportation, trains, trucks, boats, planes.

I do like how information is presented for line management, etc. in the new version.  The new management menus are fantastic, possibly my favorite part, the information is presented better than it was in TPF.  I don't know if I'll get 500+ hours out of this one, but I enjoyed the first 7 hours played today.  Road and track laying also seem to be improved, smoother, easier bridges, overpasses…

Am I having fun?  Yes.  Am I over the moon?  Not necessarily.  Would I go back to TPF1?  No.  

I do believe TPF2 is a great game, just doesn’t feel like a huge leap forward, but lots of QOL improvements that are worth it.  

For the future - I'm curious to see how large, full route, busy maps run, so that is also yet to be determined.

For example, if you get all the right resources to a refinery to make fuel, it won't produce anything at all until you have a distribution chain already running to create demand for the fuel. I'm 50+ hours in and I still only sort of feel like I know what I'm doing. There's times I look at my screen thinking, "This should be working... why is nothing happening?"  I've watched quite a lot of tutorial and let's play videos to get a better handle on the game and still I'd only consider myself to be somewhere between a beginner and novice player. I almost gave up on it and requested a refund after an hour or two, but pushed through and am glad I stuck with it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Like the name suggests, it's Transport Fever (or Train Fever for all that matters). The core gameplay loop didn't change much from the previous titles - you build transport networks and deliver goods to factories and towns. If you played either of the other games you will instantly feel at home.

There are 18 missions grouped into 3 campaigns roughly by era (early, steam, modern). The campaigns are ok-ish and more of an introduction to the "real" game, which is freeplay.

The graphics are good, the performance is ok (though my computer probably is not representative for the majority, I can't really tell how it's for averge and lower end PCs)

I liked the music in TPF1 more, but there is a mod for that. 

Which brings me to, the game has mod support and thanks to a very active modding community the Workshop is stuffed with all sort of things, from simple tree assets over vehicles to different map-generators and complete industry overhauls (it probaly also helps that porting mods from TPF1 doesnt seem overly complicated, tho I cant really tell)

The economic side of the game is pretty weak, once you built a few profitable connections, you'll just get richer and richer. So if you looking for a real challenge here it's probably not for you. The puzzle side of the game is, thanks to towns only requiring 2 (out of 6) goods, pretty strong though, even stronger than TPF1. And if you like it like it was in TPF1 -> "there is a mod for that"

All in all I would recommend the game if you are into building transport (or lets be honest train)-networks. It's also nice for just building scenic train lines with money disabled.

What I would really like to see from the devs are handcrafted freeplay-maps. But maybe in TPF3?

There are a few nuances that could be worked out though mainly with trains. Why are electric trains so much more expensive than diesel trains? It's really hard to operate a line later in the game because the expense becomes so much greater. Also there's this annoying glitch where the keys get stuck rotating the camera and won't stop.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: If you enjoy OTTD, you must have this one. It's kinda remake of the old classic OTTD, with a great optimization in usability (much less clicks), and the graphics wow! The campaigns through time and history of transports have a narrative that reminds me of another classic game: AoE II. You can't control the cities, but sometimes the graphics reminds me of another classic game: Sim City.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is pleasant and nice game. But IMHO it's broken on it's fundamental mechanics.

PROS:
- campaign
  Gives nice context, many missions with various challenges.

- lots of cars, trucks, trains, wagons, plains
- build process
  It's easy to learn how to build anything, and tracks looks very nice.

- working Linux version
  I've played on both versions windows and Linux and this is big plus, they look same on both OSes.

CONS:
- build process
  Misses automatic signal placement, in intervals 200m for example.

- translation in polish is not very polished ;)
  Missing texts, texts from German language.

- line broken finding / not finding
  When complex line is broken I can't find easily where it's broken, and sometimes I must destroy whole chunks of network to find where problem is

- trams
  If this is transportation simulator, why the hell trams can rotate in place when stop is on opposite side of road? In normal life they need loop to change direction.

- indestructible trains
  Trains don't broke, they don't need to go into depot for fixing. Even in very bad shape they are driving.
  I have train with very bad condition and it don't need repairs, it does not go into depot.
  Depot is only needed to spit out the train and that's it.

- train repairs -
  They should be optional and available to schedule. Train would be repaired to good shape and replaced only when it's too old.

- trains replacing/building
  I can replace train and it's wagons in place... They don't need to go to depot to do that.

- trains can't unload on first free platform
  Traffic dispatcher in normal life direct train to free platform when it is necessary. Even when station has 8 platforms your line will use only one...

- platforms overloading
  I have two lines over three stations.
  First station to load iron, second to load coal, third to unload both.
  One train on each line has 20 wagons of same type.
  Game knows that I can grab for example 200 units of coal, but instead of doing it right it overloads first line, leaving nothing to second. Why???

  Don't leave this one to economy. Both mines with coal and iron produces 400 units.
  Two mines produces 800 units, and I am using 40 wagons (20 units each).
  So two trains loading 50% of coal and 50% of iron can handle that easily.

  If this could be economy problem, why mines are producing at that scale?

  Image with overloading situation:
  https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1967517785

  Second problem is that they are waiting for something, even when they are fully loaded with required cargo. Why?
  Waiting problem is not present while there is only one line and one track...

Some of these problems are with us from first version of game.
This game is v1.4 not v2.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It is exceptionally rare for a sequel to be better than the original in every single way.  Transport Fever 2 is one of those cases.

While I enjoyed TF1, the vanilla version never felt "fully formed" to me.  There were economic problems, balance issues, and oddball vehicle stats that I could never resolve.  I am thrilled that ALL of those issues have been resolved in TF2, and am having an absolute blast with this game.

The devs have been hard at work eliminating some of the Day One bugs:  I had several crashes during my first playthrough, and one fatal error that prevented me from continuing in a world I had built.  This was frustrating, but I have had no similar occurrences since the first (mid-December) patch.

As ever, the modding community for TF is thriving, and every day a new asset or map or script enhancement is made available which contributes to the endless replayability of the title.  Modders for TF1 were ingenious and helpful, and the devs' encouragement of those mods continue to make this community a welcome one.

If you are old-school enough, think of this game as falling midway between Cities Skylines and Railroad Tycoon 2.  Its most apt comparison is probably to the old Transport Tycoon:  You can build roads, rails, and ship routes, but you do not directly build cities and do not build industries at all.  Maps are procedurally generated and not geographically-based, although seemingly every day a new 'true-to-life' map is added to the Workshop.  TF2 comes with a map editor which allows you to sculpt terrain and build cities and industries where you want them.  It even provides a Sandbox mode so you can build your world without worrying about pesky things like costs and fees.  There is a campaign mode which is basically just there to teach you game mechanics; having played TF1 I got halfway through the campaign before bailing out and starting my own world.

There is a broad ability to customize what you build.  Stations are modular, so you can make hybrid passenger-cargo stations by adding a platform of your choice.  Stations, lines, and vehicles can all be named...and the attention to detail here is really fun:  Seeing the name of a line scroll across the digital display on the front of a bus is strangely cool.

There are a LOT of small details like that which the devs have clearly made a priority.  Lights transition from incandescent to LED over time, people walk from place to place, and do not cease being "people" once they enter a vehicle.  In older games, people would stand at a platform, board a vehicle, and disappear.  The other day I watched people board a tram, take their seats, and interact.  A lady crossed her legs, put her hands in her lap, then began "talking" to a guy across from here, gesturing with her hands as he gestured back. It looked real, immersive.  And I loved it.

I have only really found two quibbles with this game.  The first is the life cycle of vehicles, specifically how they are swapped out when their age becomes cost-prohibitive.  For whatever reason I find it a little more challenging to do a simple repurchase of the same vehicle.  I try and "Clone" it, but the vehicle spawns at some odd location far from where I want it.  This might be user error, but if that is the case it probably should not be so difficult for the user.  My second dislike is the new "emissions" mechanic.  I don't like it.  At all.  It provides needless complication and seems almost arbitrary in how it is designed:  An idling vehicle that hasn't moved magically provides emissions along its entire route?!  You're killing me.  There is a mod to kill this feature and I may take that up as it detracts from my transportation utopia.

But when something that small is your big problem with a game, you know you have stumbled onto something rare.  TF2 is a rare and welcome achievement in the Transport Tycoon mold, and is the best game I purchased in 2019.

YOU'LL LOVE:  The numerous vehicles available, the efficient UI, the simplicity of building, the wide ability to customize stations, the attention to small, fun details.

YOU'LL LIKE:  The vast array of mods created by an active community, the challenge of starting "in the hole" with money lent to you, the ability to merge multiple forms of transportation to take goods across an attractively detailed map.

YOU'LL DISLIKE:  The inability to use your accumulated wealth to build industries or buy property, the occasional end-of-lifecycle replacement difficulties, the emissions mechanic.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a rework and expansion of TF1. It's much better and the Devs have obviously looked at what the players thought of the first iteration. The graphics are much more pleasing and it's a treat to ride around on your vehicles looking at the view. Track laying is improved, but familiar. Trucks work better and the stops are improved. Ships are now worth having and bring a lot more to the game. Aircraft need a lot more work and really seem like an afterthought. Stations of all types can now be customised and improved, with the exception of airports. This is a real weakness because as the aircraft get better you need a bigger airport and the only way to do that is to demolish the old one and rebuild. This is difficult because they take up so much room, it really isn't worth using planes until the airport upgrades to large. My favourite terrain is the new tropical islands as it's beautiful - but airports don't fit very well.
It's very addictive, great value for money (especially with the TF1 owner discount) and it sets a new standard for this genre, It just needs some updating (or Modding!) to iron out the faults.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Good game, nice details. Tutorial could be better. Some train mechanics don't make any sense too, I could have a stations that's 10 tiles long but still couldn't fit 2 tiny trains on them, they just refuse so I have to make a parallel, wtf? Having 2 trains use the same route is a pain in the ass as well. 

Production is also very confusing and not explained well in the tutorial.
I think you're better off watching some let's plays or something. Some things also just don't work the way you'd expect it to work without any explanation, for instance, when a train collects let's say silver ore from a quarry, the whole station could be filled with it, but the train would only take 9/32, don't make any sense, I had this happen with trucks as well. EDIT: also found out if let's say a truck station has 2 lines collecting a product from it, it will just fill up the line 1 side to the point it literally throws away excess product, while line 2 is not getting anything..

Wish this game had a bit more of the Sid Meiers mechanics. Looking past all that, it scratches my Sid Meier's itch well enough still.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I do like the game. But it lacks in a few key areas. Random crashes aside, the game could use a lot more industry, with more complex chains. Some of this can be fixed with mods, however, random crashes seem to get worse with mods. Disasters could make things interesting. Some sort of exploration, hidden raw resources maybe. The biggest thing in my opinion would be an opponent(s) to compete against. Other companies to crush and buy out. MP mode would fit right in with that 
All in all, I do enjoy my time with the game. If it didn't decide when it was time for me to quit with a random crash here and there, or gave me some kind of competition, it would have been a thumbs up from me.

review: Maddening and frustrating are the only words to describe this.  I have to wonder if all the other glowing reviews are from the beta testers who already have thousands of hours on this game.  It is not intuitive in any way.  The lack of any kind of manual or after sale support means you have to put in hours of play just to figure out the simplest of functions.  This much effort just to try to get near fun is just tedious and irritating.  I bought this game to have some fun.  I already have a day job to be irritated and frustrated but at least they pay me for that.  Until they make some kind of effort to produce a pdf manual, I would suggest staying away from this game unless you like working this hard to be entertained.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is a nice improvement over Transport Fever in a number of ways. Graphics are fantastic, models and mod support are wonderful too. My performance has been generally solid with one crash total, so take that into consideration. I am playing with Windows 10 using an NVidia GTX1050 on an ASUS VivoBook.

Mechanically there is one irritation I have and it's the "emissions" mechanic along with the aging. Automatic replacement of vehicles was my friend; the vehicle maintenance system is requiring a lot more attention and care; when I am in endgame or at least close to it I just want to have more fun playing with the systems and such. It becomes a tedious task to continually replace vehicles or adjust the maintenance whenever.
 But it's only a minor mechanical nitpick to the style of play I have; not enough to prevent me from recommending this game. It is definitely a lot harder than Transport Fever, and the campaign play in TF was already ludicrously difficult. You'll find that this emissions/maintenance mechanic is going to be really annoying if you use trains early on.

All in all it's a very good time.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Well, I've been waiting for this version for what seemed like forever. I'm happy to say that I was not disappointed. It still reigns as my favorite building/management/tycoon type of game. Limited only by ones imagination, and love for creating or managing things that keep me glued to games like this. The things you do [i](or don't do),[/i] as you watch your small town develop, and grow, is a reward I can't put into words.

That's not to say that it doesn't have a few annoying bugs, but I expect them to be sorted out in a reasonable amount of time. For now, I tend to look past that, or find work-around's, like I do with any recently launched games. The Dev's may not respond much on Steam, but they do read complaints as you can see when they post a patch/update.

The graphics got a notch or two better, and more detailed. The mechanics have improved, while some seems ripe for a fix or two. Still, it's an addictive game, and I expect to get many hours of enjoyment that I did with the other two version.

It's certainly worthy of a try.

The campaign/tutorial is easy but can be annoying at times. In one mission, you're supposed to harvest some plants, but the tool you needed to engage was certainly not something that readily came to mind when you think of harvesting. There were also modern airport sounds in a 1900 airfield.  While the campaign missions can be off-putting, the underlying 'builder-transport' engine seems solid and I'm giving this a yes simply because I think I will be putting in a lot of hours in it. title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I think this is the first time, when I really had mixed feelings about a game. I played quite a bit with TF1 and I was waiting for this game, but after playing the game for a couple of hours I am not even sure if I can recommend it over TF1.
The things that are value in TF2 are
- map preview
- modular stations
- easier to build cross connections in front of the stations
- easier to manage/clone/upgrade vehicles
- improved cargo transport rules
Unfortunately this doesn't make it good enough for a 2nd version of the game, but these are clear improvements.
Clearly they put a lot of effort into graphics so probably you can spend a lot of time beautifying the map, but after setting up a couple of good profitable line there is no real challenge anymore.

Couple of things that I'd expect to improved in a 3.0
- more balanced play. It is really difficult to start to set up lines as they are really expensive in the early years, but later the money just flows and you can't spend it.
- things that shouldn't make sense are generating a huge profit (e.g. transfer raw material using plane is not a reasonable choice, but generating more profit than a similar train line) Probably the transport price should be changed as you don't need to look for the reasonable option. e.g if the factory would pay a certain amount of money for the materials, then you may not want to use plane instead of train.
- city traffic is pretty dumb for both passengers and cargo. It is difficult to get it right due the scaling of the maps, but a marriage between Cities in motion and TF would be the happiest relationship ever. As it is now it is a couple of stops here and there and create a loop. 
- kind of pointless to use small cargo trucks later in the game as money is not a problem and their emission is not that much different
- very simplistic production path. in fact I am not sure if any recent game has such a minimalist and simple production path. I really expected more on this front. e.g. cities could produce things and not only consume.
- cities not accepting certain resources is a change, but personally I dislike it. Again in real life all cities needs food, fuel and so on. I prefer simulation closer to the real life.

I think most of these were similar in TF1, so no big surprises here, but the moment when I asked the 'what's next?' question, when I've received the badge because I provided all the resources to all cities. I've checked the industries and most of the things were maxed out. Sure I can tweak things here and there, but I didn't have the same feeling with TF1 and that's why I will get back to that at some point.

As a summary; if you liked TF1 you wanna play this too, but for me this is just a new major release (e.g. TF 1.1) and I am happy that I didn't pay the full price. I'd feel being ripped off. It is not a bad game, but I can't recommend paying full price especially if you have TF1.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you have not played TF1, get this one instead as it is the pinnacle of the series so far and is a great management game in its own right. If, however, you've already played the first game and you're looking for a proper sequel that builds on its predecessor's already great foundations...this is not it. As others have stated, this is a small graphics and UI update as well as a small content addition (new map type, better map creation, some extra vehicles, etc.). TF2 is basically the exact same game as TF1 and is in no way worthy of a $40 standalone product in my opinion. This should have been a small DLC at the MOST. 

It's a great standalone management title, not worthy of the steep price tag if you've already sunk your teeth into the original.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The predecessor Transport Fever is one of may favcorite games. I ve spent a lot of time with what I call tranportation meditation optimizing and tweaking my transportation network while listening to audiobooks or music.

As I'm linux only and was allways very pleased with the great Linux support i instantly preordered Transport Fever 2. And I'm not disappointed. The game runs really good natively on my Linux rig.

To the game itself:
Transport Fever 2 is more of an evolution as a revolution. It improves an allready very good game in many areas of gameplay. So far the most obvious and notricable improvements for me are:
- new scenario/theming: Asia (vehicles) and tropical (landscape)
- terraforming of water, e.g. rivers/seas (Damn, i really wantred to have this in TF 1)
- set specific filters for goods for a line, e.g. only load/unload a specific resource or even none - again somehting i always wanted to have

However the most epic new feature for me is the modular expansion system for all kind of satations which is way more flexible than before.

There are for sure more improvements I did not mentioned - Urban Games overhauled most areas of the gameplay. Which brings me to a downside: I do not like the new UI design. The border frames of info boxes are to big. I'am used to have pined several in parallel from TF1. This is no longer possible - I just can't have that many boxes open in paralell as in TF1, Secondly the lines management window (and some others) now sticks to the bottom of the screen and are no longer flexible resizable which makes it less comfortable for me. Another point is, that I personally dislike the style of the new ressource items and orthers. However this is very subjective and no sort blocker for playing the game. Maybe there will be mods altering the style.

The keyword mods is bringing me to the community modding support which is exellent. Just one month after release there are allready more than 1000 downloads in the workshop. Many of the addons there are of exellent quality and really improve the games. There are even mods altering the default gameplay. I really appreciate this openess towards modding. 

Finally there is the update politic of Urban Games from the past not letting the game abandoned just after release and providing improvements and fixes even more than a  year after the releease.

If you are not looking for a serious economy simulaon and enjoy building and managing trransportation networks over time I really recommend this game.
If you are on Linux rhis also a safe buy -at leasdt for me it runs withoutr any issues.

And do not get me started on how Catenary posts are being placed mid-track  at track junctions with trains driving through the posts! I have stopped using Electric Locos and Catenaries because of that!

Also, more difficult getting money in the beginning. Means I won't start games before 1900.

Graphics and visuals appear more appealing and landscaping tools are nicer to use, BUT

Where is the Tree- and Rock-Eraser BRUSH! We need one!

review:
I'm 35 hours in, and I've only reached 1950's in the campaign mode (less than 2/3rd's of the way). I absolutely love this game. I love the strategizing, and looking for optimal routes. I love the touches on real historical turning points in transportation. And sometimes, I love just jumping into 1st person view and watching my routes as they proceed through a city, or across country. I still have a lot of campaign time left and I haven't even touched into Free Play or a randomly generated map (I looked briefly and the controls seemed pretty nice). 
Looking forward to many many more hours on this game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It's really satisfying to watch a virtual person leave his home, hop on a bus to the train station, take the train to the airport, catch a flight to a city on the other side of the map, hop on a tram and go to the shops - all of which you enabled.

This is an extreme example, but captures what I like most about this game. The excitement you feel when a new vehicle becomes available. Helping a factory expand by bringing it the raw materials it needs. Delivering consumer goods to a town. The satisfaction that comes from watching a town grow into a city. Bringing people to where they want to go.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After long awaiting, i finally enjoying this game. I havent yet got intro much of fps lose but even if i will, damn, the game just got released, let devs collect data and release first fixes and patches. 
I absolutely like the modular station construction, UI is nice, tho vehicle upgrade is a bit messy at very first time. 

I absolutely recommend it at this point, and absolutely recommend it later, when devs add's more stuff and do performance and other improvements.

P.S.

Now after enjoying this for bit more, i wanna add some stuff.

First of all, FPS is mostly good, especially compared to TF1, yea, its still a drop of fps at late game, tho game is mostly playable with out problems. At my current 3400+ year date, game starts to lag a bit by it self, while FPS might be high enough, thats probably will be fixed within first patches.

I absolutely love how new building system works, allowing you do things you could only wish at TF1, junctions, crosses and awsome "engineering" now can be done, making really massive and crazy hubs. 
Modular stations are also as i already mentioned - great thing.
Im a bit sad due simplified cargo chain, but that's also might be soon added with mods.

I still absolutely recommending game, if you loved TF1 - you will love this for sure. Be a little patient with some possible bugs and things, as game is just released, let the devs collect some mass-use data from all our differend hardware and do good fixes / patches.

[EDIT]
Okay, now i have over 300 hours played, time to update a bit.

I have reached far to year 4000+ without date-edition and managed to grow absolutely huge cities with crazy junctions, inner/outer commuter lines in capital, and cities spread so wide.

What i was surpriced off is the FPS. It was mostly stable 55-60 and some times in capital center dropping to 22-34 which for me is pretty playable, this is not FstPrsnShtr, so a little fps drop not really disturbs. Still there was a lag caused from insane car amount, which we personally discussed with devs, they managed to re-create issue and this will be fixed within next patch. (Super great developers, rly best i've contacted with).
So basically im still strongly recommend the game, patches are comming, improvements, as always will be implented. Game is absolutely playable at year 4k+, especially if not using >>> time, the lag i mentioned before ISNT happening at > or >> speeds and even in capital core center with huge traffic between main trainstation with 16 platforms, serving 21 train-line and core tram hub with 10+ lines, as well as car traffic. FPS is ~35-40 in core close zoom, 55-60 far zoom.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Speaking to those who are considering after playing TF1:
One way streets, traffic signals, modular mixed (passenger and cargo) stations, core industries always produce max, truck (unloading) stops, and a noticeable graphics improvement are things you can look forward to.
A small performance penalty and the removal of vehicle auto-replacement (and currently $40 retail) is the cost you'll incur.
So the upgrade is mostly benefits, but small ones, so I understand $40 being a bit of a hurdle.

To those who haven't played Transport Fever before:
It's like SimCity, but instead of running the government/utilities, you run the bus and cargo lines to support the cities. Build roads, tram lines, train tracks, harbors, and airports, plan out your lines, purchase the appropriate vehicle(s), and expand your empire or go broke trying!
Definitely recommend 2 over 1. However, if you're leery of the price, go snag TF1 on sale for $5 first then you can make your own informed decision whether 2 is worth it for you or not.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a solid and well presented improvement over Transport Fever in almost every way. The building tools are better, the UI has been redesigned with much more usability and modding potential in mind, the graphics are improved and look great, and performance is better.

My only current negative point is the cargo system has been dumbed down a bit (only 2 types per city) and some strange choices made in the cargo chains (only timber to make tools??) Some cargo types are laso removed form the base game (livestock and furnace slag). It makes freight dynamics a bit mickey-mouse. Thankfully the community has come to the rescue with mods to solve it, but personally the feature should be in the game as standard to make things more challenging if you choose to.

Overall it's solid progress that I am more than happy to have purchased. If you like the first game get this then mod the heck out of it and it'll really reward you.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Great for your Transport Tycoon fix from the 90's!

Pros:
Great game, interface is easy enough to understand and interpret
The progression mid and late game is fantastic.
Fun progression. The first time I bought the Flying Scotsman and saw it flying down the track, double the speed of my other trains, all my signals working perfectly, the money I made from it, it was all very satisfying.
Reordering bus routes and installing bus lanes, updating buses to move people quicker, making unprofitable routes profitable again, all great work.

Cons:
The way the game distributes resources between lines from, say, a refinery, is very poor and requires some fleshing out. For example, I have a problem with loading speed from an oil well to a refinery. So I create 2 identical lines with 2 identical routes so I can load trucks on 2 terminals simultaneously. The game then continues to fill only one line with Crude or only fills the other with a tiny amount, making it very inefficient even though we all know that the real world is full of simultaneous loading docks, an oil refinery doesn't just load one tanker at a time.
Same with passengers, etc and you will be waiting a long time on one line and the other line continues to be overloaded even though they're the same. bloody. thing.
The progression before say 1890 can be a bit dull.
The progression after 2020 should have futuristic trains, planes, boats, buses, etc.
You can't choose to replace a tram with a bus, which is often required, it should be an option with a warning.
The game unlinked a few oil wells from truck depots without any reason when I loaded a save, lost me a fortune and left me scratching my head.
Clickable buttons like Manage Route and Manage Vehicle stop working without any obvious reason.

With all that being said, it's all fixable what they need to work on. It the parts that define what the game are that they got right. I love this game. I want it to expand and grow and I'd love to see more game modes or extra parts to it for me to enjoy.

I recommend this game to those who have played these types of games before, but I also recommend it to first timers as it is easy enough to have a go at.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Great game, played TF1 and wasn't a big fan and refunded it.  Maybe I didn't give it a fair shake but in TF2, I've invested quite a bit of time in both the campaign and free mode and have been enjoying the heck out of it.  After playing a while, I added 2 mods recently that, to me, make the game even more enjoyable.  I keep playing and replaying the same maps in Free Mode to figure out the optimal network.  It's a great way to exercise my mild OCD but can also get very difficult if you're constantly optimizing without bringing in enough income.  

Lastly, if you're just trying out this franchise for the first time, it can be very overwhelming and difficult to really understand all the intricacies so I highly recommend checking out some of the tutorials and play throughs on YouTube, Stealth17 Gaming has been my favorite to watch so far and I've learned a lot of tips and hints from him.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Having played this game a while now. I can say that I do enjoy it. However I feel that this game is seemingly more of a sidestep than an upgrade. I feel that with the amount of time and mods that have gone into the previous game, there should have been some elements of those modded features placed into this iteration.

For example. As of now, we don’t have a variety of stations to use. Although you can make modular ones, it doesn’t offer much by way of assets to place to make station unique. Curved, Elevated (even directly over roads as well), Open-cut, and underground stations are absent. And that’s just part of the features that I feel should have been native to this game. I’m guessing maybe like before, it will come in the form of a free download/update content. Which I’m not complaining. But to be quite honest, as this is a Small developer, I personally would have paid a little more out of support, if it meant those features in particular were already in game and the modding community could expand off of that, instead of porting over recycled mods.

Aside from that. I hope to see the features that I’ve mentioned above make it into the vanilla game in a later update or expansion. I’d hope from the devs or skilled content creations from the community that some more American based content in the form or trains especially, like commuter equipment as that was very small in number with the last product. Something preferably from the northeast region of the US, which has a huge variety of equipment in comparison to the rest of the country. For example: Long Island Railroad, Metro North, New Jersey Transit, to name a few and some American Subway/Metro cars.

So, I’m asking, please to either the devs or skilled modders/content creators to please look into expanding on those for this game. Otherwise this is still a great game to pickup. And hope to see the potential realized for this game come to light.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I found the scenarios enjoyable to play in this game and that is where I spent a majority of my hours.  That is the only reason I give it a slightly recommend.  And I don't expect I will play it much now that the scenarios are finished.

Improvements from Transport Fever:
1. The visuals seem to be upgraded quite a bit
2. The scenarios were interesting (although some of them were perhaps a bit too easy)

Fatal Flaws:
1. The vehicle replacement breaks the game for me.   I can't work on something new to expand my transport network because I have to spend so much effort replacing aging vehicles.  This was automated in Transport Fever 1.  Now it's manual.  And it's SO TEDIOUS!  But if you don't do it,you go from making millions to losing millions seemingly overnight.

2. The auto-growth of cities keeps breaking my transport stations by disconnecting them from the roadway!  I'm building a rail line or something and then before I know it, my entire transport network has collapsed and I'm 20 million in debt because a key cargo station is no longer connected to the road!  

It's exhausting how much ongoing care and feeding a city needs just to remain stable.  It really kills the fun of the game.  I have been building and improving  the same city in Cities:Skylines for hundreds of hours, but I can't do that in Transport Fever 2.  After 4 or 5 hours, the transport system is such a maintenance nightmare that there is no time to build anything onto it!  I am too busy replacing vehicles and repairing broken stations.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I must say I am disappointed about this game. 
Basically this is just a slight evolution of original RF/TF game. There are lack of usefull game upgrades and mods. A lot of mods should already have been ported to the vanilla game. Game mechanics is very similar and somehow limiting the game (such as fixed amount people in cities based on the original city size), free games are not fun to play if you have played previous versions. The only fun thing is the new campaign, however it is rather easy to finish (usually economics play no role) and bonus mission often does not give a common sense). 
For me it is not enough upgrade for 30-40€ game. Should have been DLC of TF1 with some campaing while the game receives some neccessary upgrades/patches.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Sadly I have to echo the comments of other players in that a great game (Transport Fever original) has been been graphically enhanced but the gameplay has been made too easy. Trains with mixed manifests no longer have individually configurable wagons, fully loaded open wagons sometimes appear empty, trains cannot be reconfigured in depots (only replacement of an entire train is possible) and costs for tracks, roads and associated assets are astronomical. There are numerous other issues which anyone can see in the forums. Hopefully the developers will rectify the issues over time. Buy on sale if you are a TF fan.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I hesitated to buy this as nothing much seems changed compared to the previous version. However, the developers did a very good job improving so many details and at the same time got rid of a lot of annoyances. Unexpectedly this is even much more fun than before!

One BIG annoyance which didn't get improved: 
The game is WAY too easy even in hard mode.
After a hard start, I have 5 trillionsbillions of money, so I don't need to care at all anymore.
Share the same train tracks to save money for building and maintainance and figure out a sophisticated plan to make it all work? 
- Nah, just build a whole new tunnel across the whole map because why not.

Of course self-motivation and setting your own goals is nice, but IMHO the game looses a LOT of potential for longterm fun by not giving the player more challenges, or detailed difficulty settings.

This game does everything better than its predecessor. To some hardcore fansmodded TF1 might feel like TF 1.5, because it's basically the same game with loads of quality-of-life-improvements. I personally only played TF1 for about 10 hours and switched to TF2 after that. 
Only two downsides; custom names for cities/industries don't save reliably, but I hope they ll fix this in a future update. Also, if you like to play with ANY mod (that can be only a custom train for example) you won't unlock achievements.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: More like an incremental refinement of Transport Fever (and Train Fever before it) than a whole new game, but still very fun. If you don't own any in the series, this is absolutely the one to get, don't even consider the older games. For people who own the original - is it worth it? That depends. For me, yes - I sunk many hours into the first two games and the refinements in TF2 make it sleeker and more playable than ever. But, because this is the same game and engine, all of the things you love and hate about TF1 still apply: construction can be unwieldy, performance issues abound. The pros outweigh the cons and I definitely think this is the best modern take on Transport Tycoon to date, though not a perfect execution. For true fans of this fairly niche genre, I give it a solid BUY.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So I bit the bullet and brought TF2. I have Train Fever and Transport Fever 1 - Logged 428 Hours on TF1. 

I WOULD recommend this game to BRAND NEW players, but for people coming from TF1 you will be surprised to see the return of a bug from the previous game, where you type a line name and the map goes into none stop moving mode, only way to stop the map moving is to mash the WASD keys, so that tells me they have either used the engine from the previous game or they have brought over several of the old bugs into an slightly upgraded one. 

Game looks nicer than TF2 and the interface is better but that is about it. Moving from TF1 to TF2 you are paying £20+ for a slightly improved visual experience, and 90% of the same game as TF1.

I had a feeling the improvements would be marginal from this developer, the same thing happened going from Train Fever to Transport Fever 1 – same assets and engine used just some extra things thrown in a mod could do for free. 

I think when TF3 comes out next year with a tree that moves in the wind but everything else is the same just in a nicer looking environment I might give it a miss. 

Don’t get me wrong I like TF games, I wouldn’t spend 428 hours on them if I didn’t but can’t help but feel the developer drops their games way too soon, take an age to fix bugs and performance issues then just moves on expecting playing to drop more money into funding the next one, keeping the cycle of make, marginally fix, replace.

As I brought the game I will keep playing it, but won't be so fast to get the next one.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It is a huge improvement of an already good game.
There are some big improvements like more detailed graphic, better terrain modifier tool, adjustable time speed (you can even stop the time and playing in a certain date forever), modular stations.
And there are many many many welcomed small improvements like rotatable cockpit view, icons display off in cockpit mode, coloring vehicles when a line selected, signals can be preselect as oneway before placing them, clone vehicles from vehicle view, modify tool for trains, roads can be connected to industrial buildings from any sides, resource flow view, big resource icon at stations instead of many small ones (you won't see 30 icons for 300 goods), when you demolish anything you built the terran is reverting back to its original... and many many other minor things which cause a huge confortable feeling together.
There were the improvements, look at some changes. But before, let me make a little difference between impovements and changes. Improvements are obviusly make a game better, however changes might be argued.  
There is a change in the game for increasing challenging level: only two resources are demanded by cities. Maybe that wouldn't be the only solution for increasing challenging level, but I think it's still better than it was and probable there already are mods for those who doesn't like it.
Maintenance system changed: vehicles cause pollution wich increases with age and negatively affects town growth. With this change you have more options to handle vehicle aging. Oh, btw. town grow I forgat to mention it...
I think I wrote enought to express my opinion about the game even it is based on comparing to the previuos version which I also loved.
One more appreciation for the developer team who really cares about the game and the gamers and works on patches with bugfixes and further improvements eg. the train edit tool come with a patch shortly after the release, because many people wanted.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It's micro-managing on a country scale, a perfect simulation for some of my old bosses!

This is another game that needs a mid-range grade scale, but since I must vote Yes or No then I'm tilting towards the yes side.  While this simulation has some excellent graphics and tools/filters to work with, it also comes with a few rather annoying issues.  That fan-boys have already been on my case touting that 99% of these bug reports are user errors who don't understand the game, and I would agree that the game is complex enough it's easy to not understand that it's you not developing your routes according to the game mechanics.  However, the issues I have found are just down right annoying and suck so much joy out of the development you've spent hours setting up and nurturing.  I find myself just getting frustrated and walking away more times than I'd prefer, but I do keep coming back to try again.

A minor issue I have is with the automatic handling of routes, it's both a blessing and a curse.  If I want to move a bus station and delete one on a current route and build a new-one nearby within a short time, then the route will self-repair the old stop with the new stop, very nice.  However, if I drop in a new cargo station that happens to be nearby to a bus stop then the bus route detaches from that stop and connects to the cargo stop and then gives me a route error, which I now have to figure out how to fix.  If you're still new to the game, this can get quite annoying trying to figure out why your perfectly running route is now all flubbed up.

Another real PITA is factory and route setups, sometimes you just can't get the factory to process correctly, I find this happens most often if you develop a couple of new factory runs while the game is paused.  Trucks will show up and not pickup the cargo or the cargo delivered won't produce the phase of materials.  But if I click on the delivery vehicle while it's pulling up to the station then all of a sudden it starts to work.  This takes the micro-managing to a new level of annoying.

And finally, routes have a hard time letting go of an old route if the current one gets interrupted with a break in the route.  I've had a back/forth route through a city where the deliver routes clearly favored the path to the "right", and basically had a big doughnut hole route through a city.  I demolished a short strip of road to force a stop to one of those sides through the city as it was a tad longer and less efficient, but the route now reports and error with no way to clear it.  Deleting the route and re-creating it still bore the same error despite having a successful line developed between the points.  I suspect the issue is that the road was a program developed road and not a user developed road, so the route manager is expecting the road to be and refuses to work until it's back.

Overall, it still can be fun to play especially if you like getting your fingers into every niche and cranny of a transportation business.  If you're not into micro-managing or problem solving, then this one might not be for you.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
-Summary-
TF 2 is a major improvement on the old game, but there are some things that need attention for the game to be great.

-What's new-
TF 2 is basically a reconstruction of the first game, taking the strong points of what was a bit of a rough production and bringing it a lot further along the line from love of labour modding to a properly designed and implemented game. There is significant expansion on the earlier one, including improved graphics, town operation, vehicles and other things. If you've played the first game, you will almost certainly think this is a step up.

- The Rub -
Like the other TF 2 game, much of what made the original good was the work of modders in the workshop. This ranged from new vehicles to buildings and mods that took the game from normal to good. Likewise, the original game also received some big improvements overtime by the original developers. It's going to take a while for the workshop to upload content to catch up to where it was before, the game needs some important performance updates to make the game more powerful, and to get some features to work. Many have noted that some features can't work at the moment without tanking even high level computers. Likewise, adding some content that was in the original game that hasn't made it into the new one would also be good (such as bridge choices and the like). It'll take most of 2020 for the game to wear in, but with a few changes under the hood, the game will go from good to great.

Buy it, but be prepared to wait for a few things.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I have played Transport Fever 2 for a few days and I have noticed a lot of changes compared to Transport Fever 1. I would recommend this game to people who enjoy creating, managing a transport empire and those who love to see the free play that is present in the game. [b] One thing that really like about Transport Fever 2 is the improved graphics, simulation, and realism. It really sets the boundary between Transport Fever 1 & 2, along side you see the developmental evolution [/b]. Before the game was officially released to the public, I did some research and watched a few tutorial videos on the new game mechanics so I would know what do when the game was released. One thing that I noticed instantly was the [b] line color choice [/b]. I found it very odd and disappointing with the few color choices given as I like to very organized with my line management. Although I found mod that adds additional colors to choose from, I strongly feel that It should be in the game by default, or allow custom colors to be made. Other than that, the game is amazing and I would recommend this game to other players.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Save often, but I like it

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So I have now completed every mission and all bonuses. The Shanghai Bonus for the tower was a pain in the a-s-s. The entire scenario basically was. Both options, trains and aircraft lose money. The maintenance costs override the ticket income.
There are some major tips to compete each mission.
Try to stick with what the mission asks you to do, but do it your way. Some suggestions is to only use unprofitable lines only if the mission requires it. Then as soon as you complete it, delete the line to save money if you feel it will no longer be needed. Sometimes you may get a "big brain time" moment to figure out ways to exploit missions to complete them that doesn't break the rules. In the last few missions, traffic can become extremely tedious, so avoid connecting cities with roads. Private traffic will take advantage of that and clog up the roads. If this happens, building separated elevated roads for trucks may benefit.

Note to Developer: The game crashes when performing large actions for example placing traffic circles in towns even when buildings have already been demolished.

12-26-19 - Having to reinstall the game after it crashed. The game crashed so hard, it actually uninstalled itself.
The previous day I was doing a free mode trains only and at one point, the music stopped and  got me panicking because I hadn't saved in a while. When I clicked to go save the game, it did nothing as if it was doing some do not interrupt background processes and felt threatened to become multitasking as Steam games do not like to multitask. Sure enough, the game just completely closed. I decided to play something else to cool my frustration and when I went to load up the next day, I noticed it was greyed out on my list of games.

-The game looks beautiful, but the missions have a few annoying quirks.
-The vehicles often have an extremely difficult issue to understand what you want them to do and will constantly go to places that they do not need to go to for example going to an unload station first. It is useful for busses only as it helps to spread out the line initially.
-It is common to see a vehicle with a full load or after unloading, sit and wait at a station despite being told they can leave.
-The missions don't specify exactly what it wants done, so you basically have to waste a lot of time and money through trial and error to figure out what to do. I see why you start with so much money for each mission. Many of the time, missions can often be completed at a budget loss.
-There are points of some missions where you are not allowed to purchase certain items needed to earn profit, for example, the Swiss mission wants you to build electric trains, but you can only buy it right after being asked, but no longer when at the next task. It is also odd how one of the vehicle descriptions says it was widely used in Switzerland, but it can't be purchased until a specific point, and only one is allowed to be purchased.
-The mission speech will often interrupt, for example, open windows suddenly close. The bonus missions are usually the culprit as they are random events. (This may have been resolved as it has not been as much an inconvenience.)
-The unique music for the missions is a nice touch and adds to the ambience, but it becomes very repetitive when tasks become longer than expected as it plays the same track until the next task even after changing the track.
-It is nice to see many different ways to check the lines, vehicles, and budget, but it can sometimes be frustrating to go through so many windows just to see exactly what you want to see.
-Some of the achievements are not displaying. Do some only apply during campaigns and some in free mode? (yes. I have gotten the achievements in Free Mode for doing the same things I did in the campaign.) There are many things that are not clear and is the most common issue is not knowing exactly what the game wants to be done.
-I'm glad to see an option to turn off autosave now. Always remember to save in case the game closes for no reason, however, I assume it's mostly a Steam issue, as many other games sometimes close without warning.
-The help menu could be expanded to show exactly what the tools do. I am still not 100% sure what exactly signals do. I have had some trains blow right through signals even with another train in the way.
-I would love to see left hand traffic as an option in the future. The Shinkansen mission has been the most intriguing. I felt it was the only thing missing when compared to when I lived in Japan.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you liked Transport Fever, you'll like this. It's Transport Fever if they had money while developing it. UI looks much nicer, more map customisation and of course, the graphics are leagues ahead. AI is cleaner too.

I read some reviews where people panned it as simplified because you don't need to provide 6 resources to each town now; it's only 2. I disagree - it's actually harder this way. You can't just see a town's near a quarry and a brick pit and think 'sweet, easy money!', because that town might only want bread and machinery. You might start developing a handful of towns and have to fly the bricks in, because the locals don't want them.

Horse models are still PS1 era though :)

P.S. 8 hours, no bugs, no crashes.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Overall Great game, Would recommend to anyone who likes transportation management games.

Things to be aware of:
- Difficult to remove tracks, roads, and items. There is no mass destroy or destroy from point to point. Be careful when placing tracks, it's a pain to fix things.
- The UI is not super informative. It gives information but doesn't explain the info very well in a lot of places. I'm sure playing the campaign would explain things better, but jumping strait in takes some learning.
- Building roads in grids is very difficult. The game has a lot of issues similar to cities skylines without the mods to help alleviate the issues. If you are a perfectionist with your city construction you will likely get frustrated.

Current Pet Peeves:
- Sometimes editing a line will un-select the line from the line editing menu.
- Sometimes upgrading a vehicle will delete the vehicle from the line instead (Perhaps when a depot is not available to that line?)

Feature Wishes:
- Ability to place many tracks / roads side by side at the same time.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It has got a bit better since launch, but still not up to speed:

-the game is vervy poor optimzed. they try to hide that with forcing V-sync/half to on.
- one cpu is peaking at 100%M while others are 'idling' at 25%. In (almost) 2020 with cpu count of 8 and higher is this big BULLSHIT.
- building custom harbors or stations is very heavy on the resources. the limit of 16gb ram is often reached.
- Sound effects of trains are stopping to work when changing maintenance settings
- It looks like the production lines are more simplyfied than in TF1. It feels to easy.
- The balancing on medium and hard are not good: in the beginning you have almost no money and in the endgame it feels like sandbox.
- vehicles are not need to be replaced anymore after there lifespan. They have a lifespan, but you can use them forever by simply do high maintenance for a few year when the statusses are getting bad.


The game should be a very fun game to play, but it is VERY BAD made.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Overall a much more in depth experience than Transport Fever.  While only needing 2 products per city (1 commercial and 1 industrial) instead of all 6 seems simple, running your lines efficiently makes for much faster city growth.  Instead of changing each wagon's cargo type, you can now easily modify your line to carry multiple products so each vehicle that can carry more than 1 cargo can be reconfigured at each stop by the system.
While the addition of the Asian vehicles is nice, there really are no new vehicles for the USA or European settings (outside of mods, but those take time, and I don't know how to make).  In addition, the multiple units are glitched and what is supposed to be a reversed engine on the back of the TGV is instead facing the rest of the train, which looks silly.  You still cannot reverse the stock engines.  There also seems to be a glitch when using multiple engines when you modify or replace a train, you can end up pushing the wagons in front of the engine, despite what you see in your vehicle window.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I don't as a general rule review games but this one has disappointed me so much I feel I have to. It's generally a good game but I honestly couldn't recommend it because it's almost exactly the same game as the original Transport Fever which you can probably pick up with a decent discount.

The good... it's Transport fever, the graphics have been improved, the stations are configurable and can be mixed, the maps feel a bit larger. The campaign is generally well done but a bit easy, there are a few frustrating bits where it's no clear what you're supposed to do to complete the challenge.

The bad... all of the user interface awkwardness that was in Transport Fever is still there, you'll be getting a serious index finger workout from the amount of clicking you'll be doing. There's a complete lack of information about what things do. Cities still only take two resources, can't grow very large and it's not really clear how they grow. Transport within cities is still a mess. There's almost nothing new in the game, just buy Transport Fever. Did I mention there's a lack of information and you'll be doing a lot of clicking. There are weird issues in the interface, I just somehow managed to assign all my vehicles to a single tram line. The game crashes occasionally.

In summary, if you own Transport Fever then don't bother with this disappointing cash grab. If you don't own TF then this is probably worth getting if you enjoy resource distribution type games.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I bought this game as I thought I'd enjoy it as much as the first. Frankly, I think I would enjoy it, but I can't play it due to the game demanding so much from my computer. I don't have a bad PC by any means and it's crashing after creating medium sized maps. I can play TF1 on max settings with the largest maps and be perfectly fine at 60+ fps. The tutorials will load just fine (due to the small amount of assets on screen I'm guessing), but when I load a sandbox game, it will take a good 5 minutes to load the map. It will then take another 2 or so minutes to do a "first time compression" on the map. Once it loads, it will be very slow which is normal when first loading large maps. However, it does not stop being slow and my memory utilization shoots up to around 90% with only Spotify and Discord running in the background.

In short, this game is too broken for me to play. There are a lot of interesting features and new mechanics in this game that're worth checking out, but if you can't play the game then what's the point?

review: I have been looking forward to this and it was as good as expected.  The change in game play to have specific needs for the city was something I was not sure about but it works well and is quite a challenge.  There are some annoyances (no option to upgrade tracks - delete and relay each section - time consuming and very frustrating, and a processing plant maxing out at 400 which is not enough to fully supply 2 1920's sized cities of 600 citizens) but I am sure either the devs or the modders will fix this shortly.  Loving the module builds, the detail of both the maps and the assets, the increased control on roads and the flexibility available with the inbuild sandbox mod.  I can see this being a major time sink!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Given that I've played 17 hours in the last 4 days, I think I can say I really enjoy this game. I think the game has improved significantly from transport fever (1) and train fever. The interface is different and may need some getting used to but the economics and growth of the towns/cities in the game make a lot more sense and they force you to develop freight lines. This aspect has got me hooked on, and I am always thinking as to how I can expand my network. I also really enjoy the addition of the tropical map and Asian vehicle set as well to further increase the variety of the game.
On the other hand, I think they could have added more vehicles overall (especially for the EU/US vehicle sets although I don't know what to add or change).

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TpF2 improves on the formula in almost every way, with a lot of changes that seem intuitive at first but are a lot deeper than I first thought. One steady theme of Urban Games has been their gameplay that doesn't fit conventional expectations, and this is true for TpF2. Population growth is a lot more rewarding, passenger trains are potentially a lot more profitable, freight is still tricky but definitely worth the effort. 

At first, I thought it was too easy, even on hard mode. Then as I got fifty years into the game I started to see where mid- and late-game challenges arrived in unexpected ways. So while the start is slow but steady as always, the real challenges arrive as you attempt to fill up more of the map. Really appreciate what has been done here.

And of course finally the UI has improved considerably, with easier access to data, and the much-demanded line and vehicle upgrade improvements. It's incredible to think of the pains we used to go to to update vehicles. It is so easy (albeit slightly buggy) to upgrade all vehicles now, as well as stations! And while there are minor bugs in this area, they're only inconvenient (disappearing cargo, mostly) and none are game-breaking.

So bravo! Easily the best launch of their three games, and based on the track record of improvements over time, I can't wait to see how this looks in a year or two. It's well worth buying now, and no doubt I'll hit 1000 hours in the game before Urban Games' next big thing arrives.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is a fun, dynamic, and challenging game that has kept me glued for the best part of a week. Only stopping to go to the bathroom and sleep. The 88 hours I have are on a single map that I designed to my first. I love the map builder. It grants the player some pretty good options to help themselves change the map and create their own level of challenge. 

I only ever watched the first Transport Fever from the likes of Colonel Failure, so I learned much of the basics of playing from there. I pretty much jumped straight into Freeplay because of this prior knowledge. This was both a good thing and a detriment due to the changes to the cargo system and building system implemented in the game. However, the changes made cargo easier to get going and scale, plus it is much more predictable than from what I experienced from watching the first game.  I love how they fixed airplanes, allowing them to connect towns. I would say that there is a bit of an issue with how the planes queue. Airports can only get so big before you have planes doing missed approaches and go-arounds for no apparent reason. I which there was an ability to control the traffic in this regard maybe spacing limits or approach paths. Since planes will run into mountains, which kinda breaks the immersion. 

I have run into some bugs, such as screen flickering and the occasional crash, but I am sure these will be patched out over time. Overall, I think Transport Fever 2 is a great upgrade from the first, offering great replayability and diversity. I would recommend this game to anyone looking to build and create something rather than playing the typical shooting and destruction game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game has potential, but it seems like it was released too early.  There are several bugs that have caused me to have to restart worlds from scratch.  The building tools feel clunky and are not well thought out.  The game looks beautiful, and its memorizing to ride a train in cab and look around, but the framerate is terrible on even the best computers as I verified from my own playthroughs and other folks in the community.  The game tries to embrace the idea of building small, then upgrading, replacing, and expanding with a growing economy, but everytime I try to modify or upgrade a station, a line, or a vehicle, I run into unnecessary difficulty and bugs that seem to drain my finances, because you can't get a refund if the building tools places something wrong or doesn't connect something right.  

I'll try the game again in 12 months or after a few patches to see if it gets better, but I would advise holding off paying over $20 on this game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A welcome improvement of the previous game. The solo missions are more diversified and the tone of the narrators is still as perfect as before.

Compared to the previous game, it is basically a mere, yet much needed improvement. The game pace is a bit faster thanks to the fact that the industries start to produce as soon as there's a line connected to them (in the previous game, it was necessary to wait a few in-game weeks before the industry would start producing). The interface is much improved, especially with the grayscale layout on the map when showing certain information like lines, building types, etc. Also feedbacks are better, which make it easier to understand what and why something is happening (like, for instance, the storage facility figures turning blue at some point with a tooltip explaining that it means that it has reached maximum capacity and is starting to lose goods). But the must is maybe the possibility to tweak your buildings; it is possible to increase the storage capacity, to customize your train station and, most of all, to mix cargo and passenger in the train station.

There are still some graphics performance issues, the same as in the first game: slowdowns when editing long train lines. It is still playable, but you can feel the frame rate drops. And there are still some bugs though, but it is forgivable considering the game is from a small studio and these bugs are not very problematic. For instance, there is a bug when replacing a vehicle for instance, you just need to be careful to click on the new vehicle or the selected vehaicle will be deleted. While no bug is ever welcome, the ones I encountered didn't prevent me from having a good time. I simply hope they'll be quick to react and fix them sooner than later.

And last but not least: it works perfectly well on Linux. While the first game didn't work on Wayland, it does now.

It is so simple. You start the company, money flows in. Unless you burn it, there's no other way to spend such amount of money, seriously. You'll lay new roads, tracks, construct bridges, buy air-crafts, trains, buses, trucks or replace them. Even after doing all these things you will have spare money (millions of dollars) with you... It is obviously fun to play for the first few hours, where you hit yourself hard learning the game. After that, it becomes a boring game.

I don't know how you'll feel about it, nor I judge. You may or may not like the game. After all, everyone has their own taste.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The game has a very chill feeling to it. What it does, it does very well, which is the creation of transport networks.  Ultimately, the game is about building transport networks, and less so about being a tycoon. It isn't especially difficult to be successful in the game, but that's not necessarily the point. You'll enjoy this game if you simply enjoy the idea of creating and optimizing the networks.

I think the game could use a bit of balancing to make a bit more challenge. Also, some dynamic elements to the map would be very welcome. For example, adding new industries as time passes.

Overall, though the UI is very smooth (much improved from TpF1). It is very rare that I'm not able to do what I intend. There are some learning curve elements. For example, at first glance, you might be inclined to think this game follows a "build it and they will come" economic model, but this isn't strictly true (although if you improve a town enough you can create a demand simply by sheer numbers). Looking at the destinations tab will give you an idea of where passengers want to go before building a network.

Any challenge in the game is found mainly by making house rules for yourself.

Overall: 8.5 out of 10. With some rebalancing, and some dynamic map elements this game can be an easy 10 out of 10.
