title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have a simple measuring stick to determine if I recommend a game or not, was the time in game worth the money spent.

I spent 44 hours in game so far, and spent <$40 for the game which means I spent slightly less than $1 for each hour of entertainment which means it was worth the money.

I have reached a point where I feel I mastered the game. I can identify and easily profitable trade routes at the start and within a short period of time hit that $100 million point. With that much money you can do anything and anything you make is just going to accelerate your total wealth that much faster. 

These games are never about making stuff look pretty, though I do appreciate it and have posted many screenshots, its more of building efficient systems from a engineering point of view. 

I experienced no bugs. I really have no complaints at all. 

At $40 it is worth buying.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Straight up, this game is not a very good transportation simulator. If you're looking for that, don't buy.
If you want a virtual HO set to make complex routes and interchanges, and like a European setting, go for it.

To delve further into those two points, there is very little on the business side of things here. Even on the hardest difficulty its very easy to amass billions of dollars. There are no competitors. There are no property rights. You don't have to pay for property and you can happily bulldoze a whole city. The price to remove buildings is a little higher, but when you have billions of dollars, who cares? There's no contracts to move anything. The industries and cities sit there silently without requests or demands.
There's no 'station city' concept where you can build retail or hotels or make real estate that you purchased earlier high in value by making an attractive transport center. 
It is very disappointing that it does not even reach the depth of vanilla TTD.

The second point is that all of the assets right now are European despite the marketing information discussing an American and Asian region. The only thing unique are the city names, and the available trains. The buildings, people, and vegetation are the same. The Asian trains are very weak as well, with only Russian trains and a couple Chinese trains thrown in. There's some shinkansen, but it feels very weird to use them when all the local trains are Russian, on a desert mesa map out of Arizona.

I could imagine later on there will be DLC to add trains, but its really hard to see future DLC coming to fix the transport sim side of the game.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review: excellent game

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Tldr: Pretty decent game.

Nice graphics with quite good detail, which gives you the feeling of emersion into a life-like simulation. Like passengers sitting on the train carriage, talking, having a meal. People look and walk like people, horses walk like horses, and car and train detail is just amazing. It's beautiful, and non-surprisingly you see the "train ride" videos on YouTube so nice it is. The water looks amazing, terrain is very detailed with ability to change every aspect and it is respond to every action, like placing a road, or raising a hill.

The goal of the game is to build and optimise transportation network, and it is pretty fun. You have variety of choices of transportation methods, goods and destinations, and it's a never ending sequence of optimisation and problem solving tasks that reward with profits.
I like the flexibility such as the ability to upgrade/downgrade the fleet, change modes of transportation, plan multi-step routes. And the nice twist of the changing times, that bring the new vehicles and depreciate the old ones.

Overall I've played 40 hours so far and enjoyed every minute of the game. At least, it's worth the money.

The only downside that I can see is that once you get to "billions" era, the game loses the challenge and becomes routine. And at times, even with all the flexibility, it seems linear. Hopefully this will be improved in future updates.

The game has just been released so you do see some people reporting an occasional bug or even a crash but that did not affect my experience. Game crashed once, and the fix was released in a few days. So overall it was (and still is) completely enjoyable experience.

title: Transport Fever 2

I've double checked my PCs specs and it is perfectly capable of running this game. I hope these errors will get corrected swiftly so I will be able to enjoy this game.

So, 1 & 1/2 weeks after release, a stability patch has been released which has made improvements. Still, though, the game will randomly crash after 40 mins to 1 hour.  Changing the autosave to a very frequent time is the only way to ensure you won't lose much in terms of gameplay.

Will not change recommendation.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is the first Transport Fever game I've ever played. So I have no expectations or previous experience to judge the new title up against. This will be a brief review of what I like and dislike about this game with having just over 38 hours in game.

Pros:
- If you like city builders and management you will most likely enjoy this game.
- Trains
- Great graphics
- Realistic timeline (watch the peoples clothes and vehicles evolve over the decades)
- Ability to play your own way, no need to follow a linear path with building up a company if you don't want to
- Very engaging
- Will keep you entertained for many hours at once
- Lots of vehicle detail and even a bit of history.
- You can pick from three different map themes and vehicle regions. (Europe, USA and Asia)

Cons:
- More stuttering than I was expecting when you have a lot going on at once
- Road building is "finicky"
- Small amount of variety in the different industries spread across the map
- Towns/Cities are quite small (performance wise you probably don't want big cities anyway)


In conclusion I would definitely recommend this game. I bought it when it was 10% off and I would definitely say I've got my moneys worth and will continue to enjoy this game for many more hours.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you played Transport Fever 1 and liked it. You will love Transport Fever 2.

They added a lot of improvements and are still improving it more. For example: they added the ability to have the date paused so you can play the game forever in 1850 if you want to. And they just added the ability to have a certain percentage of one type of cargo to be loaded (most common for trains). They also added new content. A new map type in the form of tropical islands and the Asian tech. On top of it, they improved the graphics a lot.

The maps can be customized a lot and there are mods that allow you to play iconic places, such as Japan.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone interested in strategy, puzzle or tycoon games.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I really wanted to like this game, but the lack of gameplay and the level of unpolishedness is just overwhelming. I find a few really good ideas in the game, some of them was in the previous version as well, but the lack of actual gameplay is just hidden by the really slow pace start.

Some PROs:
+ I love the music. This is one of the best part for me in this game. It really fits.
+ The modular station idea is just incredible.
+ The basic idea is good, but it was good back 20 years ago as well, nothing really more than that (sure, cities are growing by the product you transport there, and yes, you can upgrade industries by have more input/output, but nothing really fancy, these are just minor tweaks).

A lot of CONs:
- The lack of actual complexity just screams in your face after a few hours. Even hard mode is way too easy for anybody, who spent more than a couple of hours in any transportation game. On the other hand, easy mode is probably too hard for somebody, who never played this type of game. 
- They try to hide this lack of complexity with really slow-pace bound gameplay, especially in the beginning, and you hit a point in time when you can't even spend your money, you get so much. While in the beginning, sometimes (especially in hard mode), you need to just speedx3, and wait years to get the money you need to build one more stuff. It's just boring, and you can't do anything in that time. Once you have enough money, you are free to do whatever you want. But it is not hard to get to that point, only slow and boring.
- Even the largest map is smaller than we had back 20 years ago in these games. It's just funny how they call a 16*16km map "very large", when we are talking about trains going 200+ km/h, and even plains. What idiot had that idea to limit the game in a 16*16km grid? That's even smaller than a decent city nowadays.
- This small mapsize gets even funnier, when you have a high-end PC, and you still can't do more than 10 fps sometimes, and the autosave freezes your game for 10 seconds, or when you want to build, and you get seconds of stutter and freezes. And tho the game looks decent, it's far from the point it would need too much hardware. The game is insanely underoptimized. They should have not put on the market in its current state.

TLDR: slow, boring and very limited gameplay, lack of any kind of complexity, freezes and stutters all the time even on high-end PC.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
*** Update ***

I'm getting used to the new play after playing for 30 hours.  For those of you wondering why you can't tell the cars what type of goods to get, you do it from the line configuration.  As far as reconfiguring your consist, you can do it on the fly without having to send your train back to the depot.  If you want to add additional cars to your locomotive, send it out, and click on the "reconfigure" icon.  I never really used layers on the old TF (or even knew if it had different layers), but the different layers are very helpful. Missions are challenging, routes are easier to configure, aligning tracks is better.  I definitely recommend.  Oh, and as far as the narrator's accent I mentioned before, he uses that accent throughout the game - I just thought it was a really bad American accent after the first mission.  :)  Transport on!

------

Played the first mission of the game.  First impression is that it's about the same as the previous Transport Fever with a few additional features, such as cockpit view, environment (you can focus in on bears and see birds flying about), showing layers (where the residential, commercial, and industrial areas are) and probably other things that I haven't discovered yet.  Some of the nuisances carried over from the previous version of the game, such as not being able to align the buildings exactly the way you want to, and trains reversing unrealistically at the train stations.  The narrator has an awful American accent, but a bit better than Liam Nieson's.

Is purchasing the new version worth it?  Meh.  I haven't really formulated an opinion yet.  So far, I haven't noticed many changes.  But I'm a fan of the game and the creators who built it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Check most of the negative reviews and they tend to complain about one thing: they dumbed down resource requirements for cities from All end products, to just two per city. Here's the deal. It took less than two weeks for a mod to come out which reverts that change. 

The graphics engine has been upgraded considerably. The game is stunningly beautiful. I've spent a considerable percentage of my play time just watching the onboard camera on vehicles on my lines. 
The campaign is actually very interesting in this iteration and I've enjoyed it quite a bit
The new terrain generation for Arid maps is fantastic looking and the all new Tropical generation manages to create beautiful and realistic island landscapes.
The new line manager, while it took a minute to get used to, is far more robust and feature rich making updates to existing vehicles and lines substantially easier than before.
Modular stations are a literal game changer if you're aesthetics conscious. 
The map editor is very well put together and powerful for authors

I could go on. There's a lot more but I think you get it. If you're skeptical about moving from TPF1 to TPF2 I can tell you with certainty it's worth the update and deserving of a separate release.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So here we are with the latest instalment too the "Fever" franchise.

Now Transport Fever 2 is a game changer from the first 1 (let alone train fever). There is just too many things too list! But! They are all great improvements! Heck you can get a better start on hard mode too!

So going to list a few things off with the game.
* Can slow, fast forward, or out right pause the year so you can stay locked in a era.
* You can upgrade, change out, adjust, all vehicles and aircraft on the fly with a simple ease.
* Can easily adjust what cargo to load, how much of it, and unload with the new waypoint system.
* Interface is much nicer and easier to use.
* Much more micromanaging if you so wish.
* Configure your base station to suit your needs and customize (You can make some wonky / combined stations now).
That is just a few point of what is in store. The only down side is I can not find a way to use my old transport logo from Transport Fever 1 in Transport Fever 2.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The game is a good improvement over the TpF1 in all but one item...

The older game had a feature to automatically replace worn out vehicles when it was time. With this game introducing wear and tear, increasing emissions (noise and air pollution), and functionality it seems to clash with the older game's auto replace. Instead you have a maintenance factor, which could STILL use an auto replace.

There is also the option to place a company HQ although I have yet to see the advantage of this. Does it improve or detract from land values? Does having it in a particular town focus growth in that town or reduce the overhead in that town as HQ is closer to those routes? If so then hub and spoke would make a lot of sense.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Alright, 10 hours of total gameplay time, two days of ownership. What do I have to say about my new game? Well, to start off, a MASSIVE improvement over the old TpF. Sure, I had to upgrade my PC because it is so RAM heavy, but my goodness! was that worth it. 

[b] Map graphics [/b]
First off, the graphics are a surefire improvement over the old game because you finally are not left with either green or yellow-coloured land without features, and the new tropical setting looks sweet. Now with the map generator. Of course, in the old TpF you could pick the geography of your map and the time era with settings such as "Flat", "Large", "1850", etc. In this one, though, you first go to the map generator, and you have a small side screen which shows what the geography of your map will look like, which is pretty darn sweet. The next page is the continental theme and time era setting page, and here you can access your mods by hitting "Custom" and the button right next to it. 

[b] Gameplay [/b]
Now to the gameplay, which is a massive improvement over the old one. I have mostly screwed around with planes initially, and finally I am glad to say that planes aren't broken pieces of shit that nobody will use like they were in TpF1, and to add to that you have cargo variants, which I really like. I was actually also quite surprised by the Sherpa, which can be both used as a passenger and cargo plane - a feature I didn't know about. Heard the Ju 52 has a similar feature, which finally means planes have proper utility. Let's move back in time to the steam era, and what do I have to say? At least, the Ruskie locomotives are good lookers, which says something. (No dissing to you Americans! Just my 2 cents!) But Ruskie locos aside, the new smoke textures look great. They just aren't translucent circles with different colours, but rather actual smoke. This is a graphics improvement on many levels, aiding with immersion and similar. [i]Oh, and God Mode has basically been added as a stock mod included in-game[/i] (don't tell this anyone!). And there's a new emission mechanic in the game, so be sure to keep silent (literally)!

[b] Modular stations [/b]
Now, modular stations. This is probably the biggest addition to the Transport Fever series, as all stations beforehand (and still are now, only when you plonk one in) had to be configured by hitting a button and picking what layout you wanted. I have no problems with this system, however it can be a bit clumsy at times. Still I am surprised that Urban hasn't implemented curved stations as stock yet. Airports probably benefit the most, as you could build a passenger airport and implement a cargo station and vice versa, which in and of itself saves a lot of hassle that comes with building a second separate cargo airport. This feature actually also applies to every other station in-game, although I am not sure about the cargo harbour. You may still need to build a separate cargo harbour to use cargo ships.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Now the campaign is something I haven't tested yet, and I am looking to test it in the near future. But for now, here's a (brief) conclusion. I have downed 1k+ hours into Transport Fever 1 (mostly thanks to mods, they're still a thing here), and now we have Transport Fever 2. This game, from my experience with TpF1, builds and improves on almost everything from the OG game. The only thing now is to implement curved stations into the game, and I am convinced this'll be the Transport Tycoon Deluxe of this age of video games. Solid 9/10, needs slight refinement, but otherwise great game. BTW they written in some good gags into this, and I have a good chuckle at 'em whenever I see em, namely when you hover the cursor over animals, etc.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game is a straight upgrade to the original.  If you enjoyed the first, you will likely enjoy this one.  So far the only real negative I can say about this game is the lack of auto-replacement for vehicles, which is completely baffling and kind of insane.  I suspect this will be fixed sooner than later, since it was in the original game and plenty of people want it back.  

There are plenty of other QoL issues and weirdness here and there, some of which was brought over from the first game, but if those things didn't bug you too much in the first game, then they won't bother you here.  

For new players, if you are new to the genre, then this game is a pretty good introduction to it.  You will most likely need to look up guides since it feels like a lot of the game and its quirks are not really explained well in the game itself. 

Overall, a safe purchase if this sort of thing seems interesting to you.  If you ever catch it on discount, then I would say it is 100% worth it.  At full price, that depends on how much you view the price point as a burden.  If you only prefer to get sure things at the full price, then maybe it might be best to wait for a discount, or see if you can get a better feel for the game before hand.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Good tutorial in Campaign.  Beautiful graphics.  Much better than earlier Fevers.  I'll actually spend some time with this one.

****After spending more time and finishing the campaigns, I now understand that what I had thought to be overly-fussy and clumsy routing controls are actually intentional and are a big part of the game.  Nothing moves between depots unless everything is set up perfectly for both pickup and destination.  For example, my biggest frustration in the campaign was getting the steamers to transport stone across Lake Baikal.  After literally hours of being stumped, I realized that one step in the transport chain, a train, was equipped with cars that worked fine earlier to carry manufactured iron but were unsuitable for coal.  I changed it and it instantly started working.  

If it's not working, keep checking,.

review:
Played for a while now, its definitely an improvement on TF1.
I like the much enhanced opportunities for shipping. The Dunara Castle ship is excellent, and an accurate rendition of the prototype, it has the right look and feel. The pusher tug is useful too. 
The aircraft have improved too, the Bristol Freighter and Hercules are excellent. Air freight is good in small doses, as in the real world. Having made millions transporting stone by airfreight this would be unlikely to happen in real world. 
The modular stations are excellent and the look and feel of it is much improved.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So finally here it is, Transport Fever 2, I was hyped since I heard the message the first time from Tom the community manager from Urban games. Every preview they showed seemed to good to be true and now here it is.

So is it living up to the hype? Is it the revolutionairy sequel to Transport Fever 1?

To answer this question I have to talk about some aspects of the game which are until now kinda unpolished, some even seem rushed and unfinished; but there are also ton of improvements over the first game, so let's see.

The obvious thing is that mods made TF1 great, it was a nice enough game by itself, but the best experience came with shaping the game the way you like with mods from the unresting, talented moding community this franchise has. I'm fascinated by the fact that there are allready this many, allready gamechanging mods for TF2 out there, but as it is, it's only the beginning. TF 2 will ripe like a nice wine over time, as there will be more and more mods available.

[b] Economy: [/b]


a lot of people complain about it. "No new production chains!" "Only 2 recources demanded by cities ! " "Raw material producers are always producing 100% making the game too easy! "So, there is a lot of hate out there. I gave this a lot of thought and came to the conclusion that they actually made a pretty good job. Raw material producers, that are always producing sure make the game less difficult, cities that only demand certain cargo make it harder on the other side.
You have to plan your transport routes all over the map to effeciently get the resources to where they are needed, clever! I found myself often thinking how to make the next steps in my network for a long time, and it made a lot of fun. 
Why no new production chains? I guess they had to keep the game balanced and it's allready a bit crowded with industries. Anyway, there will be plenty of mods for this matter in the future.

There are even some new ways to transport stuff, cargo airplanes and ships that actually work and they look really awesome. Thats a BIG step coming from TF1, and I really apreciate it. Only complain I have here is that cargo capacity of Airport terminals and ship docks is not increasable, meaning, you loose some cargo because of overfilled stations, very frustrating! It's not often a problem if you are using ships, but for airplanes it's kinda redicolous at the moment.

[b] Stations: [/b]


probably the most spectacular anouncement was that there will be modular trainstations. You can now adjust them as you play threw time, making them bigger, smaller, make two platforms for 2 small trains instead of one, or combine cargo and passengerstation in one building. It was really fun experimenting with this feature, but also tedious at times, because "modular" means you have to delete, create every module of the station seperately, if you make adjustments to your network or enter a new time era with new station buildings and platforms you have to spend a lot of time editing your stations. At least upgrading your station to the current era should be a build in feature. 

[b] Vehicle maintenance (emissions): [/b]


This is a big change to Transport Fever 1 as well. Vehicles will age as we know it from TF1 but they will not cost you more money as they age, instead they will have increased emissions. Emissions are a new game mechanic introduced in TF2, more emissions near the residential areas of cities will have a negative impact on city growth.
The automatic replacement feature from TF1 is no more, but instead, we can increase the maintenance cost of vehicles to restore their condition, making replacement obsolete and saving you a lot of work, thanks Urban games. 

"But no increasing costs, isn't it going to be much less difficult that way?" you might think, and yes, it is. After all I allready said about economy and vehicles you can conclude that this game is easy compared to TF1. Is it really that important? That depends on how you play the game. If you want it to be challenging and hardcore you have to depend on the mods, i allready saw some nice ones like "Oil king" and a mod that let's you pay for cargo space.

[b] Changing of timeflow: [/b]


You can now decide how fast time is progressing, that's just awesome. I have only love for this feature and it changed the way i play the game significantly.

[b] City growth and traffic: [/b]

City growth is now completly transparent and gives new opportunities to plan your lanes, you have to keep town needs and emissions in mind and deliver the cargo the city demands, it works great. But I have to say city growth feels kinda "less". They don't get as big anymore.
I'm still unsure about traffic, and that might be because i haven't had a lot of traffic. With my game I'm in year 1986 now, and I'm at 100~ hours in game and I don't really have a lot of traffic on my map. Maybe it will change in the upcoming years or they nerved it, i can remember how crowded my streets became in TF1 on larger maps, holy moly, that was a mess. I never experienced this in TF2, but this can have many reasons, for example that I planned and build my passenger network from 1850 on and build a nice highway connection threw the map. IDK.

[b] Graphics: [/b]

It's not the prettiest game arround, but on the other hand it's a pretty big game with big maps and a lot going on, so you have to balance this out. Obviously it's a big improvement to TF1 and I really like the new style.

[b] My conclusion: [/b]


This are all the major impressions I had so far with this game and I do recommend it. For new players as well, as for TF1 players. As i said, it will take time until this game will have the mod variety of TF1 but it's allready a great game. It's like a raw diamond, and if you wait for a little it will shine.

Thanks in advance to all moders and Urban games for making this possbile, and i hope for lots of new fixes, content and improvements in the upcoming months.

If you, dear reader, are a friend of trains, transportation, managing of cargo chains or you just want to build something beautiful without any challenge, this game is for you. You can adjust so many settings, and download mods as they come. This game is what you want it to be and I'm glad I can experience it, and I'm addicted please save me....

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I was going to skip getting this at first, because the weird placement of resources to industry really irritated me in the first one. Why the heck is that refinery on the other side of the map from the oil? Makes no sense.

Then I got it, played through the first 5 missions, enjoyed, went into the random map generator and just got over my prejudices.

And in all fairness, the first map I'm doing has the resources closer to production facilities so I'm not having to get over it too much.

Now I'm enjoying it! I just have to remember to play it as a game and then it's a plenty good time.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
As a large avid player of Cities in Motion 2 (A game about creating a public transit system), I wanted something new but I felt intimidated by Transport Fever's main feature of... Transporting cargo around. After a few playthroughs, I figured out ways to make public transportation-only runs profitable.

The game runs very well (a few complaints about the initial load time, but minor ones at that), and I like the flexibility of controlling how trains work via rails and switch tracks. (You can tell I primarily play this game and only run train routes).

For any transit enthusiast, I'd recommend this game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Well I have been waiting for a good Transport management Game since Transport manager back in the day.

This is an early review so things may change over time.  First impressions are good and I would at this stage recommend the game provided there are some improvements in the pipeline.

1 Love the graphics 
2 Love the way you can set up most lines without too much of a learning curve

Dont like the fact that there is no apparent competition, which make it less of a game and more of a simple simulation whereas in TM of old you had the pressure on  you to perform.    

Dont like the tutorial style of the Campaign game - this is too juvenile and does not actually show you which buttons to press.    This leads to much repetitive trial and error until you get it right.    Ok this makes it a challenge but the real challenge should be to run the Transport Company efficiently and at a profit and compared with other AI players except it does not (see above).

Still would recommend the game at this stage and hope for more challenge in the future.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Absolutely excellent successor to Transport Fever. 

The 18 mission campaign can get a little long however contains tens of hours of content and the first 6 really give you a good understanding of the game.

Hard mode in Free Play though, even for me with hundreds of hours is simply too difficult, but I like that. It's a real true challenge for experienced players. 

The modular station system is the best improvement to the game along with street cargo drop offs these are true game changers.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Transport Fever 2 is a great sequel to Transport Fever thus far. It very much improves on the last game from the features they showed off to the features that you have to see for yourself (or hear from others). The modding community is also so far very active and, imho, quite high quality for content such as locomotives, assets, and rail track/road replacement/addons. Hard mode is recommended if you want a challenge, but there is also easy and medium if you wish to just relax or even sandbox mode (as a mod) if you wish to flex your creative brain muscles. All in all it is quite an addicting and fun little game, as well as a great addition to the many different transportation tycoon games there is.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: A business and transportation logistics sim where you run a transportation company. You are plopped onto a map with different towns and factories and mines and farms, and it's up to you to move passengers and freight to where they need to be. The campaign was fun (if a bit buggy in parts) and progress you through scenarios of increasing complexity in a satisfying way, and leaves you well-prepared to tackle free mode where you're given a randomly generated map, some money, and the rest is up to you. I enjoyed it a lot. One other noteworthy thing that didn't bother me but feels like it should be mentioned is that there are no adversary companies, just you and the map. All challenges are purely budgetary. I guess if I had one complaint it's that I wish the early tech weren't such a struggle to make money with. The game has tons of different trains and vehicles that change as time passes to more up-to-date versions, and I really like playing with the trains of the 1850s, but their moneymaking limitations mean you often just watch a bunch of train models pass you by until other, more profitable ones make their debut. But overall I enjoyed it a lot.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Visuals, cities are great. 
It still suffers from the same problems plagued by TF1. Correct goods not getting picked up/wrong goods selected and you can't change the goods type in the train's interface window (as you can in OpenTTD).
Constructing train tracks is still a pain in the *ss. You've got to do a million doughnut tracks just because the game finds the terrain to steep for the trains. Yes, I am aware that heavy loaded trains can't go down steep slopes, but this is just ridiculous. A 5 degree slope requires a bridge or a doughnut... 

Too bad. Not Recommended.

review:
I just can't suggest something anything I, myself, couldn't enjoy. Unfortunately for me this is a game that wasn't worth the 32$ USD  I spent on it so I did ask for a refund, but even if it was free it just plain wasnt fun or captivating. 
This game to me didn't/doesn't do anything different than the first TF, don't let the shiny new trailer make you think these graphics are on par with a triple A late 2019 game should be either but games like Prison Architects shows even graphics arent that import, this game TF2 just isnt fun and doesnt do anything new that makes it worth getting into this even on sale for 30, infact I paid less I believe because I owned the first TF on steam.
 Look at my library, I have at least a couple thousand dollars in games, as an adult I  try and support the good honest devs out there,  this isn't a dig at urban games, its just my segway into saying honestly the smartest thing I did but stopped doing was I used torrent games, and if I loved them I would buy them to support the devs and get the latest updates. One day steam isnt going to be so nice and let me return disapointing games  so I may need to do that again some day, but till then Ill buy games and return them, of course ill never say don't ever try it because what I like would be different of course than what you like, but again this isn't a game I see my self suggesting anyone to buy ever until it drops to the 10 usd range when its on sale.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever is a game you sit down to play for a few hours and suddenly the sun has risen.

I thoroughly enjoyed the first iteration of the franchise and I hadn't expected a second iteration so soon after discovering the first game.

If you haven't played the first game it would be worth picking up as it is cheaper and is a solid game in its own right, I would highly recommend picking it up first to enjoy everything the first one has to offer.

If you have played the first Transport Fever or you are a fan of similar games (Factorio is a great comparison for a game that isn't a usual simulation tycoon game) This is a must have.

It looks amazing, and it is well optimised. I had no issues playing on my system and I am running a i7/16GB RAM/GTX 970 rig.

Detail is excellent the vehicle models are lovingly made with insane attention to detail, the scenery is a brilliant backdrop for you to create your transport network.

Other reviews cover the game in excellent detail and I would recommend looking through them or finding a video review, a review for the first Transport Fever would outline the game well and it would carry on to the second, the second is a refreshing update and sticks to the core gameplay values.

I believe there are a few things that need to be added to this game through FREE Updates.

Changing Vehicle colours. The colour selection is lacking and overpowering. The colours that you can change are overpowering.
You should be able to change each wagon/section of the vehicle independently, I don’t want every wagon to be the exact match I want some odd coloured wagons for some realism.

Add a few more resources, I like the selection but just a few more for variety would be great, perhaps add some more by products to make managing everything slightly more difficult.

The modular additions to platforms should allow them to be added as a stop, for example: If I add a cargo bay to my platform, I should be able to set that as a stop on my road vehicle lines.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
(This was my review on 12-18-19) I hate to be "that guy" but I feel very let down by Urban Games. Don't get me wrong, I love the game, my anger stems from not being able to play it. The developers have dropped off the dace of the earth (as of 12-18-19). Imagine it, a cool December day, Transport Fever 2 launches. For three days I was able to play with no problems, but now it is impossible. It began with my large map not loading, then the game started using 13gigs of RAM, then my saves stopped loading, then every 3mins the game would crash, and now, in the winter of my discontent, my saves will not load again. The game is, as it stands, unplayable. Until this problem is fixed, I will not recommend this game.

(As of 12-19-19)
The issues that I had mentioned above have been rectified. The developers have come back to fix the numerous bugs that plagued the system. This game is on its way to becoming one of the best of the year.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review: If you played their previous title you will find far too many similarities... because it is exactly the same game.  Everything about these games plays exactly the same.  There's also a lot of language difficulties in the game that make it intolerable.  You might have a simple objective "Sell 5 Trains."  So you sell five trains.  Nothing happens.  It turns out "Sell 5 Trains" actually means "Sell All But 5 Trains."  You spend a copious amount of time experimenting trying to figure out what the game designers actually mean.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Very good game and far better than the first one. It's a must

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I was at first furious with the game.  Besides the usual release day bugs that we've learned to accept from just about all publishers, some critical game features available in the first Transport Fever were not yet implemented.  One of those missing features was the ability to ratio resources on your trains, the other was editing the carts or locomotives of the trains.

I am changing my review to positive now because now it feels like a complete game that allows me to actually strategize my transport empire just how I want it.

The game also runs better now that they've had a chance to fix some issues so I feel that it's at a good stage to give it a thumbs up.  The workshop it's also already starting to to 'deliver' and one thing that I loved about Transport Fever 1 was that the game was not flooded with paid DLCs like so many other games are doing now. 

Keep up the good work guys, you've earned my change of heart.

title: Transport Fever 2

review:
My advice: Get TF1 instead. TF2 might have better graphics and looks lovely, but the gameplay in TF1 was much more fun and much more captivating. Loved TF1 and have spent hundreds of hours on it, but TF2 is just not doing it for me. Managed to work my way through the campaign up to mission 10, but by now I am so bored I will just drop the game.
Really been looking forward to this game for a long time, and hate to give it a bad review, but with the design decisions Urban Games took they kind of ruined the soul of the game for me.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I enjoyed the original, but some of the new bits and bobs just don't do it.
1) The removal of Unload Only in the line manager for stations causes my truck lines to bunch up at stations for no reason except that the trucks are waiting to be filled, on a line where they're not meant to be filled.
2) The adjustment of production ratios. Normally I would build a line where trucks go from plant to plant to plant etc and finally to town. But now, where one log used to make one plank but now one plank requires two log, means that lines must be separated between source to first plant, and first plant to the rest, thus adding to truck station woes.
3) It's a lot harder to turn a profit in the early years. While this is not inherently bad, extra maintenance costs combined with loan interest can really kill you if you don't start with a profitable line immediately.
4) Freight lines have become less complex. We used to have to connect multiple sources for something as complex as plastic, but now we only need oil. While some of the freight changes are nice, others seem out of place
5) This is one of the big ones. It's incredibly hard to justify to yourself playing this game when you make what seems like a profitable line, just to be whacked out of profit by half of your maintenance costs. Even in the previous game the ratio between maintenance cycles and distance covered by vehicles wasn't great; now it's abysmal.
6) There's not much new. I was hoping to see more variety in freight types and vanilla vehicles, no such luck whatsoever

title: Transport Fever 2
review: An otherwise fun game but rail cargo is badly designed. The message boards are filled with people who are frustrated and don't understand why cargo isn't appearing at their rail stations. It's OK in theory that any one of many factors can prevent cargo from being deposited at your rail station for pickup - complexity can be rewarding! - but there are MANY, MANY reasons that will result in no cargo appearing at your station, and the game provides zero guidance why. I recommend the developers surface more of these so players will understand what they need to do; or simplify the cargo - for example, let cargo appear at a station for pickup, even if all conditions are not met.  --And a design request: building is expensive and hard to guess "right" from the outset. A "Build Mode" where you are not charged for construction until you accept all of the construction would be appreciated. Thanks!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is good, but:

This game is a good start to be a updated, modern successor to 'Transport Tycoon Deluxe'. The graphics and the new station-placementfeatures are absolutely wonderful.
I played OPEN TTD a lot, and recently again. Transport Fever 2 needs a lot of polishing and the most important feature would be a coop multiplayer mode for at least free play. (like the king in its genre: open TTD)


The campaign has its moments but in a few missions there is nothing to do (omg Paris-mission 7), the quest and sidequests are boring, restricting your own playstyle and its way to easy. You simply have to much money and never have to think about earning some... 
And goals like 'deliver 40 tons of oil to a city' is simply bad design; a train with 10 wagons holds like 90 tons of oil... (please increase the amount of wares transported and reduce the profit - it feels wrong in its current state)


Please update and polish this game further, it is just a few grand patches and maybe 1, 2 addons (dlc) away from being a 10 out of 10! Keep up the wonderful work, 
Absolutely recommended for genre-fans! I'm looking forward to the mods in the workshop too :-)

Thanks a lot

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I was a big fan of TF1, and now I am a big fan of TF2. The changes in gameplay are minor, but overall it is a big improvement. There are a few QoL things missing imo.
- Roads do not snap to roads (like rails do) which makes it difficult to make parallel roads; esp. for highways this is a big oversight.
- The ability to zone cities (being able to decide where commercial/industry/residential grow. And being able to define  city-limits.
- The need for workers in industry.
- A third product need (residential) like post/mail or better yet, placable buildings in towns that have a specific need (like a postoffice or a hotel (tourism) or a pub (alcohol).
- I also think that replacing vehicles should involve them going to a depot.

But despite these wishes, I love the game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Unrefined gem.

My perspective: casual OpenTTD player. Skipped previous games from this dev. Focused on gameplay and tycoon side of things (not a train junkie etc.).

Positives:
- Amazing graphics for this type of game (with familiar vehicles from Asia/Russia, America or Europe). You can actually see every passenger in vehicles and every unit of cargo on platforms!
- I like the art-style approach in this game, unlike most modern games. It's a perfect balance between over-saturated slightly "cartoonish" style and grim&dull realistic representation of the world. Just like a modern version of good old TT.
- Amazing passenger agent system where you can track every single person as he travels to/from work or shopping, even between cities etc.
- Cargo supply/demand system similar to Cargodist in OTTD. Here it has very clearly designed mechanics and works very well.
- A lot of the familiar features from TT (though some stuff is simplified-away).
- Finally a full-blown campaign (18 missions, 1-3 hours each) and not *just* a random game.
- Covers the history of transportation from 1850 to 2000 (just the way I've always wanted in OTTD).

Negatives:
- Track/road laying is tedious (a lot of extra clicks, can't automatically follow the terrain elevation).
- A lot of small/medium usability issues with UI (bugs, illogical/inefficient workflows, etc.).
- No vehicle maintenance/breakdowns mechanics from TT. Instead you have an "emissions" mechanic. I liked having to send my vehicles to maintenance on their schedule in TTD, it gives extra challenge etc.
- Primary industries produce always the same amount. You can "upgrade" secondary industries by efficiently supplying them and their consumers, but there's no random element like in TTD where some industries produce better yields etc. which gave some more variety. Having the same amounts of cargo everywhere might be dull.
- Performance issues (objects like trees eat way too much frame time etc.).
- Can't use modifier keys for hotkeys, and you need to use a lot of them!
- Campaign missions are not challenging at all. Most tasks are trivial. Few hard tasks have obvious exploits to easily achieve them not the way the game suggested. Overall it's not that bad and is entertaining for me.

I've only played the campaign so far. Want to finish it before starting a full random game. Might update my review afterwards.

Big fan of the islands maps! Also really enjoy the fact they change what goods the cities demand. Makes the game a little more dynamic. Looking forward to what the Steam Workshop has for this game. title: Transport Fever 2
review:
About 20 hours in and I have a few thoughts on the game. First, so you know where I'm coming from, I have never played the original Transport Fever. I also have no played things like Train Simulator or many other "transport" type games. The closest I get is the old school Sid Meier's games or tycoon games. I've played (and loved) Factorio.

Let's start off with the bad:
The cities are a little underwhelming in size (though they do grow, but I'm not sure yet just how much).
The campaign seems like just a *very* long winded tutorial. I stopped after a few episodes because it felt like extended hand holding that I didn't want to waste time on.
There are times you will think something is broken, but it's not. You just haven't connected your lines up properly (this comes with time, and you will get *very* good at it). 
The game is "too easy" as far as money is concerned. After a couple hours you'll have figured out how to make sure you're always netting positive.

The pros:
The game is beautiful. It's fun to just look around the map at your creations ticking away.
It's a lot of fun. Easy or not, there's something pleasing about hooking up transport lines successfully and watching the money roll in.
There's a variety of transport types. There are three "cultures" from 1850 to modern, so there's a lot of different vehicles to play around with (planes, trains and automobiles). 
The map generator works pretty well (though there is a distinct lack of challenging scenarios).

The other stuff:
There is no "enemy" AI. Do not expect to be competing against an AI. This game is just about connecting logistics around a reasonably good sized map.  
There are no hand crafted scenarios outside of the campaign (which best I can tell is just a really long tutorial). 
The game is pretty "easy" in that once you know what you're doing, it's almost hard to do anything wrong. You will make money doing almost anything as long as there is supply on one side and demand on the other. This could be as seemingly stupid as flying wood across a map to supply a lumber yard and then flying that lumber back across, despite there being a forest and lumber yard directly next to your end destination. 

Overall the game is fun. For the price, it's worth it. I'm 22 hours in and plan on putting in a good few more. That comes out to ~1.6 USD per hour of fulfilling entertainment so far. A relatively reasonable price if you ask me.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The 2nd generation of transport fever is worth the money. 

PROS:
The user interface has been improved a lot, by adopting the modern flatten flavor of icons and aggregating vehicle/line management function in a more user friendly panel and by intuitive instructions in case of any problem with your empire. The developers must have spent tremendous effort in bringing the player such an abundant choice of transport vehicles from all over the world ranging from the steam era to the latest Fuxing EMU train. As a Chinese player i'm really delighted by that.
The graphics have been brought to a extraordinary level, benefiting from exploiting the GPU capability of dynamic lighting, blurring etc. 

CONS:
1. Player can neither select vehicles by age nor select lines by cargo type in the line management panel
2. When editing a specific line, the map still renders paths of other lines.

Overall, I would recommend my friends to purchase this game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: As a seasoned TpF1 player, I have found the new game a great product so far. There are some niggles but that's to be expected so soon after release and I've now enjoyed many stable hours without trouble. Takes some time to adapt to changes in game mechanics and UI from the earlier version but its close enough for the experienced to play by ear, and I now prefer many of the new ways of doing things. I like the new easy clone train/vehicle feature (although there's a bug that creates in a random depot that might be unconnected to the particular line), faster load/save, improved graphics, modular stations and the way stations connect to roadways and industries via 'paths', editor, sandbox mode and climates.

Rather dissapointed.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Transport Fever 2 is an incremental update from the previous version. If version 1 was a vanilla Paradox Interactive game, version 2 is essentially the same game, but with a lot of updates and revisions. And: without having to pay > $ 200 for DLC's.

[b]Two cargo per town[/b]
I think the best change is the switch to a two cargo per town system. Some people have called it a dumb-down, but I see it as a simplification that actually adds more complexity, because you need to think about the actual destination of the products.

[b]Emissions[/b]
Emissions is a new system in which heavy traffic has a negative effect on city growth. On itself it's okay, something about it annoys me, but that actually has to do with something else.

[b]City growth[/b]
What I find really disappointing about TF2 so far is the city's maximum size, and the even more limited size of a lot of towns. I want to have large cities, because I also want to have innercity transportation networks that actually make sense, and I want to have the feeling that my transport networks are really driving development forward.

[b]Lines interface[/b]
There are basically 3 interfaces about lines. The line manager, the vehicle manager, and the lines overview (button on the lower right). I don't see why they didn't merge at least the first two interfaces. Now I find myself constantly switching between these windows for basically doing 1 task.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The graphics are really beautiful.

[b]The El Dorado of TF2[/b]
So what it's all about, especially on hard mode, is to have transport lines that deliver profit in both directions as much as possible. The more you think about it the more complex it gets. In the beginning it's easy, road cargo brings stone and returns bricks. With trains that doesn't work anymore, but what [i]does[/i] work is to deliver stone and return coal. Or to deliver goods and return machines. You [i]can[/i] create a transportation network in which this is the case, but it requires a lot of thinking, especially with towns only requiring 2 cargo goods. That is what makes this game challenging and exiting.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Top notch improvements. Developers listening to feedback? In my 2019?!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This game, i was slightly sceptical about, seeing the trailer i was a bit disappointed that they decided to not expand upon Transport Fever 1, and I continued to be disappointed, until I watched the game-play video when it released, and my opinion went polar opposite, I was ecstatic about the graphics changes, the quality of life, and I don't know how they did it, but it feels like they have created something entirely unique from the Train Fever and Transport Fever 1.

There are only two things that I don't like:

Why are there not any lower settings than MEDIUM for terrain and shadows, like, what? I have a pretty shitty system, and I wish there was more opportunity for people with worse systems (me and a lot of others) to have a relatively smooth and non stuttering game. Having an option to turn off shadows would EASILY give people 60 FPS and barely any stutter. I know that people might just say, 'hAh WeLl GeT a BeTtEr SyStEm!'. Well, I am in school and I don't have a job, and I have better stuff to spend money on.

The other thing about the game, which isn't actually bad, it's just a personal preference that I believe a lot of people want to. But having multiplayer in Transport Fever 2 would make this game an 11/10. No joke, in my eyes, the Transport Fever series is a direct successor to the classic OpenTTD game (if you don't know what it is, watch the Yogscast play it or Jschlatt). Having multiplayer, whether it be cooperating to maximise efficiency in your transport empire, or it being competing to gain the favour of towns and push your rivals away from the profitable industries and cities.

The best things about Transport Fever 2:

- A blast watching your vehicles travel the lands
- Watching the towns grow after you have laid plenty of infrastructure
- Seeing the evolution of your railways and city routes
- Hundreds of vehicles that in my eyes, can never get old
- A genuinely satisfying experience throughout all portions of the game

Overall, this game is amazing, a solid 9/10, another masterpiece from Urban Games and associated teams, a game that is actually worth the $60 AUD. A true successor to older transport management oriented games, and worth far more recognition than it already has.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I bought this after watching Biffa play it. After playing it a bunch, it has a number of problems. First the logic is terrible. You have no control over what goes where except for trains, and the AI makes terrible decisions. For example, vehicles leave depots 90% empty with the depot completely full.  There is no point in trains, they are absurdly expensive to run. Unbalanced, poor AI, insufficient control.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: This is a review which covers the early iteration of the game. No major patches have been released, nor updates or DLC so what I'll say will be with respect to that. In any case, the game is pretty good. It's certainly very enjoyable if you liked the previous titles in this series - Train Fever, and Transport Fever. However, it's lacking in some features which were present in the previous game. Not having as much at the tip of your fingers is a bit frustrating. I especially miss autoreplace as well as the inability to make curved stations. Now, it's true those aspects were added with mods after the initial release of TPF1, but it's odd it wouldn't be standard in the base game. Some things were added that were present via mods, such as paint options and a whole asset tab. That is a nice addition, so it's odd that some features are absent and some added.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Great game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Suffers from "get it out by Christmas regardless."
If you haven't played TF1 then it is a good game, but not the sort of game you can dip into -  which can be a good thing,    It is nice to have a immersive game in your own game catalogue.
If you have TF1 then it is basically the same except for the improved graphics, no learning curve whatsoever!
It seems to run quicker and with less glitches.
PROs
* Good Graphics
* Nice game play.
* Nice music again.
* A Good Challenge.
* Lots of fun and options.
CONS
* Unfeasibly long time to load - go have a cup of tea, play another quick game, go write a review - Haha!   Obviously loading from an SSD improves loading time a little.
* If it takes so long to load - how come it takes a nano-second to unload???  (lol)
* Why does reloading a gameplay involve load the WHOLE game???  
* A CTRL-Z button would be nice, one accidental click/build and it could cost you the game while money is tight..
* Travel on a train but without any points or level crossing rumble which is weird.  This is the sort of improvement one would expect in 'the improved new version'.
* .. see above.  Very little time and effort has been spent creating a better game in V2.
I think more could have been done to add more content and develop animations of the game so it is disappointing for a so-called improved game.  But it still the best there is of the genre which might not be saying much for the potential of what could be.  We live in hope.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: If you haven't got Transport Fever 1 it is worth getting. If you have, it's a waste of money. The graphics are improved, but there are virtual zero gameplay changes from the original. Cities are only interested in 1-2 specific commodities now and you can freely mix cargo/passenger platforms on the same station, but that's about it. Traffic is flow still just as poorly implemented and campaign is just like the original - a bunch of pointless tasks rather than something that builds to any strategic goal.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I gave it 36 hours, most of that spent in the map editor, but I just can't get into it like I could the first one.

The UI changes take me 'out of the game', if that makes sense, the "two goods per city" mechanic makes logistics uninteresting to me,  and the "initial size" mechanic takes a lot of development choices I enjoyed in the original away from me.

Revision: Changing the thumbs down to a thumbs up because even though I wouldn't recommend it, I also wouldn't recommend against it. Where's the 'whatever' option?

Note: overuse of "me" is intended to make it clear that I am only speaking for myself.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Good Game

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I'd have a hard time recommending this right now vs the previous version. Yes, the graphics are a bit nicer and the modular stations and stuff is nice but I find the interface totally a mess now. You just can't SEE details of stuff anymore and act on it. There's so many things you cannot do or see from what used to be just the 1 panel could in the past. Trying to find old equipment and actually replace it is a nightmare. Trying to add on train cars to an existing train becomes a chore.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is a dumbed down version of Transport Fever, it removed what little control you had over what you can do with your train cars. You can no longer tell your train cars to only carry a certain product. 
You can no longer switch train cars around , now its just buy and sell. 
They made the Missions the tutorial, so if you play the game first and then decide to play the missions you will have to deal with them explaining things you already know.
The game seams as if it was designed for children. In the missions if you successfully place a building where they tell you to put it you get a clapping sound and a Task Completed notice. You feel like your in grammer school and are getting rewarded for a minor accomplishment.
Like Transport Fever the stations aren't capable of prioritizing trains that are waiting for products so your train will just sit there while all the products get loaded on the other platforms.
They made the train car cost ridiculously expensive. In 1850 you can buy a steam engine for $250,000 but the 14 person passenger car cost $400.000.  add in the high maintenance costs and you end up with low profits which results in it taking way to long to make any money to expand with.
The game runs way to slow. It seems like the highest speed (3) in this game is less than the speed of the 2 setting in Transport Fever. This results in the player doing a lot of staring and waiting. 
These are just some of the things i'm annoyed with.
For me the game is annoying for the lack of control, aggravating for it's inability to do common sense things like prioritize a waiting train, and boring because it's slow and you can't really do much to control your vehicles in the game. your stuck with FULL LOAD on trains and nothing but LOAD and UNLOAD at the stations.

review:
This game feels very much like its predecessor Transport Fever 1.  If like me you played the previous game, you'll feel right at home.

The industry supply system has greatly been improved from TF1 (No more production back to 0 because it exceeded the demand).   So far I had a lot of fun.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Overall, I like Transport Fever 2. 

One major drawback is the fact that the game crashes. The crashes seem to be related to earth moving (leveling land, lowering land, etc.) as far as I can tell, though I've suffered crashes while doing things other than earth moving.

Cargo planes are added, which is fantastic. The models look amazing, and the details are a ton of fun to check out. 

Please continue improving and fix the bugs! It's frustrating to have the game crash after working for an hour or so without saving. Cannot recommend until the crashes are no longer a problem. Game play is great!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have played this series from the first Train Fever and i keep coming back to every upgrade. The series keep gettig better and better. The last addition is good, im having some minor stabilityissues but nothing that autosave wont cure, and its hours between each crash, so that doesnt bother me.

What bothers me is the silly debt cap that they still have. When you are starting with the trains, and each train easy is like 10 mill each, you need a shitload of cash to put up a few lines. With the debt cap this will take longer time than it should have.

On the plus side, you have a lot more options when it comes to your stations. This gives much more flexibility when setting up your stations than before.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'm new to this series, but i've played many simulation before in my whole life.

Lets getting started by saying this game isn't newbie friendly. The UX designer must be mad to think that the starting mission was enough for tutorial. Many things in game were confusing for me, even now, as i only played just before the 2 hours refund limit.

Get going, the optimization were bad, real bad. My pc was definitely above the requirement stated, but somehow it takes forever to load just the small map. The first time i tried to play mission, i got a message from a friend and alt+tab when its still loading. Guess what, its crashed! So i had to start over again. When i tried to play on the large map, moving the screen feel really laggy, and when i tried to zoom out, the game crashed again! Its not a bad thing that a game requires a good specs to play, but please state the requirement correctly. This is definitely a trap for borderline specs players.

The end of the day, i do not recommend this game at all to borderline specs gamer. This game is good in graphic, and i feel the game itself is good if you get enough understanding of how it works. But it has a steep learning curve because the lack of tutorial.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Good changes, but greatly misunderstood currently. At first glance it may seem easier than TF1 but 40 hours in you start to realize the amount of depth added in TF2 lends to a more challenging and satisfying experience. 

The biggest complaint is the way demand is handled by cities. You can no longer drop a depot between your 3 largest closely located cities and just profit with little to no planning. Land, sea, and air lines (all actually useful now) must be properly planned and routed over centuries. 

Everything feels much more connected now, which in a transportation game is a really good thing.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Honestly, this Transport Fever 1.2 but it is good. It's detailed and fun to play - the closest thing to Transport Tycoon with amazing visuals. The game is not without it's faults, but it's certainly among the most solid out there. The developers have shown that they will stick with the game and have really impressed me - honest, hardworking and passionate. Honestly, it's worth buying just to support professional indie game developers.

4.5 Stars.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: FREEZES ALOTTTTTTTT AND HECK,IT FREEZES AND SHUTTERING

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I've played Transport Fever ever since figuring out it's existence through Youtube.

That said, I have put a lot of time into the original. I love this iteration of the whole idea. Environments are awesome, terrain gen is new and improved. Graphics on ported trains and vehicles from the previous title look amazing still.

I really enjoy the new industry system, it's challenging and creates new concepts to figure out how to maximize profits.

The issues I have with this game, and the only reasons why I am not recommending it in it's current state is due to some issues I have with resources.

When launching a game I tend to get a max usage in my RAM, having 16 GB of RAM this is pretty unacceptable. I understand we are loading a massive simulation in some of the worlds, but it is upsetting having all of my programs and PC slow to a still for around 30 seconds to 1 minute.

I also have read a lot about difficulties being pretty poor, at least being less impactful than the previous title in the series.

I sincerely hope that this may help. The game is great, but until the heavy RAM usage is fixed without a physical CONFIG change (which may help[?] I have not tried this option) I cannot 100% recommend.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you love city builders and transport tycoon games, this is for you, it certainly does sound boring if you are a regular or hardcore gamer.
In my 24hrs of game play my game has crashed once. I haven’t researched the issues but I have a pretty decent PC and up to date drivers. No mods on mine yet as I want to earn a few achievements.

Purchased it for 25% off as i had Transport Fever 1. Watched a gameplay video and the un-moded experience looked so much better than the first game. The new features and sale enticed me to buy the game for sure!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The management of the supply chain is fundamentally broken.  You are allowed to deliver an unlimited amount of materials anywhere on the map and still earn money on every shipment.  This allows you to earn unlimited profits with no real thought.

Don't buy this game if you want a challenge.  There is no challenge here.  This is a very disappointing sequel and now feel let down by the time that had been spent on the game only to discover that the supply chain management challenge was actually all smoke and mirrors.

I don't plan to play this game again until this is addressed.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Great game, big improvement!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'm 42 hours into a massive tropical map on difficult.  It's run flawlessly on windows 10, intel 5, and a 2 meg video card.  The tropical map with islands expands the water dimension missing in TF1.  The map preview, sliders, and working map editor are very welcome.   The changes in interface were easy to move over to after a couple of frustrating moments.   The resource power ups and city demands make more sense.  The values of all the numbers have increased, but so have the costs.   Making some money on difficult is easier than in TF1.  Making enough to expand your transport empire the way you want is a challenge on difficult when putting in two large airports and one decent plane can run 50 million or upgrading 3 trains to high speed electric tops 100 million in costs.   On easy managing money is easy, on difficult it requires management. 

I'm satisfied that there are a lot of hours of both enjoyment and challenge here for me and recommend it to anyone who likes tycoon games or liked transport fever.   It IS transport fever of course, but it's also different enough for me to enjoy the changes.   I'm satisfied that for me this is money well spent.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Its fun

title: Transport Fever 2
review: A clear improvement on the first game. The missions are interesting and the new map tools are amazing.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: OK. Everything checks out. But I am sick and tired of replacing the vehicles manually. I have over 100 lines and each time I have to manually select a line and upgrade or replace a vehicle. Why ? This is stupid. The first version had so much ease.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This just feels like a polished version of TF1. There are subtle changes, the interface for one, is better and obviously, it looks a lot better. I'll recommend it, but it needs some work. It needs to optimized, BIG time. It's laggy and very slow to load. I own a "newish" machine and it took close to 20 minutes to create and load a large map. It says I have 2.2 hours of play time and literally 25% of that is in load screens. 
The map customization is far better than TF1, but... The times to move materials around the map, (especially starting in 1850), is ridiculous. That part needs work.  
In any case, if you want TF1 polished and some interface upgrades, yea, it's not bad. But again, those load times... wow. 
I still think Steam needs a "meh", button, because that's where this game is for me.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
If you liked the first one, you will love this one.
The devs took some huge steps into the right direction. First thing that comes to mind here are the missions. They are shorter and much more streamlined so they ease into the game without overwhelming the new player. Veterans will still feel much at home and can enjoy more variety overall plus much better info tools.

Overall this is a GOTY candidate if you like this kind of game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
My favorite tycoon game.  Similar to the original Transport Fever, which itself was based spiritually on Transport Tycoon.  Quite a few improvements versus the original Transport Fever, including custom stations, a much better economic model that is a lot more intuitive, and better graphics.  I find this far superior to Railway Empires or any similar game.  

The custom stations are terrific and I can never go back to TF1 after having them.  You can easily make any road depot, train station, airport, or harbor accept passengers or freight and add more terminals as needed.  It's modular so you can always add more as you need it.  

I personally like the new economic model.  It makes it much easier to determine what is causing cities to grow and your lines are much less likely to wildly change their production.  This means much more reliable production chains which can thereby be made more elaborate.      

The only downside compared to Railway Empires or the Sid Railroads series is that there are no AI opponents.  For me, that's not an issue (for instance, there are also no AI oppents in Cities Skylines).  

Only disappointment is that there's no ability to disable Vsync in the menu, but you can still manually do this in the settings file.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: It's definitely better than TPv1 and if you like playing the game you will enjoy version 2.0 much better.  I will easily get my value out of this game and a lot of play time.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Short and sweet review.

TF2 is essentially a re-skin and rebalance of TF1 with many improvements to graphics, vehicle sets and playability.

However, the one key issue with TF1 was with optimization, where the game would stutter and demand too many system resources on even average sized maps.

TF2 is the same, if not worse. Severe lag, performance issues and game crashing is present once the transport system gets large enough (not very large in reality).

This game is a step backwards for those like me who just want to build an extensive network without lag and stutter.... It's all i ask.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Have Transport Fever  the two version plays differently. I think it is better, probably a litter harder than the original

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Really enjoying my time with this game so far. It's everything a Transport Tycoon/OTTD successor should be. I really enjoy that each map is a blank canvas for one's creativity in planning transport. Building tools are intuitive and fun. The supply and demand systems work well and are a welcome change from TF1 (cities accepting certain goods only). The different transport types seem pretty well balanced. I am not experiencing any crashes - game runs stably, at least on a medium size map. I do have a powerful PC however. The soundtrack is nice.

All in all, very pleased with this title and will be enjoying hundreds of hours on it!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Easy to beat. Very easy. Just second game in 1852 I was making 1.5m a year and by 1950 I had 300m on my account.

The simple truth about this un-complex game is - the money is in the distance. Use the river, find two businesses at both ends, they don't have to be next to the river, just close so you can deliver with 20 cars large ammounts to the port. Buy a ship. And watch money flowing in.... the game is beaten on 1852 and its only about expansion.

The plus is for the graphics. If it was 2D map or isometric you could run in the browser. 

All in all it is very simplified variation on immortal Transport Tycoon by MicroProse which has so much bigger maps, so much higher level of complexity and it was running on DOS in 1994 when it was released. 

Advice: if you want true Transport Fever get yourself OpenTTD - its free and it so much better.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A pretty good game overall, but not a huge improvement over the original transport fever. They haven't added as many features as they could have done but the features they did add are quite good. In particular, configurable stations are great, and the terrain/asset tools are pretty good. Aside from that, its mostly quality of life (Instant selling/upgrading of vehicles, deleting stuff doesn't ruin the landscape, fewer bugs) and general experience (graphics, wild animals, movable first person camera) improvements, which while welcome, do not a good game make. I feel that they really missed out on opportunities such as underground stations,  or even different modes of transport like monorails.

All that being said, I'd definitely say it's a great game. If you enjoyed or were invested in the original transport fever, you'll probably enjoy this game even more, and if you're new to the genre I think its a pretty good place to start. If you tried the original transport fever and found it wasn't for you, I don't think that this game offers enough to change your opinion.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Loving it so far.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Pretty graphics and an improvement over the original Transport Fever as far as having to make some gameplay choices (not every town accepts every good). That said however, it is an evolution, not a complete change. There are still elements that I would consider to be missing from a logistics game - for example road vehicles still can't overtake anything that moves slower than they do (so you have to upgrade them all on a route otherwise they'll just get stuck behind the slowest). Worse though, is that trains using the same line cannot be made to pass each other which means you must use the same trains/config or risk not getting the most out of the faster train. You can frig this by using separate lines and forcing routes that go onto different parallel tracks - but I would rather see a routing system that will understand multiple ways to get to the destination and follow a path with open signals if there is one available when the first route is blocked. 

TL;DR - Worth playing, good eye candy, slightly more challenge than the original but still lacking the tools to be a really in-depth train-set.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Despite being a great improvement on the original Transport Fever this feels more like when (bear with me) Paradox do a huge content patch and upgrade of one of their games (think Stellaris 2.0) that really being a full sequel, but still being sold as a full release.

Pros -
It looks an awful lot better than TF1. 
Lines and industries seem cleverer than they used to be. Much easier to establish a multi stage supply chain (different modes of transport) than it ever used to be in TF1.
Industries don't have a habit of forgetting you exist like they used to. 
UI is clearer (to me anyway) and available info is better in game
The ability to pause the game year while still playing is lovely. 
Modular stations are a brilliant new feature. 
New map generation allows for decent tinkering before you begin. 

Cons - 
Building bridges over railways still a nightmare. 
Cities only ever accept two products plus passengers as opposed to the 6 plus passengers of TF1. Makes it very easy to supply and grow a city with minimal effort, unnecessary simplicity.
In fact the entire economy system is simple and arbitrary. 
New vehicle management system is a step backwards and not very instinctive. It's about condition rather than age and how it works or impacts the game isn't obvious. 
Despite modders having added curved stations to TF1 the devs still don't support them. 
New "Island" map setting tied to Asian environment for some arbitrary reason. 

In short, did you enjoy Transport Fever and Train Fever? Then you'll enjoy this. 
Looking for a fun network builder? You'll enjoy this. 
Looking for a challenging logistics tycoon? You might be disappointed.
