title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This is quickly becoming a game that I start playing when I get home from work at about 6 in the evening then blink and it's 3 in the morning!. Where did all the time go, I swear I was only playing for 5 minutes.

Did you ever wake up at Christmas hoping that St. Nick brought you that epic Hornby Train set that you had your eye on?, if the answer is yes you simply must go buy this game now!. I would also highly recommend  this game to anyone that is interested in the old tycoon management style of game like Railroad Tycoon, TTD etc as it will be right up your alley as this is basically a virtual train set.... The campaign is challenging at the later stages and will leave you scratching your head in bemusement trying to figure out how to meet all the objectives as quickly and cheaply as humanly possible. However this is no real story or motivation in the Free Play mode other than to generate more profit then Disney does each year abusing the Star War franchise. While I admit that doesn't sound that appealing to many, it was this mode that I enjoyed the most and being free to create my transport however I see fit. I actually found it quite liberating when I could go outside the normal game and play about with the sandbox mode enabled (safe to say some of the towns got rather large).

in conclusion there is not much actual improvement here over Transport Fever 1, which I have sunk 200 hours plus into!, other then a few minor changes which I thought worked much better like that each town requires 2 resources. The other main improvement is the much better graphics which holds a much greater level of detail over the original title.

Oh and before I sign off... I haven't spoken about the steam workshop have I? this along with Transport Fever 1 was my biggest pull to these games, want to model your game in the style of the early 1900's Great Western Railway (GWR) or London North Eastern Railway (LNER) you can with the wide selection of mods, this gives the game a massive replay factor and what keeps me coming back and wasting hours on hours with my virtual train set.

Playing for 55 hours in 2 days, I feel the mixture of virtual and real worls, satisfying all of my fantasy regarding driving transports and managing the tracks with LOGICAL REASONS. Enormous maps to connect, sometimes its tremendously stressful to solve the traffic routes, but in the end, its speechless to experience the tour of your own created world with your unique and profitable strategies.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A surprisingly good game. I'm new to the genre and so far found this game well worth the $39.99 I paid for it. 
- All vehicles, Buildings, and the game world itself, look  great.
- The game play is fairly easy to pick up, but there is a learning curve that's not difficult to overcome. The campaign missions help teach the basics.
- The UI is simplistic yet very detailed. For example, with a simple click you can  see the conditions of your vehicles at a glance and determine if they need to be replaced.
- The problems I've encountered so far are minimal. For example, It would be nice if there was an auto replace feature for the vehicles because, as your transportation empire grows, managing all your vehicles and keeping them in good condition can become a little overwhelming.
- If there is anything about this game that needs improvement, I would say the in-game music. Worst soundtrack ever. Thank God for Pandora. The Mariachi music in mission three cracked me up. Then it just became annoying.
I highly recommend this game especially if you are a fan of city builders like Cities Skylines.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
YES! YES! YES! I absolutely LOVE Transport Fever 2, for many reasons that I will add to this review after I have fulfiled my binge play of this beautiful successor to Transport Fever.

Ok still binge playing but wanted to add a few things to this review...

The best pre-purchase I have made since pre-purchasing the original Transport Fever!

THE MAP TOOL! is fantastic. It is what Create-a-World was to Sims 3! (Simmers will get that reference). I can now create my own very precise and custom maps in the game without having to use 3rd party software and tools. That makes this game worth its weight in gold for me personally. It is what I wished for most and Urban games delivered!
The totally modifiable terrain including COASTLINES is a BIG plus.
The modular stations are fantastic and the fact that I can now combine passenger and cargo in one station is sublime.
The graphics are stunning.
The factories, farms, manufacturing buildings have far more detail and better animations.
The People are a lot better and their animations a lot more "natural".
The variation in biomes is fantastic.
The game loads a heck of a lot faster than TF1 did (even before it got weighed down with mods).
Runs very smoothly so far.
There seems to be a lot more detail in every aspect of the environment.
Lots more info easily accessible about, vehicles, lines, towns, industries etcetera.
Better movable ride-along camera.
Not having every product demanded by every town does add more challenge to deciding where and how to ship goods and materials.
The new highlighting is a LOT more visible. Much easier to see catchment areas and zones.
The new UI does take a bit of getting used to and a few things do not feel as "intuitive" as they might be. It is very easy for example to buy the wrong, train, carriage, truck for example BUT after a lot more practice it will fade.
Already the fantastic modding community are porting over mods from TF1 (hoping my favourite Multiple Units will be converted soon.

So YES I absolutely recommend this game especially to fans of the genre!

15*09*2019 Played 15 hours solid now have a City of 3500 people on a large custom designed map I made and its looking so beautiful and ran perfectly. My partner who is not a "Gamer" was fascinated watching me play lol

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I love this series, as it's the right level of immersion that want, while still letting me be hands off sometimes to enjoy the view.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have played through 3 of the  quest scenarios, and about 15 hours on a frustrating "free" game, and what a huge disappointment. The only positive reviews you will see are from people who have not played the first one. I have about 200 hours on TF1 and nearly all the achievements. I loved it and was so looking forward to 2. The graphics and all the colours on 2 are kind of faded. You really have to look carefully to see the towns zones. And now you have to first create a line and then you can assign vehicles to it. In 1 it was all in one go. The interfaces coming up are dull and dark grey, with no personality. The graphics are barely better than 1. The towns now need just two random resources. This is so unrealistic.  I just get the feeling that these guys thought. "Ah well - got to make a sequel - lets up the graphics a bit and see how we can twiddle a bit with the controls." What any gamer wants from a sequel is some surprise, something new that makes you think - wow that's nice!  I am sad - yes I am. Especially as I bought the first on a special and felt inspired to pay proper money for the second version.
O my goodness... - there is no more auto replacement of vehicles at its retirement age. This means that  you now either have to replace individually, or the whole line at once. The info screen where you can see the age of each vehicle in a row, is not the same as the replacement screen. On the replacement screen, no age appears.... which means you will have to look at the numbers of the vehicles on the one screen where you can see their age., then either write it down, or remember, then go to the replacement screen and tick the correct ones you wish to replace... Why on earth would they change a system that worked so intuitively, to these cumbersome bland grey screens? Well - because it is an expansion old chap! We can't have you thinking we did nothing! I might make a video of this on that tube thing...

The AI at any farm or industry just doesn t work. Try building one truck station with more than on line... There is no sense in the way it is setup. The old way of 5 stuff in, 5 stuff out was much better. You have no control on which line the produce is placed for transport, and there seems no logic in the way it is done. Town growth is just stupid. I have Dallas in 1990 with 435 residents! That is after I have managed to supply it with goods and passenger transport for 50 years. But the city almost looks like a metropolis! 

It seems that the specific two commodities any town needs, is almost impossible to get to them - until later in the game with faster road vehicles. A cart can take years to eventually get 4 units to the town. TF1 has its problems, but it pales in comparison to all the mistakes in TF2

review:
I looked at this game and all the reviews and decided to give it a try.  

Lets just say that the game while playable isn't as it seems.  Imagine being a craftsman in lets say Europe and deciding to take an item that has no value to anybody and place your factory in the middle of the outback of Australia and hope to sell it to somebody in the upper regions of the Yukon territory.   

Yeah, that's what you deal with, unless you want to make horse runs in literally every town and maybe after 5-10 years make enough to pay off your loan to the bank.  It's got some promise just not enough to make it worth your while out of a hundred or so maps i've gotten 1 good commidity run on a random map.  If you like being frustrated and basically having no game to play for like 2/3 of the time its a winner or perhaps with all the mods you can make something of it.  Cheats/hobbling 4tw?

I would like to play it but its just like the laws of economics have been completely suspended.  People build chains in or near the product not completely across the world.  Perhaps after a bit it will get better i hope.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I really don’t understand what goal the developers had in mind for TF2; quite a lot of changes to game play and navigation, but for what purpose? There are no new features or content to speak of, certainly not to warrant new game pricing. Navigation and menus are definitely not improved (initial impression - it’s worse, granted I do not have the same familiarity with them yet); dialogs e.g. in train depot/purchase menu feel more convoluted and shortcuts like creating a new line from assignment button are missing; object windows not being linked and popping up anywhere make getting orientated harder. Graphics are nicer, though control over building roads, bridges, crossings etc. is as limited as before which still sometimes causes odd/unrealistic construction. Still need to play more for a final verdict on gameplay changes, initial sense is that especially the simplified industry mechanics make that aspect of the game much less interesting. I love TF and was excitedly looking forward to TF2 release, very disappointed at the moment.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'll just say it.  I am enjoying TF2.  I'm enjoying it quite a bit.  While it boasts a number of improvements over its predecessor, I can't help but feel like a good number of the changes were more "lateral" in that they alter the gameplay and functionality from TF1, but don't necessarily deliver tangible improvements or enhancements.  

 For example, I don't mind the changes made to vehicle management;
- Vehicles still age, but the mechanic that impacts the game is their "emissions" which can be reduced with increased maintenance.
- There are still depots, but we no longer have the ability to "store" equipment, or move cars/locomotives from one train to another.
- You can easily now select multiple vehicles to apply actions against.  I like this especially when you want to upgrade vehicles but don't need replacements on a 1 to 1 ratio.  In the past, that meant sending individual vehicles to the depot, now it's a lot faster.

I don't necessarily dislike this new overall feel, but can't help but feel like it doesn't really represent a great leap forward from TF1.  Is it better system?  Maybe a little bit, but certainly not a "deal maker".

Also, I like that the cargo system no longer has a 1 to 1 relationship in supply/demand in the sense that you now must draw on multiple primary industries to get production at secondary and tertiary to their upper levels.  I'm not however sold on the idea that cities don't demand everything.  After all, what city doesn't demand food?  Goods?  It's just a game, but games such as this still generally should try to follow basic expectations that are rooted in reality.  I hope we see some mods to address this as well.

Overall, the biggest improvements over TF1 I can think of are;
- Better maps and variety:  I love that we now have open bodies of water and more value added to the shipping aspect of the game.
- Modular stations are really very nice.  I will still very much miss the ability to curve the stations as we had (via mods) in TF1.  I hope similar efforts eventually pop up in the workshop, but in the meantime, I was always annoyed in TF1 and Train Fever how much of a chore it often was to upgrade a station.

I would still highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the genre, just be prepared to not be blown away by any one thing.  It shakes things up a little and certainly, it's still early in my time playing this game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TF2, like TF1, is a great game, make no mistakes.  I honestly don't think there's a better game on the market that revolves around transportation.  The improvements (like the map editor and modular stations) are strong and the core gameplay is still great (mainly because it's the same).

Why, oh why, did they dumb down the economy??  Honestly, the one thing I wanted from this game was a deeper economic system with more complex industry.  Instead we got the exact opposite.  Now, towns only accept 2 resources and certain resources have been simplified.  I don't get it.  I understand they wanted to make the game more accessible to new players (which it is), but if you can't do that while also accommodating the base who will make up the vast majority of your sales, what's the point??  

I still recommend the title.  I'm just a bit annoyed that there were no real improvements to depth, and in a lot of ways, they actually made it more shallow.  Still, there's not a better title when it comes to transportation.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed any classic transport tycoon game such as Transport Tycoon Deluxe, Chris Sawyer's Locomotion, etc. Those games were my go to when I was a kid and this just feels like a more advanced, more modern version of that. The mechanics, the visuals, and the steam workshop make it a really solid game where I feel like I'm reliving my childhood. I don't review games often but I've felt so moved by playing this game that I had to write a review. This is 100% without a single doubt in my mind worth the money and I can tell I'll rack up hundreds of hours once more on a transport tycoon kind of game. I didn't even watch the tutorial either, I just went straight into free play and started going at it and it was simple enough to get the hang of plus the discord community is really helpful if you get stuck.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: It is a good continuation of this series. There are things that need improved or that need restored from TF1 and I'm sure will be as they see what the complaints are from old users with this new version. The modular stations and improved graphics (now that NVIDEA supports the game with optimized settings that part is better than when released and the game wouldn't recognize NVIDEA at the time) seem to be the most popular new things. The white on white design in a planning tool is the worst change and I'm sure they will fix that lousy bit of planning. The "campaign" is now basically just a tutorial to me and not very good at that as it's hard to say where it wants things put and I tend to give up on it. Use that as much as needed that you can figure out and watch videos to figure out what makes no sense in the tutorial. The game was designed to not be using the campaigns though and is good then. Just remember to find videos or other sources to learn how to do things if you struggle with the tutorial and didn't play prior games in the series. It's great fun once you learn and without having to deal with obnoxious folks in any multiplayer areas. lol If you think only games with multiplayer are good then this one isn't for you and there are tens of thousands of multiplayer games to choose from for you.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I managed to find the same broken problem in TP2 that exists in TP1, and that is freight not being delivered to a town.  Out of two separate games in TP2, I had a freight item that would not deliver.  For those who see the ten hours of play, I have hundreds of hours in TP1, so I know how it works.  When I worked with support to troubleshoot the issue in TP1, the answer was my line cost was too high.  Like I can reduce it??  I could make 2 Billion a year in profit, and successfully deliver the other five output items with no line cost too high.
While the build a station may have some perks, it takes many minutes to just get a station going.  Maybe mods will solve that time issue.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
First of all its not a bad game and if you havent played TF1 you will most likely enjoy this game.

Having said that, I cant recommend this game to anyone that liked TF1. While they improved a lot of things, like the UI, they cut or changed a lot of things for the worse. TF2 feels in some regards more like a predecessor not a successor of TF1. To give you a short overview:

+ trains etc. look really nice
+ map look more natural than vanilla TF1
+ performance is good (because cities are much smaller)
+ modular stations are great
+ some balance changes to industrie (e.g. there are no more cows)

o asian vehicle set is nice but more or less russian and not asian and easily replaced by TF1 mods
o tropical climate set is a good addition
o island maps are great, but map generation fails here sometimes and they are only available for tropical climate
o UI changes; some are great some aren't in the end it balances itself out
o income system hasent changed
o industries do no longer need demand from a city to start producing
o emission system 

- cities are a lot smaler and city size is limited by the initial city size (e.g. in 1960 I usually had 3000 people per city in TF1, the limit for cities in TF seems to be around 1000-2000 depending on the initial size)
- cities only demand two products and they are fixed (there was a lot of room here for improvement e.g. number of product depending on city size,...)
- hard mode is way to easy compared to TF1
- easy/normal mode seems to hard for new players
- some vehicles are still useless and some are straight downgrades
- no chain signals
- cant replace/add vehicles on a train, you have to rebuy/upgrade the whole thing (which can be done anywhere)
- same "physics" as TF1 (there is still no need to pick a freight loco for a freight train, max speed is still king)

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TpF2 is essentially a refinement of TpF1, which in itself was pretty good. It offers lots of QoL improvement and new features over the first game - Modular stations is a very welcome addition in particular.

My biggest issue with TpF1 was not the gameplay, not the price and not the content - it was performance. Thankfully, it is better this time around although not perfect. You will still experience frame drops if you zoom in to cities as the simulation is pretty intense in this game (and I have a pretty powerful setup w/ 9900K / GTX1080 + 16GB fast ram). I would like to see further improvement on this area but nonetheless I still enjoy the game a lot.

Its a modern take on Transport Tycoon and thats all there is to say about it - those who enjoy it will enjoy it and those who don't enjoy this sort of game probably would not.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Welcome to Transport Fever 1.5, where the graphics are a bit prettier than V1 (good), the stations are more modular (good), the freight system is screwier in that some cities don't need food or fuel to be provided by the only significant transport network on the map and get it instead from... I don't know, a magic carpet or something (WT????)... and where not one iota of effort has been put into the single most infuriating part of the gameplay, track and road laying (bad. Very, very bad).

Oh, you'll still "enjoy" those classic Transport Fever 1 track building error messages; "too much slope", "too much curvature", "too much chilli sauce on your french fries", "construction not possible because {shrug}, don't wanna"... but all those other fan faves are there too:
- "Zoom in to build so that you can't even vaguely see where the other end of your line is so spend a few hundred grand drawing in a line which you hope might, possibly, connect to the far end". 
- "Ctrl+Z is for sissies, If you didn't MEAN to put the track 5 degrees off from where you need to link up to the other end, why, you should never have done it!" 
- "Track planning? Who needs it?!" Just commit to laying down the track and hope that the slightly differently shaded terrain map doesn't indicate that a 5 mile long tunnel will be needed." 

Oh, and my personal favourite, the lack of any auto snap so that when you drag your track up to the existing track, the end of your new line is about 5 feet away. And strangely metal lines don't stretch, can you imagine that?

Did I say that that was my favourite? Sorry, my bad. "Line 1 has a problem, but it's a secret and I won't tell you what it is" is my absolute fav; it's such fun. In a loop it was showing one station as a terminus. It isn't. The track forms a continuous loop. I tediously followed the track aaaaallll the way from that station to the one before it. Nothing. Wrong. NOTHING. No gaps, no issues... save for the fact that "Line 1 has a problem" and that there was "no route available".

Maybe, possibly, it's because I had to put the station on a weird angle adjacent to the road because stations have the catchment area of a teaspoon, and there is some unknown and unknowable "obstruction", but trying to find it is someone else's idea of fun, not mine. 

I suppose that I could obliterate the track along with my bank balance and try again, but this comes back to the failure of the devs to address IMHO the biggest issue with TF1, the failure to be able to plan a line before you commit money to it and/or the ability to walk it back while you're paused without blowing fistfuls of cash.

I like the general concept of TPF, I like the whole planning of a network, but when a network fails to work because "nah, not gunna" and when there is so much tedium involved in just trying to get something to include a decent sized catchment, it ceases to be fun. 

If I'm not finding any enjoyment in the game, and at this point I'm not, I can't in good conscience recommend it. If subsequent patches and upgrades deal with these issues though, I'll happily revisit this review because I do indeed want to like this game. At the moment... I really don't that much.

review: It deffinetly plays different then the first one. The money and vehicle management are changed but once you get used to that it plays pretty smoothly. And upside you now have a flat vehicle cost instead of it increasing. The only thing that increases with vehicle age now is Emisstions. Witch is only importent to town growth. the lower it is the faster the growth. but it will still grow if its high, just not that fast. But the way around that is to truck everything to the outside of the town then use something with low emissions to truck it in. or only go in were you need to and get out. don't have your vehicles drive all the way through the town.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'm sorry, but this feels way too similar to Transport Fever 1 to be worth the asking price.

The economy has quite a few changes. We get a couple of new traffic tools. "Emissions" system seems mostly pointless so far. The interface is still quite clunky, but there are some good new additions like being able to search by line name.

I don't care about the terrain manipulation stuff in terms of how I play the game (that's mostly for the model rail enthusiasts). The wildlife is pretty but doesn't have a function.

Maps feel really small, still. High speed rail and aircraft barely have a function. Passenger logic is still silly, with them skipping express services for slow trains. Performance is still not great.

I would have liked to see some new modes of transport like canals, narrow-gauge rail, cargo trams, and pedestrian paths.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Just switched from TF1, so this is what we've got in the 'free game' mode:
++ new economic model for more interesting and focused gameplay
++ better graphics and performance 
++ mountains really challenge building, as they should
+ release quality pretty good
+ more options for road traffic routing
+ both goods & passenger rail traffic bring in good revenue based on resp. distance & speed  
- no more floating windows (quick access/overview)
- clunky large menus
- slower speed of building and fiddly quirks with track laying
- emission & growth model have zero bearing to reality
- occasional glitch with routing, goods pick-up/drop off

But in conclusion, Urban Games created another hugely addictive tycoon game! It take three steps forward and one back (for now) and we still have the workshop option.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I played extensively the first version of the game, Transport Fever, and 2nd is in a sense the same game with added improvements. But never the less, about this game:

Pros:
Detailed system to create massive multi-vehicle networks
Great improvement over last game with multi stage stations and platforms for goods
Map editor implemented into core game
More of vehicle choice, map offsets and terrain options
Towns now have specified need system, that is easy to see and interact
Added pollution for realism

Cos:
Town now are more specified in goods needs, thus losing complexity of the first game
To the extent it's just improved and more optimised first game
At current stage stations for some reason reset in goods/people count after changes to them are made, making lines reset and thus lose profit for a shot time, and it drives me nuts!!!

Anyway, it is a chill game, same concept as games like Cities Skyline, Train Tycoon 3, Train Fever or other building games. If you like that kind of game, you will enjoy this one in spades. 

Also, last game developers did not add any paid DLC's, all patches were free, and the support last till today, so developers hearts are in the right place, and knowing climate of modern day video gaming, that counts for a lot nowadays.

Also, if anything, the amount of mods and community of the last game came to this game, and from my experience, with the amount of mods that other game had, this will most likely have same dedication of moders.

This review might sound bias, but honestly, I can't say a single bad word about Dev's or Community behind this game. Last one gave me countless hours of fun, and this one by the looks of it will not come short...

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I dident play much yet, but compared to Transport Fever 1 then the graphics are better, and there are many nice new features.

Example you can upgrade buildings and even combine passenger and cargo stations together. This is nice so you can build better looking stations. It work in such a way you can install modules to the sides of a station a bit building with lego.
You can also expand your stations quite easy.

The campaign act as a little bit of a tutorial. In general the missions are good all though the first 2-3 missions feel rather simple.
I have not had any problems with stability or speed of the game but i also dident play long enough to get a big transport  empire.

- The little negative i do feel like the new UI is a little more difficult to use than the old one, example to attach a wagon to an excisting train you need to click a wrench to edit a train, while in TS1 you could just drag and drop a new wagon.
- The route system is more or less the same, but it look different to be honest i liked the old one better.
That was a bit more intuiative.
- The music is annoying ( turn it off, no big deal )

All in all a new Transport Fever 2 game that i can recommend so far.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Important changes compared to previous version:
- better multicore usage
- more road types (one direction)
- possible to keep current year/era forever
- you can connect industry directly to train station, without using roads (just place it very close)

Still missing:
- better rail/road placing system (place and bend like in Railroad corporation)
- some king of draft/planning mode
- tools for easier tunnel bridge building
- no new goods/industries in default climate

Is it worth paying for upgrade from TpF1? Probably not. It makes more sense to buy if you don't have previous version(s).

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
As a player of Transport Fever 1 and a general fan of Transport Tycoon style games, I have to say I'm disappointed in this sequel. The improvements offered are mainly presentational in nature, like graphics, maps or campaign. Things I do not much care for. While none of the core gameplay improvements I hoped for materialised.

Edit: Updating my review to include some info shared by IraRock. Apparently factories no longer consider supply and demand when accepting raw materials. Allowing the player to transport raw materials to a factory that never exports anything for a profit in perpetuity. This is extremely broken and not how it worked in Transport Fever 1. In TF1 you had to manage the whole supply chain and you could only transport raw materials based on how many finished products were being sold. I personally didn't mind the other changes to industry that much, but this is wildly off mark and broken.

Trains were the main focus in Transport Fever 1 and continue to be the main focus in Transport Fever 2. This is not a bad thing necessarily, but other forms of transportation feel even more neglected in this sequel. I focused on shipping on my first game and found that the game mechanics don't really favor ships. Passenger ships generally don't work at all or are condemned to run at an heavy loss. Cargo ships work better, but are highly conditional as there is no garantee there is a viable route accessable by water and it seems like for the same volume they cost significantly more than trucks or trains. I didn't try airplanes yet, but road vehicles work pretty much the same as before.

Then I tried using trains and found that train track maintenance has been increased massively. The double track passenger line that I set up, like I usually do to start off, ended up running at a 100k monthly loss just because the tracks maintenance feels like it's several times what it used to be.

Overall the tracklaying has not been improved. You still place down a blueprint when building tracks that you can then accept or reject, similar how it works in other games like Railroad Empire. However unlike Railroad Empire, in Transport Fever you can only lay down a blueprint for a single segment and you can't use waypoints and can only modify the beginning and the end point and the elevation at the endpoint. This is the same for TF1 and TF2. Using this system building long and complex tracks is very tedious and requires constant saving and loading unless you want to lose large amounts of money deleting and rebuilding tracks. This becomes even more tedious when bridges, tunnels or intersections are involved as the tracklaying becomes even more fiddly and costly. This is one of the issues I was hoping would be improved on the most, but from gameplay videos I was already suspecting it wouldn't be.

In addition it seems like lines can still only use a single terminal/station line, even Railroad Empire has managed to implement something as basic as vehicles choosing to use an empty terminal instead of insisting on using a specific terminal.

The map size feels a little better and doesn't feel quite as cramped as TF1 was, but building train junctions is still problematic. Road building doesn't seem to be greatly improved, it's still very basic.

I'm not a big fan of the new UI. There's more clicking and more menus or tabs to go through. Line management and info is now divided into three menus. It's generally harder to find information. And the general design is even more boring, imitating the all too common boring minimalist flat design used everywhere nowadays.

Overall I'd say that if you have Transport Fever 1 then you're not going to lose much by giving this one a miss. If you're new to Transport Fever or transport management games it comes down to what you're looking for. TF does offer some complexity other might not have, even if it might not do it very well, and good graphics, but there are transport management games that are more accessible and that are more specialised.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Some people are condemning the game as a small upgrade of TPF1, I disagree. The games share the same engine, however TPF2 is having some significant improvement on the gaming experience over TPF1, which nonetheless is a very good and fully functional game.
The models of buildings are new and are even more beautiful. Game engine is improved and graphics is refined. Stations, docks can now be customized, which is a wonderful feature, although I always experience lag, even game crash when customizing a dock. Terrain is now truly editable. An in-game map editor is available and it has the feature of importing a height map, allowing player to create realistic map. 
The campaign has some interesting story telling, but less challenging since budget is no longer a concern.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After a short time of playing, this is my initial impressions about Transport Fever 2 compared to Transport Fever 1.

[h1] Economy [/h1]
[b] The Good [/b]
I really like the improvements to clarity on how demand and supply works. In the first game, this was confusing at times to understand why there were seemingly random fluctuations in demand. Being able to clearly see a building's Production, shipment, and transport is a real improvement.  Also a huge improvement is the seemingly instant recognition of a new transport line. In the first game, it was always a rough start at the beginning of a map having to wait for buildings to start production and for passengers to accumulate. 

I also like how towns now show their progress and what you can do to improve the size of the town. The clarity is extremely helpful and can help shape a town how you want. 

[b] The Bad [/b]
While I like the improvements to understanding the economy, I feel it was been greatly dumbed down. Towns now only accept 2 types of cargo? This seems way too simplified. I liked how in 1 there was a demand for every product so I could have the freedom to choose where to start. Not only that, it makes little sense that every building in the town has only 1 need. This means I have no reason to create cargo hubs like I did in the first game, as every town needs something different. 

I had also wished for more complex industry in Transport Fever 2 over the first game, instead I got the opposite. The only good thing is that oil now makes more sense, having to ship it to a Oil refinery and then to a Fuel refinery is a welcome improvement... However, nothing new was added and some complexity, such as buildings having multiple choices for input, was removed. Farms, for example, now only produce grain. Bakeries only accept grain. It was nice having both livestock and grain options. Same for Stone and tools, being able to select multiple was nice.  I was also hoping for some new industries to make things more interesting. 

[h1] Management [/h1]
I only have good things to say about the management improvements. I am going to just quickly list everything that i like. 
* Finance Table and Chart
* New Vehicle Manager that lets you clone and upgrade vehicles
* Changes to how Condition and Maintenance works
* Line Statistics

[h1] Building [/h1]
Building and running lines, more or less is the same, which is fine since Transport Fever 1 mechanics worked great. However, the addition of modular stations is by far a welcome addition to the game. No more fiddling around in smaller towns having both a passenger and a cargo station separate. The only criticism I have here is the lack of curved stations, at least from what I can tell so far. 

[h1] Graphics [/h1]
Not a whole lot here has changed, but the game looks pretty good already. The UI facelift is a good improvement. Overall, the graphics are in a pretty good place.

[h1] Other Thoughts [/h1]
I REALLY like the free map creator. Its is great that I can preview a map before jumping into it. I really like games that give you choices like the new map creator does. This is a great improvement over the first game, particularly the Desert and Tropical maps. 

The introduction of Asian trains is a nice addition. I always wondered why they were not there in the first game, despite them have a great variety as well. 

The changes to how time works is, imo, a fantastic change. I can 'pause' time but still keep running. It looks like income is now real-time based instead of based around the in game time. This makes it particularly useful if I want to make a map that is purely stuck in the 1900s for a long time or I want to slowly transition between eras at my own pace. Alternatively, this change gives me the ability to speed through eras if I choose. A very welcome change over having to 'mod' the game to slow time down. 


I may update this review as I play more.  I only have 17 hours in the game, so I have not really hit everything there is to know.

 Disappointed in TF2. As some of the other reviews state, there is little  new game play. The developers made some very questionable design decisions with TF2.

If you want a challenge in hard difficulty free mode, stick to Transport Fever1.

There is a lot of good things with Transport Fever 2, but the UI changes, graphics changes feels mostly like a DLC release.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After having played just under 15 hours, I feel a bit disappointed.
5 years in and the some of the main culprits still haven't been properly taken care of. Factories still can't balance the production output evenly between two chains, resulting in production losses in one chain and almost complete lack of production in the other. The engine feels the same and it would seem that the devs still haven't learned much from the community, leaving much of the work to the modders instead (no overpasses, curved stations etc). Why on earth is the auto-replacement gone? It used to be possible to just click on the line in order to replace all vehicles, now it can only be found in vehicle management window. To make things worse, required line needs to be selected before the vehicles are chosen individually. Makes sense if only the oldest vehicles need replacing, but there is no info about the age of them there! It's on another window and it's just a descriptive information instead of the actual age. Why the change?
Fair do's, the graphics has been greatly improved, the free play map preview is a plus, campaign mode looks interesting at first glance, some of the production issues have been addressed and modular stations are a huge change for better. I haven't had any issues placing level crossings, switches, bridges or tunnels, so good job on that one too.

Looking forward to the updates

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have  a couple of hundred hours in TP1.  The base game/concept is solid, and I happily forked out the 50 bucks to own and play it.  It has, over the years, become even more awesome by the many assets/mods created through the steam workshop.  These guys/community have secured this games longevity.  TP2 is a repolished/updated version of the same game.  It is great having the streamlined features (that most are mods in TP1), sharper graphics and better optimisation.  

BUT, In saying that anyone who owns TP1 should not have to pay another 50 bucks for it.  Maybe $15 - $20 max.  Fair enough if you have not purchased TP1 you would be happy to pay 50 or 60 for the latest version of the game.

I feel a bit ripped off....
But, its just a game and I will get over it... I know have to wait until all the mods are ported/created for this version of the game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Over all I would recommend the game. Though it does have a lot of downsides as well as a lot of changes from the previous game that I have yet to determine whether I find them to be better or worse. But on the whole the game mostly improves from the previous game. Following are noncomprehensive lists of some of the more notable pros and cons that come to mind.

The positives:
-It is visually much better in my opinion. Better lighting. So much more and varied flora in the environments and the addition of fauna as well. Not only are the graphics better but the camera options let you view the game in ways you couldn't in the previous game. Such as the ride along camera which you can now fully control rather than being stuck looking forward at all times.

-Map creation is much improved. Not only is there a map editor in the game now but when just randomly creating a new game you have a lot more options you can choose to customise it, and you are given a preview of the map before wasting time generating a map you don't like. Each environment type, Europe, America, and the new Tropical, each have a different set of map generation parameters this time so that you can choose from much more varied random generations. In the previous game the map generation was identical between environment types. The only thing it changed was the ground textures and the tree/bush varieties.

-Modular stations. Although the implementation of this feature seems a bit rough around the edges it still adds a lot of customisation to the functionality of stations, as well as to simply the look and size of stations. Perhaps the biggest functional improvement this feature adds is allowing truck and bus/tram stations the ability to have multiple entry and exit points, and this allows for far more vehicles using the stations before causing traffic congestion.

-Connection paths that connect buildings/stations to each other and to roads. Previously you always needed to connect a station to another station or a station to an industry by having a piece of road connecting them. Now you can simply place them close together and little direct paths will be created between them, connecting them. This now allows you to connect a train station for instance directly to an industry from any side of the industry with no roads involved.

-The addition of cargo planes. Which I'm not a big fan of when it comes to transporting raw resources simply because it seems silly to me. But for transporting finished goods it is an interesting new addition to the game. 

-New vehicles. Having a larger variety of vehicles is always nice. Granted you could always get new vehicles from the modding community, but having officially added, high quality and (supposedly) properly balanced new vehicles are always nice to see.

-Traffic lights and one way roads. The addition of traffic lights will finally allow us to avoid particularly congested intersections from getting grid locked as would occur in the previous game. One way roads allow for a lot more customisation of the road network in general such as the ability to make proper highways for instance.

Changes:
-Town growth now works on a modifier mechanic which allows the player to clearly see just what and how to improve the size of a town. With the new system supplying cargo now can have a much more meaningful impact on town growth compared to the previous game. And there are negative modifiers that come from having congested road traffic,  from emissions and from overcrowded stops/stations. So it is now about maximising the positive modifiers and minimising the negative modifiers to achieve maximum town growth. Though this new mechanic comes with a fairly significant downside which I mention further down.

-Cargo chains and supply ratios have been altered. For the most part all raw resources are consumed on a 2 to 1 ratio now, with the exception of stone quarries. This definitely changes the way you might setup your networks as it becomes much more difficult to setup lines where your vehicle is full in both directions in order to maximise profit. Machine and Tool factories are now separate factories and have been given just a single recipe each. The Fuel chain is now a 3 step process instead of just 2 steps. Towns now only accept 2 randomly chosen (during map generation) finished products rather than all towns requiring all finished products.

-Cargo supply mechanics have been changed. Now you can, starting from the raw resource industries, supply cargo to industries in the next step of the chain without the need for completing the chain all the way to the towns. But only upto the minimum consumption level of the next industry in the chain. To upgrade the consumption level of the industries still requires actually finding and supplying for the demand of the products the intermediate industries make. On the one hand this is a simplification of the mechanics of the previous game making it easier. However on the other hand, because of the other changes to supply and consumption ratios along with the reduced options when it comes to supplying finished goods to towns, the new simplification to production seems to help balance out the added difficulties.

Negatives:
-The changes to the UI seem to be, for the most part, bad. In part it may be due to simply being used to the previous game. However there are definitely downsides such as having to click on more things on a regular basis to get the info you may want or to do certain functions. Opening certain windows causing certain other windows to automatically close that you didn't want closed and things like that. The minor improvements made seem to just be outweighed by the negatives in my opinion.

-Town growth and size. Though towns can visually grow vertically more easily than before, the actual footprint of the towns seems smaller and the size the towns can grow to has been greatly restricted. Because of the new modifier system that determines town growth, towns are now always growing relative to their original size since the modifiers are based on the original size of the town. If a town starts with a population of 50 than acquiring a 200% total positive modifier means the town will increase up to 150pop. Where as a town that starts with a population of 200 that acquires a 200% total positive modifier will increase up to 600pop. In the previous game all towns could potentially reach any size and the cap on size was far greater and more open ended.

-Ground works. When building you will often either cut into the ground or build elevated embankments of ground. This now automatically reverts to it's original state when a construction is removed. This leads to considerable expense and annoyance for me. The cost associated with these cuts and embankments is considerable and now if you want to demolish a section of road and relay it a bit differently you have to repay for the entirety of the ground works involved rather than just the difference from the changes made.

There is a considerable amount more I could say but I have run out of space. Suffice to say that I think the game overall is an improvement and adds a number of core changes to the game to spice things up a bit from the previous game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I love TF1, but this game is not for me:

- Oversimplified UI which hides a lot of the interesting detail from the user. 
- Still no fix for the bad colour choices and the hidden detail when you go into particular modes. For instance, if you want to pick a specific cargo from one place and you go to planning a route mode the cargo icons disappear from the factories. 
- Really weird politics in the scenarios that highlight a lack of diversity in the dev team.
- Economy aspects of TF1 toned down and are less interesting.

What would be better if they used the upgraded graphics engine on TF1 and sold that as an upgrade. I would buy it and continue to run TF1.

Very disappointed with this game and refund requested.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The new game has improved many things over the old version. The graphics have been improved. The shading has been improved. The fluidity of the framerates is smooth if you have a good high end PC and GPU.  The new map editor is fantastic but glitchy.  Having to import my old mods into a community created converter to get it to work in the new game is a little of an annoyance but they did  that because they changed over to FBX support for mods. The model editor included with the games files is supposed to let novice modders create their own mods if they know how to make 3D Models in applications like Blender.  However the new model editor is having some issues and does not work correctly yet.  

So many improvements, and so much more to discover yet.

Now I just gotta get my mods converted over so I can focus on my new stuff.

For those that asked, no there is no night mode officially but someone has created a mod that gives you that mode, its not a cycle mod tho so its permanently night time all the time its used.

There is some issues with the UI where some windows are permanently affixed to the bottom of the screen (please fix that).  The ability to not edit a train consist once you take the train back to a depot, is annoying as you have to sell your train and create a new one any time you want to make consist changes (please fix that).

The new station editor is genius. You plop modules down around the station to make it larger and to customize it. This time around you can deliver and PICKUP freight at the same station as passengers.

Bus and Truck stations are also customizable, as are airports and ferry terminals.

I can keep going but I have only had a few hours to play it. I am sure my fans want more USA trains so I gotta get back to that stuff.  

Note: Bugs and Performance issues can be fixed. That shouldn't lead one to leave a negative review of the game for that reason nor should they leave one for performance because their computer needs an upgrade. It's just how PC gaming works.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TL:DR

The second iteration of the popular TF1 unfortunately has next to no gameplay enhancements, and objectives, dynamism, and real-world simulations are entirely absent. The failure to better model real-world economics and transport systems turns what would be a brilliant production into a very average one. One places down routes and purchases vehicles and watches these move all over the map, but the failure to create dynamic structures for how these routes then play out completely ruins the game. 

I spent 500+ hours in TF1 to enjoy the modelling of my own beautiful train set. TF2 was supposed to be about creating a real-world transport empire, as close to scale as modern technology and hardware allows. Unfortunately this has failed utterly.

Cons
- Re-skin of TF1. Particularly, the vehicles have all simply been copied and pasted over with no changes (even graphically) to these vehicles. 
- Removal of auto-replace of vehicles, making it an absolute chore to go about replacing vehicles every 15 years. 
- Absolutely no adjustments made to industry/town dynamics, meaning towns grow exactly as they had in TF1.
- No dynamism in transport routes. For example, if you set a boat/train etc on a goods transport route, it will make exactly the same profit every single year (with a slight decrease for escalating maintenance costs). There must just be something a little more dynamic. Breakdowns, weather (snow-storms, rain, nature disasters), factory problems, contract requests, changing commodity prices. Just something to alleviate the deadening monotony. 
- First-person camera view of the vehicles is all still the same, and again there is no rolling behaviour synonymous with typical vehicle movement, just the sickening lurches every time the vehicle changes direction. 
- Collisions still happen (i.e. boats etc will still ghost through each other, boats will go through bridges). It's a bit amateurish for $35. 

Pros
- It looks nice, and the products (i.e. steel, wood) look particularly gorgeous when they can be seen. 
- Boat transportation routes seem to be working a little better (at least they make more sense). The increase in water space devoted to the map also means running detailed boating networks is also a little more possible now. 
- The map is larger, which means that towns are not squashed against each other, and there is a better feeling of space. 
- As a digital version of building one's own railroad and train set, this is still the go-to product to alleviate that itch. It is wonderful to watch trains rolling lazily through the countryside, and to watch passengers move around.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After a few minor bugs dealing with textures, (I was getting black textures instead of train tracks. The fix was to delete the texture_cache and let the game recreate it) I've found a lot to love in this game.
I've been playing on the slowest date progression to experience the most out of every era in free play mode and never really find myself wanting for more. Though the end is always in sight, as you can see all production facilities and town needs as soon as you load your first map. That doesn't mean things are easy though, you will have to plan carefully to make sure you can actually pull a profit. I've been playing on medium difficulty, and the game is difficult to manage at first (there was much restructuring as I found lines were losing too much money to bother keeping), but once you get the hang of what you're supposed to be doing, it should be pretty smooth sailing. It's a lot of fun managing how much cash you have to deal with new routes and expand. The game allows the player to influence every aspect of the maps growth. You provide the raw materials in various chain lengths (some goods require a simple 1-1 line, others will require multiple goods shipped for one product, and others will be the child of those multiple line products), and eventually ship them into the towns of your choice, where cities begin to thrive. This will then allow the player to send passengers to various locales. The player has many ways of hurting town growth as well. If the player is too ambitious with their lines, traffic and pollution will drive people away. I've barely touched the campaign mode, but from what I have seen, it features fun quests following the eras that give a little bit more purpose to your transport empire. It is a welcome distraction from optimizing your lines and a great way to introduce the player to the game. 

TLDR: If you love management games, supply chains, or just want to have fun with a few transportation lines, I would recommend giving Transport Fever 2 a try.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After 10+ hours of play on release day, there [i]are[/i] a few critical problems.

The UI is a disaster. Not altogether surprising, since it's been their weakness ever since Train Fever.
The number of different windows to achieve just one action is daft... and exhausting. (setting up a new line; reviewing the progress of a line and making small changes like adding or removing a vehicle)

The interface scaling feature is nice... but makes everything either too small or too big on my rig; seems mad that I might have to buy a new screen to play this game.

The interface colours are the worst of it. So here's one of the best improvements in the game, and how to ruin it:

When creating a consist ([i] le terme technique en Anglais pour la composition du train[/i]) you can now choose loco and wagons BEFORE YOU BUY. You can even see the capacity of the resulting train. You can also see how much it's going to cost. [b]In red, on a pale blue background.[/b] Yes you read that right. Even if you're not colorblind, it's painfully difficult to read. In general, the color choices in the interface are [i]just terrible.[/i] So bad they impact game play.

Worst of all, is the "Winter Wonderland Overlay." When in line management or construction mode, a bright white overlay is added to the whole screen which is both straining to the eyes (with the constant switches in luminance) and also results in inadequate contrast in map features and structures so that, for example, while laying rails, it's [i]harder[/i] to see potential cuts and fills when it should be easier. This seems downright mad... so Given how good Urban Games have been in the past at fixing and improving, I wouldn't be at all surprised if many of the UI problems are fixed in the not too distant future.

I'd also like to bewail the absence of the Company Logo feature. I want to use my gorgeously designed Radiant Railways logo again, dammit!

Finally, the lack of auto-replace (it's been replaced with a "maintenance" feature that isn't a waste of space; it allows a degree of realism, and means you can keep very old rolling stock if you happen to like it, which many transport enthusiasts do) means that vehicle management is even more micro that it was before. Which is okay for trains. But for trams, busses and trucks, kinda tedious.

The stations are mostly awesome, with one exception. Truck stations are still hopeless. Even though they're all modular now (which is great), no matter what you do with terminal placement and entrance and exit configurations, trucks still loop around in a sort of mad dance, and different truck routes cross over and foul each other [b]inside the station[/b]. I created a series of mods for TF1 to solve this. Hoping that I won't have to do it again because I don't like the idea of learning to mod the much more complex modular system. The problem is the same for the tram stations (which are basically the same asset). Fortunately, you can solve the problem by just [b]building several of them side-by-side[/b].

Okay, [b]NOW THE GOOD STUFF[/b]:

1. Industry goods flow predictably, without unexpected and coslty drop-offs in production or inexplicable (or merely incalculable) reasons for routes being too long. The system [i]actually works[/i]. This is a really big improvement. It makes playing with the industry goods feel like goods management rather than an obscure Japanese puzzle game. There's still a glitch with "goods buffering" (looping more than once on the same route with different terminals) that results in a "coals to newcastle" effect; but more testing will show if buffering is even necessary.

1.1 Industry networks are better too, since you have to link more than one primary resource to a secondary or tertiary factory. It makes for a more realistic network, although the placement of industry is still random, so still not terribly realistic. Hoping there will be a "raw resources only" and "industry building" mod combo that will solve the placement issues in the near future (as there already are in TF1).

2. Shipping is economically viable. I haven't had enough time to test whether it's actually competitive with rail for goods transport, but at least it's economically viable and routes that use shipping only don't suddenly stop producing as they did in TF1.

3. YOU CAN MAKE REAL HARBORS, AND EVEN [b]"CANALS"[/b]
Changes to terrain modification mean you can now change shoreline... creating inlets and building realistic-looking ports, along with the modular ports. This is just fantastic. It's also possible to create shipping canals to cut longer journeys short... but very expensive, of course. I'm disappointed that there isn't a full canal system with locks, tunnels, aqueducts, etc. Maybe we can wish for that in an update (or a mod...?).

4. The modular Rail Stations and Ports are a joy. I can't praise them enough. A huge leap forward.

[u][b]In summary:[/b][/u]

Some very big improvements to gameplay. Some UI teething troubles that are a step in the wrong direction but I can't imagine won't be fixed rapidly. Still the same lack of attention to truck stations; but a generally more rounded and complete game than TF1. I'm looking forward to another play session; and also looking forward to editing this review after the first major update... whenever that is.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'm impressed. I’ve experienced some graphical glitches and occasional frame drops, but the modular stations make for an interesting puzzle, I like the strategy added by giving cities two specializations, industry spawn location is improved, and the economics seem better balanced.

If I'm building a cargo station, I may as well build a passenger line, and once I've done that, how do I make the lines share a double track? Then later, a quad-track. Giving each city two specializations provides a lot more focus, too. Instead of finding the shortest route between factories, you must also consider the demand of nearby cities. If you can sell a route to one city, that's OK. If you can sell it to three, you're in the money! The algorithms for factory placement must have been revised, as well. It's relatively easy to find and start a single resource goods route. It gives you more options in 1850 and provides a more logical progression from single to multi-resource routes. I always hated that starting a goods route in 1850 on TpF1 put you on the struggle bus 9/10 times. It seems easier to turn a profit in TF2, but the revised maintenance expenses are a good balance. I have yet to feel like my cash liquidity is running away from me, even after setting up some solid goods lines. Creating a single depot and laying a passing track instead of double track are a lot more important now.

The game is a little rough around the edges on launch week. If that’s going to bother you, check back in a month. Otherwise, it’s a solid improvement over TpF1 with more strategy options. It's easy to lay a route and there's always room for optimization.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Pros and Cons

+ I think the passenger side of the economy seems to be running sweet if you're into that over freight.
- The Industry supply and demand needs some big changes 

Minor bugs:
- When you copy a vehicle it should spawn from the nearest depot instead of the last one you purchased from (this glitch destroys the usefulness of the cool new features for coping vehicles)
- Auto vehicle replacement like TF1 (replacing old vehicles didn't reduce operating expenses)

Re-invented broken wheel:
- 2 x industry demands per city just doesn't work.. it's really boring.. they literately spawn right next to the industry they need too
- Max Industry output of 400 is only good for 2 young cities :(even on hard setting they're conveniently spawned really close):  
- MORE INDUSTRIES!!!!! Surely the TF1 mods and many comments asking for it would get that up there on the build list RW Tycoon was awesome for it... Loved that game 

The whole micro sized industry with little tiny rail networks and little tiny workshops the biggest let down for my preferred play style.. for now. Someone has already attempted to fix the spawning issue using a mod but the lack of scaling up production and sending goods far and wide is still just a dream 

Hope they open up the full demands asap 


Pros over TF1 
- no waiting for new lines to say yes for connection  (If everything is connected, everything runs straight away)
- managing lines and vehicles is so much better. 
- all the other stuff in the trailers you also thought was cool
- It does feel like a really good starting point for the game.. Probably a little behind schedule when they released it. If the modding community is half the size of TF1 it will still get there with our without devs 

IDK why so many people are saying it crashes heaps.. this UP TO DATE COMPUTER hasn't missed a beat 

Saying it's a bad copy of TF1 is a going a bit far... These people are probably into COD though haha. 

Hopefully this game will get much better with MODs and hopefully we get some patches asap!

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I am a bit on the fence with this one. As someone who only recently got TF1, I really enjoyed it and thought it was laid out in a logical way. Whilst the new game is a major improvement in terms of graphics, I am not sure the UI has improved and if anything it is more complicated to navigate. Also, a number of features from the first game have been removed which (to me) makes the UI seem more clumsy. An example is setting up a new line. In TF1 you could do this from the same screen as the buying vehicles screen. In the new game they are two separate processes. Merging trains / carriages is another omission from the first game. Also, it does need a bit of optimisation to get it running more smoothly with a number of people having issues in terms of frame rates. On the whole, I can recommend this game and I expect a number of patches will be forthcoming to address some of the issues.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Yes! at 27h in game (+1085h in TF1)

it takes a few hours to get used to the new user interface, in fact I think the TF1 UI was a bit more polished, but this game is just released so I'm sure we'll be seeing patches or mods for this in the future.

Functionality is great, hardly any bugs, and none of them game braking:
- maintenance feature needs polishing, it's currently worth ignoring.
- occasional bug where road vehicles wait too early for a railway crossing, causing traffic jams.
- silver ore does not show in the railway trucks (campaign mode)
- HUD filter icons for cost and income are reversed

my favourite new features:
- Terrain texturing! I'ts great to make the place look pretty (for free) whilst waiting for cash to roll in.
- Ride along cam in improved. you can now ride first person and adjust the camera with mouse.
- Grass, wildlife, improved water effects make the place look stunning.
- Terrain modifier now allows to dig canals of navigable water.

All in all a worthy successor of TF1.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I think its a little weird how negative some people are being about this title.

If you're new to the series, this is a fine one to buy.  It's a great game.  Most of the fanboi meltdown is because it's just not a massive leap forward from the previous game.   So they aren't recommending it even though they like it just fine and are just a little bent that it didn't make all their digital train set dreams come true.

And I agree, its not a huge leap forward, I do think the devs really dropped the ball on an opportunity to move it forward a few steps.  But it is every bit as good as the previous and looks better, and is a little more refined (but still kinda clunky).

Maybe the discount for owners of the previous one should have been a little deeper, maybe that would have chilled them a little.

Anyhow, all that said... It's good, its got some balance issues that I hope the devs will address going forward, its a little too hard in some ways in the very early game and quickly becomes too easy.  Once you understand the differences in the rhythms between this one and the previous, you break through it really fast.

The music in the first one was far superior.

Anyhow, if you're a previous owner, you're getting the previous version with some nicer graphics and a few new tricks.  And if you've never played before, buy this one, the previous one will feel pretty old right out of the box.  Even this one isn't exactly this weeks technology.   But if you like this type of game, you'll enjoy it.  It's more of a sandbox than a game you try to win anyhow, so most of that balance stuff doesn't matter anyhow... It's a digital train set, and nobody wants to fight with their train set, they just want to build it and watch it... And thats easy to do in this.

I haven't seen any bugs or performance issues, but I'm running pretty new equipment, so YMMV.

Transport Fever 2 is better than its predecessor. Modular stations take the pain out of planning and expansion and is a fantastic addition to the game. I have also found trains to be a little smarter than in TF and I have enjoyed creating large networks on the freeplay maps. The added map editor (I haven't played with it much yet) looks to change the way I play as I can now create custom maps with focused industries and cities.  I would have liked to see a few more features and content but we have the workshop for that. 
I'm really enjoying TF2 and I think its worth a try if you've played the previous or if you are looking for a good transport game. 
I also haven't experienced any crashes or major bugs.

A burden because I really like to complexity of having to get lots of industries to a city. Though it is easier to get all cities/towns supplied now...

Pro's- Graphics and interface are good. The ability to manage lines and buy vehicles took some getting used to but I would find it hard to go back now....

The biggest PRO is the stations, I love the feature of being able to combine different types...

Overall.. Great game... Many hours playing to go...

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I'm disappointed. While the new game adds some new features like station configuration, those are very small changes.
I'm not really excited about new terrain. It's less important for me than lack of new features. 
I don't see new industries, we still can produce and refine same shit. How about paper? How about gold, jewels? Post? Don't see it. Production industries now cannot be extended. Only refinery industries get updates.
No improvements in transport: one line may only utilize one platform. Train tracks also haven't got any attention, those still have the same problems from the first game.
New features buggy too. You have to juggle with one way entrances and exits before your lines stop looping in the station.
They also killed nice transport autoupdate mechanics. Now you need to track every single one transport unit in order to update it (because bulky update will lead to unnecessary updates of newer vehicles).
Adding to new bugs, there are some issues with sounds overcome music, also game is unstable and sometimes may crash.
Don't think any of my concerns will be addressed any time soon, so I wouldn't recommend buying this game right now. It's just Transport Fever v1.1, not v2 for sure.

Carefully planning each line and service and managing the capacity on each service is a bit tedious at times but enjoyable. Love the soundtrack too. I am using an i3 processor 16gb ram, GTX 1070 graphics and I have very few performance problems. Usually runs at a solid 60-90fps and it dips in intense situations or adjusting lines/stops. There are some annoying bugs but overall, very solid game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
After I turned off vsync and the game runs a lot better. And I must say I'm hooked. It plays away like TTD used to. The campaign is really well done and highlights some historic moments. Changed my thumbs down in a thumbs up. Wish the developers wouldn't force on vsync to begin with. The first impression could've been a lot better.

---

Edit: I've changed the resolution down to 1080p and switched off vsync in settings.lua. This results in a somewhat stable 50 FPS with 2xAA. I'll keep playing around with this (and different scenarios in the game) and report back here.

Looked forward to this title after I watched Squirrel play it for a bit. Unfortunately tho, this suffers from the same issue as Transport Fever 1 (and Train Fever for that matter): bad performance.

My specs:
Intel i5-8600K
NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1050 Ti (probably the culprit here)
16 GB of DDR4 @ 2,666GHz
1440p monitor

With the default setting of everything on high I get 20 FPS. With everything turned to the lowest I get a somewhat steady 30 FPS. The highest I've seen it go is 48 FPS but that was at the edge of the map without much of the map in view. I'll see if changing the resolution does anything. But from what I read on the forums it's the same for people with a RTX 2060.

Other than the performance this is a great title. I already had a bunch of fun in the few minutes I played. But I will probably refund this one until I get a better GPU. I suggest you only get this if you either have a better setup or don't mind underwhelming performance.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Brilliant game!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
(Review for those who haven't played TF1 at the bottom)

This isn't a reskin, despite what other comments are saying. 

Terrain and coast modification is better. (As in, you can actually modify coast). There's a map editor. More varieties of map. Extra props etc. There's also a terrain painter by default.

There's been some UI improvements, and the station customisation is far better. (No bendy stations yet though, which is a shame. But that was a mod.)

There's a greater variety of vehicles, far greater, by default. 

The graphics in general are radically improved, although I can see the arguments for reskin here as some of the improvements are rather subtle. 

The Music and sound is also better/less repetitive. 

City growth is far simpler, and easier to understand and manipulate. 

There's no more annoying triangles, and glitches. Things are working a lot smoother snapping wise, which is hard to notice without going back and playing TF1 and realising how prevalent that was. 

The big, negative change, is cargo distribution. Cities now only accept 2 goods, as opposed to all 6 like TF1. This means that if there are no industries that supply a town near it, you end up making massive huge truck chains in order to even break even, as Trains are very expensive and can no longer supply multiple towns. 

This also means that once you're done with those, you're done. No towns want more items. So you can hit the point where it's not worth making any more things, due to distance, and you're making money hand over fist so can't be bothered.

There has been some balancing, between consumption and production, but overall that is the one resounding negative change. The UI being nonsensical is sort of the same as the last game. 

Overall, so far, I would recommend this. But bare in mind it does *feel* like TF2, even if under the hood there's a lot of subtle improvements. 

For those who haven't played TF1:

This is OTTD but for the modern age. It has a slight difference of forcing things along lines, but that's kind of it. Cities need supplies and passengers, you send those supplies and passengers. You build the rails, more roads, the trams, the trucks, you create intricate transport networks, and by the time you finally fully connect a city it's 2am and you have work in the morning. 

However, if you're debating it, buy Transport fever 1. It's cheaper, and you'll see if you like this kind of game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
It looks absolutely wonderful, but in all honesty, that's about it. The new menus are intensely frustrating. You need to open several different windows to do anything and even then, you often can't find what you want to do. 

Running anything is phenomenally expensive, but trains are a joke. I was doing fine - although progress was painfully slow - until I added a train and next thing I know, I'm making a huge loss. Ended up selling my ships running passengers between islands and eventually sold the trains too. Later tried adding trains again, but hit big problems trying to shift freight as the wagons want to only load and unload logs, even though I filtered to just picking up and delivering bricks. Seems this is the default cargo for those wagons and you cannot change them until you have built the train, assigned it to the line and sent it on it's way, but even though the Line setting shows it is set to pick up only bricks and one station and unload them at another, the train is saying it's cargo is logs, so piles into the station full of bricks and goes out again empty.

The maintenance feature on vehicles is just plain annoying. Changing them so they stay in good condition will send you straight into the red. Ignoring them results in endless pop-ups telling you they are in poor condition and your towns won't grow.

The game is only two days old, so some glitches are expected, but the game itself need a big overhaul to make it playable. Until then, stick to TF1.
