title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I didn't like the first fever and I don't like this one but I gave it a shot anyway.

Pros:
-I like this more than the first Transport Fever
-It's very pretty

Cons:
-No AI to compete with in freeplay mode
-Difficult building placement (Who uses shift+M/N?)
-Can place loading areas next to producers and it will not fill

This is the primary complaint I got against my review of Transport Fever 1 and I'm sure it will be the same here. I didn't play the tutorial. I absolutely hate tutorials and think that games are poorly designed if you have to play the tutorial in order to play them. For example, I've never played the tutorial for Cities:Skylines yet that game is much more user friendly than this game.

The Review:

I was really excited for this game because I've always wanted a game where you can set up your own transport company. Whether it be cargo or people. I didn't enjoy Transport Fever 1 and sadly I didn't enjoy Transport Fever 2 either. My main problems with Transport Fever 2 are the building placements. I was pressing Q, E, left Ctrl, right Ctrl to try turn the building yet nothing was rotating it. I finally gave up and guess maybe I need to click then rotate the building to orient it to the road. Nope. Google the answer and find out its M + N, however the turns are rather large, maybe 15 degrees, find out later that Shift + M/N turn it in smaller frequencies. That's such an odd button combo. When I was playing the game and guessing what buttons turn buildings Q/E didn't seem like a valuable use, infact I played just 12 hours ago and I don't even remember what Q/E did. I'm blown away by the fact that you can't hold down the mouse button, then circle your mouse to orient a building to a road. 

Onto the next problem I was having. I would place my truck pickup spots next to the producers however for some reason they wouldn't pick anything up. I could see they were linked via highlight but for some reason whenever my trucks would come, they would just leave without picking anything up. For some reason I didn't have this issue with trains. I could see that certain types of haulers/cargo carts would pick up certain items but I saw trucks could pick up all cargo and yet they would come and go empty. 

It's a shame because I really want to like this type of game. However just like the first Transport Fever there are lots of minor UI issues where you can't execute what you want to do and are often left scratching your head or googling how to do what you want. I know this review is going to get lots of negative feedback because I refuse to play the tutorial but I judge games on playability. If you have to go through a tutorial to play the game then it isn't very playable in my opinion. Often times in video games goals a very concrete, this game's goal is to make a transport company that delivers good and makes lots of money. However if you just start a game I would argue that is a very difficult goal to achieve. 

TLDR: Better luck with Transport Fever 3/10

The interface is TERRIBLE

YOU CAN'T CREATE A NEW LINE without closing what you're doing to open the line menu. It should work like it did in the first: buy new vehicle > set line > create new line. Easy! 

For the life of me I can't figure out how to add a carriage from the depot to train without buying a new one. There is no ^ arrow to transfer a carriage from the depot menu to the train manager menu. 

 All the station building previews appear stretched.

Will likely refund if no improvements are made and I certainly won't be playing it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Love it! Graphics are fantastic and terrain tools make designing and tweaking maps a breeze. Taken ideas from some of the best mods of TF1 and incorporated into game. title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Well for the players moaning about how it runs, crashes and is a re-skin of TPF1. Don't listen to them. I have had Zero issues since playing. No crashes, glitches or bugs. Runs smooth no slow down no complaints my end. I read the system requirements so knew my PC would run with ease. Amazing reading the system requirements. I suggest the bad reviewers tried that before slating the game. 
Onto the game. Well since Train fever i have loved everything Urban games has brought us in the series. And am very encouraged to see what this title will bring and hopefully future ones. Graphically its beautiful. The new UI and interface took a while to get around. But after 20mins piece of cake. For any veteran tycoon player like myself you really wont struggle to find your way round it. 
I love that the towns spawn in grids to begin with now. So much easier to plan early on how to lay everything. Town bus networks actually make money now. And the cargo system, even though i have not delved too much into that part yet. Being able to find suppliers to industries is such a good feature. Will save so much time looking for that quarry to supply materials to make bricks, goods etc.  And Finally being able to have passenger/cargo trains share the same stations is huge. While not making the map look like a mess with single lines running from point A - B - C then to its own cargo station. 
I could go on further and i have not even touched on the amazing modding community this game has. TPF1 gave us a good 3 years. And i am sure this one will give us many more years. I clocked 300+ Hours on Both TF and TPF. And this one will get as much if not more of my gaming time. 

I think we should all appreciate what the developers are trying to do here. And they have shown us steam players so much loyalty. And not to sell out for "other" platforms. Please don't read the negative reviews and let it be a deal breaker for you. Try the game out if you like it great. If not then review it constructively and not go straight for the developers throat. Try reaching out to them via message boards, email etc. As i have in the past contacted them directly and yep got a response Amazing!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Sadly a lot behind expectations, with some questionable changes and ignorance to a lot of player wishes and mod improvements coming from TpF1.

While there are improvments like modular stations, map editor or the new tropical graphics, this game also makes too many steps backwards (even more so when factoring in the great improvements done by modders). Especially when it comes to UI (even the color palettes are ridiculous limited now, with half of em being ugly selections noone will use), the again dumbed down complexity of the economy (2 random goods per city, incomplete chains being profitable, etc.) and the overall lack of challenge/difficulty. Performance should be better, but I am nowhere near a map and modcollection able to test this claim. 

And its a real shame how they ignored so many improvements modder made, for example integrated lkw terminals in industries or waggons/cars fitting the actual years instead of using something from decades behind/later. Even if own development would have been too much, it would have been extremely easy and profitable for all involved to just licence + integrate such work from modders, but somehow that huge potential was ignored?!

I am sure as with TpF1 many of the issues will once again be fixed by the community and some longwinded patching done over the next years, hopefully the whole complexity and difficulty problem as soon as possible before too many get bored. But that waiting for and keeping up with mods/patches in itself was a rather tedious task already in the old game. It certainly will put off plenty of gamers once again.

As for wishes ignored: No prioritizing trains on signals or other way to allow overtaking when several lines use the same roads/rails. No weather, Night/day/season cyles or other noteworthy dynamic visuals to get some atmosphere ( those flock of birds are a laughable tiny step to take), No immersive differences in cargo quantity, pricing and profits within production chains. No Mapfeature which easily gives a full plan of your networks.

TpF1 was at its limits engine wise for what I build, so thats out of the picture.  ... but as it is now it will take quiet some time for TpF2  to become as good as the old one especially regarding gameplay/content. Cant really bring myself to recommend buying it as it is, such small steps forward together with several backwards dont really justify the price.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
TLDR: Overall a great game, improving on what TF1 did well. 

Transport Fever 2 takes what was good in TF and improves it a lot more. The new system of town needs actually makes you choose better where you spend your money, in order to fulfill the towns commercial or industrial needs. Also, the graphic improvements are a welcome sight. The new map maker system is also a great addition, since now we can see the map to be created by the seed we input. 

Station construction is amazing, giving you the chance to make realistic machine yards, several platforms for cargo and passengers, and also a central rail for high speed express trains. I loved this the most.

I didn't see the industries I saw on the tutorials (like coffee, for example) so here's wishful thinking for that in the future. Also, raw resources like grain, crude oil or similar do not evolve over time, they just reach the cap and that's it, which means you have to supply a processing industry (like a bakery or an oil refinery) with resources from more than one production field. Maybe mods will tweak this in the future.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
As a player of Train Fever and Transport Fever I'm a big fan of the franchise. And I'd say this is a good addition to the series.

This game is one day old while i'm writing this, it's not perfect yet. The game does crash time to time.

The game in general really is a prettier Transport Fever with some stuff being better and some worse. 

7/10 for now.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: A lot of improvements from TF 1, but at the same time you can feel it's the same game. Recommended!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
As many other fans have, I too waited eagerly for Dec 11th and Transport Fever 2. I loved the first one. The depth and realisim of it all. I love city builders and I love managment games and I really love vehicles. So this game is a top notch match for me. 

And as a sequel, I assumed that it will have all those futures that the first game had, and even more and better. But that's not really the case here. You see, for some reasons the devs decided to take out, or just simply forgot (?), to put it into the game. Eg. the automatic vehicle replacement. How they could possibly forget such a important part of the game does blow my mind. 
Another annoying thing for me is how they re-worked the supply and demand chain. For example, in the first game, if you had a line from a farm to a food processing plant you didn't gain any money for it because the plant couldn't sell the food they were making. So, for to be able to have an income, you also needed to have a line from the plant to a nearby town which in turn needed the food to grow. So in other words, you always needed to take the supply and demand in considiration. If there is no buyer for a product, then the factory don't want the raw product either because they cannot sell the end product. But here, in TF2, that is no longer the case. Here you can simply take the grain to the plant and have a huge income. The plant simply store all that grain.. or maybe throws it out in the garbage? Who knows.. This simply isn't realistic for me and it also makes the game very, very simple and easy. Not that TF 1 was hard. 

Other things, which on the other hand is the other way around, like the traffic lights were missing from the first game now are in this one, which is nice. Specially in later stages in the game when the cities grow bigger. If I will  remember other things I'll write it down.

The story missions are pretty fun, better then in the first game. Altough I have only completed the first chapter.

Visually it's much more pretty, for sure. Even on low setting. The vehicles have high detail with trains haveing moving parts, which I find cool. It's really nice eye candy to have. I do enjoying take a ride with some of my trains and just enjoy the scenery.  

But, in the end, it doens't feel like a sequel to me. It also doesn't feel like a dlc to me, but rather like it's TF 1.5.
It was nice from the devs for giving me 25 % off since I owned the first game, but even tho I think it is really on the edge price wise. Because these thinks that I've described, I don't think it should be 40 euros. More like half. IF they decide that they put in those features and fix the whole supply and demand system than maybe. 

So in summery, I do recemmend this game soley for being a fan of this game series and still love the game for what it is. 
But the fact is, that I'm dissapointed in these things so if there is some new players who wanted to try it out, but doesnt know which one to go for, then I would say go for the first one. Sure, the graphics are a little worser but it has more depth to it with proper functions which makes the game harder.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: The graphics on this game are incredible for the size of maps, and the Dev's did a great job with the game mechanics for the population movement (from town to town). The game is definitely worth the cost if you like city builder style games.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2

I thought the two manufactured items per city would be a deal breaker, but I am enjoying the challenge and find it to be a great logistical challenge.  Excellent Game that offers hours of fun.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
This would rather be my first "meh" review.

It's just a reskin of the first transport fever. The bad game design is still there, only this time it looks prettier. It looks meaty, as the first one did, but it really isn't.

Mashinsky does trains better, Cities Skylines does everything else better and it even isn't it's main purpose.

Open TTD is free and does all this way better as well. If you're looking for your really good simulator game fix, this isn't it.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Great game. I've never played a transport, or any other, tycoon game because they never really appealed to me. This game caught my eye on Youtube so I thought I'd give it a go. I'm so glad I did. As a noob to this type of game I thought that I might struggle to balance the books. I shouldn't have worried. The campaigns taught me everything I needed to know, being left to scratch my head only a couple of times because it didn't give me quite enough detail on where to find certain things that I was meant to build (the headquarters being one such time) 

iI thought that I was losing money, but I just had to relax and take things easy, allowing the routes that I'd set up to bed in and start making money as they got up to full steam. 

The visuals are lovely and the game runs smooth without any stutter with settings up max on my modest HP Pavilion Laptop with i7 9th gen cpu and a 1660gtx ti with 6gb of vram and 8gb on board. I know some people have complained about CTD and black screens instead of the maps, but after about 6 hours of playing so far I have encountered zero problems whatsoever. 

I recommend this game if you're sitting on the fence, it's fun and addictive.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: This is a fantastic game. I haven't played it for very long but it's already fun. I can tell I'm gonna waste many hours on this stuff.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Divine!

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I love simulation games especially build games.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Really impressed by the many small changes that have made a great game much more enjoyable!

First of all - the graphics and UI dialogs have gotten a much deserved overhaul. The base game was great before - but very confusing and annoying to work with. The UI dialogs are now in AAA class - instead of feeling rather dated in TF1. Some part of it can be seen as eye candy - but the main change in all the dialogs is the clever way that the user experience has been improved. Now everything that in the "end game" felt really tedious is so much easier... Replace that rackety old train is a breeze now... The thing you do a lot like jumping from a line, to a train, to a depot and back to add or replace vehicles etc is now so much smarter. A lot less dialogs popping around making a train purchase or similar a lot easier.

The overlays now look almost as good as Cities Skylines (and that game is almost too good ;)). I also like the added clarity of supply / demand etc that makes it a lot easier to see who demands the goods from one of you raw material sources etc. 

Another great thing is the "configure" option for stations etc. Being able to add a passenger platform or another cargo building is great as having two stations (passenger + cargo) in a small town feels awkward. 

The only thing I feel is a bit lacking is the track laying tool that feels almost like TF1. It would be nice to be able to add multiple bending points when laying a track, so that you could add a small bend and tweak that track to see the whole layout before pressing "buy". Now you can still end up having to bulldozer that last bit because it was a bit to tight in the end. A good minor fix though is the arrows for the signals that makes it a lot easier to see that you did put that signal on the right side ot the track!

Summary - some may feel that it is rather similar to TF1 in the core game play - but that is a good thing! And the annoying UI / UX is so much better!

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have not played the first Transport Fever, which made watching previews and reviews of this title annoying because many of them focused on the differences, which I didn't really care for.

The core game loop is fun and interesting. The logistics sim seems quite good, and the modular station building is very useful for growing your logistics network over time. My initial impressions are good over-all, and I anticipate spending quite a lot of time with this title. I expect that the Workshop will be integral to the game's longevity. If you liked Rise of Industry and Railway Empire but felt that they lacked a certain something, like I did, check out Transport Fever 2. It blends a lot of the interesting aspects of those games and adds a lot more to the pot.

I love the sense of technological progress over time, as your various modes of transport become redundant, replaced by newer, better models, and your logistics efficiency improves in kind. I don't recall another game which captured this in quite the same way. Nice work.

There are a number of minor annoyances at launch, such as the lack of "fullscreen windowed" display mode, cloud saves weren't working as of this morning, the fastest game speed isn't very fast which results in long periods of waiting for things to happen (in the early campaign at least), and the windows/dialogues seem like they could use a good thorough UX pass.

Some elements of game play are hidden in weird ways. For example, to get into a pure sandbox mode, it's necessary to go into custom settings in a Free Game and enable certain mods. That was not clear from the start. It's more typical to have Sandbox available directly from the main menu.

That said, I also had several other items on my list which were patched in day 1 (such as inverting mouse controls). The developers are responding quickly to feedback, so if you're hesitant, check back in a week.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: This game is horrible. It looks bad, runs slow, and is fiddly as all hell. Play Open TTD for free if you want something better.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Even at low setting it looks reasonably good at full HD.
However it should be called Transport Fever 1.5.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I wanted to like this game, but can't.   This is really TF1 with a better graphics engine.  I don't have the crashing issues that others have but I have a high end CPU/GPU/memory. 

1.  The focus is on trains, which I like.  But the train AI is extremely poor with the trains unable to use empty station platforms.  The routing of trains with signals is horrible.
2. You can deliver all the raw materials you want to a factory, and you'll get paid for it.  But the factory will not produce a good unless the rest of the supply line is complete.  Therefore you can't "pre-load" the factory and buy the truck/train/etc when there is sufficient goods to deliver.  
3.  It is just about transport, you can't purchase the industry to help with funding your network.
4.  The costs associated with maintaining the train system is huge.
5.  The user interface is a major step backward.
6.  Step out of the campaign and into the sandbox/open and the it gets worse.  

Since the focus is on trains, I'm just surprised that it can't beat the user interface/depth/fun of an extremely old game like Railroad tycoon.  

I hope it gets better with patches...

title: Transport Fever 2
review: (Edit: I wanted to preface this review as a "reluctant" negative recommendation.  I, like many, pre-ordered TF2 and had very high hopes.  However, aside from a bit more flash and people who are no longer scanning the skies for meteors while waiting for their train, this second version of one of my favorite titles of all time, left me feeling a bit let down.)  Modular stations and a map editor.  That's pretty much it for TF2.  Overall I'm pretty disappointed.  Same old vehicles as version 1, albeit a few more planes.  Same pathetic horns that sometimes work, sometimes not.  Panning with keyboard gets stuck after some menus and you have to use the mouse to "reactivate" key movement.  But, we do have grass now!  (eyeroll).  I must say that I DO very much like the one-way roads and highways with ramps, which will undoubtedly offer countless opportunities for creatively mitigating traffic.  It's just not enough to pry me away from TF1 with it's environment mod, the hundreds of custom vehicles, etc.  So, after just 5 hours with TF2, I'll be going back to TF1 - and to cities that (more realistically) accept more than just 2 cargo types.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I played TF 1 for over 1200 hours so it is fairly safe to say that I was a fan. 

TF2 seems to offer some great improvements, especially in the game mechanics. TF 1 if you played on Hard it was a grind, you could make money but you had to be really careful with every line.  Some lines were always losers like internal bus routes and there was a lot of guesswork on where the demand was for.  Boats and Planes were generally unworkable/unbalanced. 

In TF2 so far it looks like it is much more balanced, I'm playing on hard and internal routes are profitable, and boats seem viable.
I was initially concerned that reducing to only 2 products per town would simplify the game but it has actually made it much more complex and challenging.  The lack of easy routes is causing much more thought.
The redesign of the industries has made the workflow much more challenging and interesting too. The cargo chains have been structured to make it harder to get bi-directional train routes which again is an improvement in challenge.  So some major steps forward in game play.

Disappointing misses - there is no change in cargo mechanics, we are rewarded for longer lines, there is no differentiation in cargo. I would have liked to see some cargo being worth more than others or the price reducing the longer the time to delivery.  Similarly I'd like to have seen demand information on passengers to see which were looking for fast routes and which are looking for cheap routes.

But so far I am really impressed, it looks and feels really good. A great step forward and I can only hope they will look to enhance mechanics in the future.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I haven't played for long, I haven't been able to. The interface is so ****ing horrendous it takes ages to do anything. It's exceedingly frustrating. The interface is 'hip' as in Windows 8 metro, totally unsuited for pc use let alone gaming. I don't know why it's still so popular. I've just requested a refund. If a mod comes out with a useable interface I'll revisit

title: Transport Fever 2
review: If you like Transport Fever 1 but found yourself fighting with its UI and cringing at its visual hiccups, then this game is for you. If you like transport tycoon games - this game is for you. It lets you manage lines and service on a very macro level while still requiring you to focus on the design of your infrastructure - tracks, switches, junctions, signalling, building configuration, etc. Although limited by its small map sizes, this game is definitely worth a shot to anyone interested in the transport tycoon genre.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review: Easy to play, hard to master

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
So, Transport Fever is good. The UI is a lot nicer than the the original, the new modular stations are a hella nice addition. It's more simple but at the same time keeps its challenge. Changes to vehicle replacement, despite the change in realism, are appreciated. There's no longer the need to faff about with pulling in trains at the end of their line or wasting loads on trucks by making them change out at depots. 

The only thing I am iffy on is the decision to split the old lines window into three separate windows. I feel that it's better for new players because it's more approachable, but as someone use to having all that info at once, it's annoying to have to switch from line info to see efficiency, to the vehicle tab to edit the vehicle, then back to line info to check efficiency again.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
6 hours in, ready for my initial review.

I am loving the new changes. The campaigns are actually fun in this game, unlike TF1. The controls seem very intuitive. Graphics are better, and the nice things such as station names on signs at stations is a good thing to see.

I like needing 4 farms to feed into 1 factory to make food that can make a max of 400. I know some don't like that, but I do. I am loving modular stations. I can create an eye sore, or I can spend an hour on 1 station and make it everything I would like to see in a station. I can make a 4 way terminal station if I so choose, or I can make 2 full stop terminals, 2 passthrough. I can see great potential in the mods, and the beautiful buildings that come out of there. Default buildings are good, but some mods will always be better.

I absolutely LOVE freezing time. You still lose money at the end of the "year", but you don't skip forward. In TF1, my biggest struggle was the giant leaps of time that kept happening. Just as I think I am OK to unpause the game, I would suddenly get another train, I couldn't afford for the brand new line I just put in the year before. I was always playing catch up with my extra money instead of building new infrastructure. Now, if I want to play in 1920 for 50 years, before I get airplanes, I can do that. I can then choose to no longer pause the date, and move forward. I love the choice being available.

I haven't run into any game breaking bugs yet, and the only one I have seen, I don't know if it was oversight, a bug, or intentional. My right click does not exit build mode, or menus, or anything. Every similar type of game uses this standard control scheme, including TF1, so I cannot fathom why they would force this change, if that is what happened.

Overall, if you like this type of game, give it a go. Next thing you know, you will be way beyond the 2 hour limit for a refund, and saying to yourself, how is it midnight already?

title: Transport Fever 2
review: So far I've only played 10 hours, but this game is a load of fun.

However, I do realise how much I rely on mods in the first game and therefore, it will take a few weeks or even months until we can expect the same range of vehicles and so on coming to TF2. As I know the community though, people are already eagerly working on it.

I've hit a couple of snags while trying to be clever with the building customization system and mixing lines, but it's been nothing game breaking thus far.  Probably just setting them up wrong.  All in all, really enjoying this game!

When it reaches 8 GB and stays there for a while, the game crashes (I have a feeling I'm going to have to go in and edit to allow for more RAM utilisation if this continues). My computer is well beyond the "minimum specs" (i7 6700k, 1080ti 11GB, and 32GB of system RAM). Not only that, but there are bugs - unable to close the vehicle depot building window: i have to first choose another building tab then close out that way.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
One word review: Disappointing.

UPDATE: Okay, I've looked to see if I can mod the game. During that time I came across the dev's video (https://youtu.be/Ecxe7TzbhBc?t=291) saying they were aware, in 2016 for TF1, that they were aware people wanted a planning tool. Good grief yes. I'm going to play up to my 2 hour limit then, I think, return the game and do something less frustrating, like vacuuming.

Many word review:
Okay, so I enjoyed the first game and pre-ordered this second but I was really hoping they’d fix the many UI misses of the first game and, well, sadly they don’t seem to have taken this opportunity to do that. I’ll update this review as I play more, though and if I realise I’ve missed anything.

Don’t get me wrong: there are some great touches – the graphics are nice and in theory the simplification of goods routes make things more readable, as examples.

But with those more limited goods options, you have less chance to make a round-trip route that will make you sensible amounts of money. Some of this might be solved by tweaking the map generation I presume, but I might suggest the devs tweak the defaults (unless I was just unlucky in the two maps I generated?). This may be simply because my map was too small or not dense enough [update: I am now playing a hard, very large map and it has given me a lot more options. The lack of undo remains my (and others) biggest cause of frustration in combination with the costs that choose a "wrong" track path incurs)

But it’s the UI issues that persist that mean I’m really disappointed and make me think you might simply be better served in buying the first game if you have neither. A lot of these might be quality of life issues, but with modern games now you’d expect these things, and it’s hardly like they reinvented the wheel here.

If you’re wondering (and heck, you might be able to correct me if I’ve missed something) the things I’d love to have are generally related to a lack of planning / undoing options and UI.

On the former perhaps while paused the game could let me experiment then Undo anything that I can’t complete? Or give me a quick save so I can at least pause, save, then load again if I need to (although ideally just snapshot my state when I press a button if you’re going to do that route – don’t make me actually load again please). It’s really annoying to start making a track, micromanaging it as the game doesn’t really ever help you find a best route (or close to), then not being able to finish it off.

Small other bits I’d love to see addressed include:
•	A view reset button so I can keep a fixed idea of North in my head (also great when playing with a few friends on the same map, to have a common frame of reference)
•	I’d love to change the scroll speed of the cursor keys (this might be in an ini file?)
•	I would find it great to have a windowless screen with no mouse capture.
•	Alt-F4 – It does something, which is nice, but if press that, how about simply quitting?
•	Give me a circle around the depots or terminals so I can see where their reach, as maximum, can extend to. And not just have it in that white that’s so hard to read, especially if you’re in terrain mode

I will play more and I’m sure I’ll enjoy it to some extent (and I have a friends who is in love with the first game, and like with all love, this means he ignore the bad and focuses on the good 😊 ), but I just wish they’d done more with the UI – and the main thing I really would love to have is a way to do “what ifs” with building roads or tracks (including a path editing tool before committing), and that’s simply not here.

in any case, loveing it!!!

The camera being completely free to move about, even to the point where you can inside an aircraft or bus. Still exploring the game but so far so good.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: oh man, i dont know what people mean when they say the performance is crap, im running a gtx 1060 3 gb, an intel i7 and 16 gb of ram and im actually runing high graphics at about 50-60 fps, so the point is that the game performance is not crap and the visuals are stunning and that i love the game allot, thats my review.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: even better than the original

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The first game was incredible for when you wanted to scratch that logistical itch. 

The sequel is leagues better. It is an improvement on the first game in every way:
Graphics
Interface
New Content
Quality-of-Life

On top of the many major changes (such as configurable stations) are just little details that make you realize what a well made game is again. Such as the stations having signs that have their name, or the ambient animals that wander around. In a game about moving things from point A to B, it adds a lot that wasn't needed but is appreciated none the less.

Would fully recommend.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I will work through and hopefully enjoy the game after some hard work but I can't recommend this game to new players of the series due to it's insane learning curve.

The tutorial needs a tutorial. For instance, on campaign 1 mission 2 it tells you to build truck stops but what you actually have to build is a truck station. It makes learning how to play the game extremely difficult. 

I bought a train and 3 cargo wagons for it separately and couldn't figure out how to connect them. This should be something super easy to do. 

I placed a road depot but it was too close to the road and didn't make a proper connection. You can't move the building, you have to destroy it or "pay for your mistake". The problem with this theory is that it showed what to me, a new player, was a proper connection (the thin blue connecting line) but a real proper connection for the depot is when it shows the big drive way. This took me almost an hour to figure out. I tried several "fixes" before finally figuring that out on my own.

I have played the game for roughly 6 hours and have made little progress due to every time i figure one thing out i have to spend another 30 minutes to an hour figuring another thing out. I haven't been able to "play" at all. 

Though, it does seem like it will be super fun once I know what i'm doing.

Edit: Literally fuck this game and it never working. Unless you have a degree in dumb shit, fuck this game. I have played so many games like this, but this is by far the most bullshit game ever. Nothing works. Ever. I did the tutorial. But there is always this one little thing you didn't do so it won't work. It's so fucking stupid. I've spent so many hours on this game just trying to do basic things and I can't. It just won't work. Such a fucking waste of time. There is no where to go to ask questions or get help either. Fuck this fucking game.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: A worthy successor.  Has some new mechanics and balance to make things interesting and things like one ways, traffic lights, bus lanes, highways, all make managing your traffic not only possible, but enjoyable if you're the sort of person who likes the challenge of traffic puzzles in city games.  The graphics feel new and shiny and the tropical map is great, the overall map generation has been improved and allows you to control more aspects of how it generates.  I kind of like the maintenance system that allows you to keep a vehicle running much longer rather than just throwing it out every X years, although some people seem to have their gripes with it.  I haven't personally experienced any major bugs, and performance has been holding up okay for me so far on a 24x24km map with a GTX 1080, i7-8700k@4.7GHz and 32GB RAM, not butter smooth frames but I'm playing on an experimental map size and the fact that it runs at all with all the detail at this scale is impressive.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I had been following this on youtube for a while now so had what I thought were pretty low expectations, but after buying the game I instantly had regrets within the first half hour.  It's a visual improvement on Transport Fever, the modular stations are neat, but in almost all other areas it's a step back from an already lackluster game.  

There's some pretty basic economic stuff all transport sims have to bake into their core mechanics to make games of this genre work, but the Transport Fever devs have attempted to ignore them out of some misguided attempt at "simplicity".  There's no difference in pricing between cargo,  no difference in decay rate, and no difference in sensitivity to speed.  This doesn't actually make the game more simple, it makes it unintuitive and leads to weird and confusing results.

These devs clearly have some talent, but they need to play some Railroad Tycoon 3 or OpenTTD and understand the core essential cargo pricing mechanics that makes games like this actually work, let alone be interesting to play.

review:
The user interface is so bad it makes the game super irratating to play. The interface in Transport Fever 1 wasn't great, but it was light years better than this. Things that only took like 1 click in TPF1, now take multiple clicks. Information that was all on one screen in TPF1 is now spreed across multiple screens.

Just managing things is a pain because of the interface.

Also, the game just doesn't seem like a sequal. It's more like Transport Fever 1.5.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Man the game is awesome imo if you are into this style of games. There are clear differences between TF2 and TF1. Yes you can argue that the track laying system is kind of the same but i feel like in TF2 it is more fluid and track laying is less clunky. The modular stations are such an amazing improvement that i feel like only that feature makes this game worth buying yet no one seems to acknowledge that. The graphics are greatly improved compared to TF1. Also i feel like 90% of the people that play this game will use steam workshop, a massive part of TF1, so this game still needs time for that content to be made by the people on the workshop. The terrain tool is so much better in TF2. It could be improved ofc but it works so much better now. They also officially said they will have DLCs. Yes you can argue that u will have to pay a bit more for more features but look at how good that turned for cities skylines. The combination of massive DLCs and Incredible workshop support made that game arguably the best city building game ever. Is all that content worth the money? Imo yes but i feel like that is up to every person as we are different and have different tastes so... yea.

I see people compare this game with Railway Empire but people keep forgetting that RE even now costs 20% more, and that's not even taking into consideration the additional -10% off if you own TF1. Also RE is purely a train game and this game is so much more. Yes the track laying system could take a few points from RE building system and be improved but the game just came out so maybe in the future? Yes i know RE also has the different station line management system where the same line can select different tracks where to drop things off in the station so yea there are a few things that could be improved in this game also but again, i dont consider these things so bad that it makes the game unplayable, farm from it actually.

Also yes some ways of transport are gonna be more profitable and/or harder to manage than others. Trains will run more profitable at one point than anything else, ships are indeed kind of hard to set up in the beginning or trucks wont provide such a massive amount of income as trains but they are very easy to set up and almost instantly turn quite profitable. Arguing that one mode of transportation sucks compared to another one and from there on saying that the game is bad is like arguing that because they took the Concorde out of the sky even tho it was amazing but almost impossible to run they should ground all planes because they suck. Also yes the maintenance costs are increased but you have different difficulties also you can do sandbox where money is not an issue so complaining that things are expensive and you can't handle it when you have the option of turning that down/off is again a mistake imo like complaining that you play Resident Evil on highest difficulty and you keep dying so the game is bad... The economy in this game works differently than in TF1 so you will have a few trial and error moments before you learn the jist of things. There is also the map generator that is a bit different and i quite like with the different bioms and all.

That being said if you are into the transport tycoon type of games and you have the money for this game in strongly recommend it. The game in its current state is great imo and it will only get better with workshop support and DLCs. Hope this helps.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Very good sequel to Transport Fever.

+Beautiful modeling of landscapes, towns, and transports.

+UI looks cleaner, and once you figure out where things have been moved to, not hard to navigate. 

+New map generator is dope fantastic, great addition to the franchise.

+Whole new set of vehicles with the Asian map, seemingly some new vehicles in other maps, but I haven't spent a lot of time in America or Europe yet.

+Interesting changes to cargo and goods. I was on the fence before I played, but after interacting with them I can say I'm satisfied. 

+Game seems more optimized. I used to have stutters after first loading in the map. That seems to be gone. 

// Information
| There seems to be a reformulation on how passengers move between cities, as there seems to be less intercity travel. This absolutely could be my fault, but I am playing the same way I played TpF 1. 

| I have not played past 1950 yet, and my Transport network is not overly large yet. Because of this I cannot say how late game performs just yet.

- Game seems to be heavy on my GPU. I can have a steady 30FPS with peaks of 60FPS (VSync will not allow it to go past 60) During gameplay CPU usage on my I7 7700k is around 20-30%, whereas my 1080 is seeing 70-80% usage. This is not a problem really, as 30fps on this type of game isn't a deal breaker. Otherwise I'd turn down the settings. 


Overall I am very pleased with this game, It is definitely improved across most fronts, and no significant steps backwards in my opinion. Very happy I bought the game. :)

I will also tack on as an edit: This absolutely could NOT have been done as a DLC. The changes seem to go to the core of the game, and possibly needed to update the engine to handle the changes. People need to realize that not everything can just be tacked on to a game with the wave of a wand. Large scale changes it is easier and faster to just build from the ground up than add on to an existing system. The asking price is fair as well, as a great deal was done between TpF1 and 2. Just take a step back and take stock, there has been a lot done. This is a small studio, and should be supported, so stop being a bunch of beggars, this is a great game with a fair price.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
I have mixed feelings about this game, i must say. To find out why, i have taken other opinions in mind while writing this. I love TF1 and played it for a long while. It was simpel, but still enjoyble. After awhile it kind of got bored, I craved new game features to make it more interesting. When this game got anounced, i got to be honest, i jumped on the hype train (no pun intended). 

Right now after i played for a few houres, im kind of disapointed. The graphics got a huge improvment, with new UI design and sounds. Even the campain is finally enjoyble to play. Maybe the biggest change is the terrain and map editing tool, which has gotten a big overhaul. Is there more? No... There is no game changing features that makes you play any different from the previous game. It feels like a reskin of TF1 nothing more. 

I wish the developers would have tried venture to other transport solutions or ways to manage existing. This game is still mainly focused on trains. Passenger ships are useless, cargo ships are useless and airplanes are still very difficult to use. Coman lets improve these things and lets add new transport methods; like cruises, ferries, metro, hooverrails or even helicopter to remote places, whatever, just do something new. Nothing has been changed to make the game more interesting, only the aesthetics. Paying 30$ is not worth it if you are new to this series i would rather spend 23$ on TF1, the same game just an older version than this. I still hope new stuff is going to be released, but i have my doubts...

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
First off, i dont know what everyones performance complaint is. To anyone second guessing buying the game because of those negetive reviews: it must be something on their end. I am running a 3 year old Laptop with a Core I5 @ 2.5ghz, 16gb ddr4, and a 4gig GTX 1050ti and everything seems like 98% fine to me. Slight little lags here and there when buying vehicles or zooming the map but totally smooth and playable otherwise. 

Secondly, I do agree with some people that this is more of TF1.5 than a full blown sequal. There isnt as much change or improvement to the game play itself as I was hoping for. Having said that if you just want this game to play transport fever with better graphics and better FPS you are in luck. Thats exactly what it is. Also the map generator is FREAKIN AWESOME. I always hated how lame the maps were in TF1 and that problem is completely gone and over with. 

In conclusion, maybe just a tiny bit disapointed from what I expected from all the hype but it definately still deserves a thumbs up. There is no modern alternative that does transport better than this. Game is beautiful and relaxing and will give you potentially thousands of hours of time sink for $30. The value factor alone is excellent. Just buy it and play.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: TF2 is an improvement over the already well-loved Transport Fever. Vibrant modding community and a true love by the developer make this a must have if you like train games at all.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
my favorite things about this game series were always the procedural-generated terrain (great replay value), the town-growth modeling algorithm based on supply and demand (creating a game economy with very few simple rules) and of course the trains and vehicles. there was a lot of info out there on youtbue about the game but not necessarily about the stuff i was most interested in - so for me it was right into sandbox mode 1850 on hard when game was available and i'm pleased to see it improves on all of these aspects, and more. 

here are the ten things i like so far (6 hours in):

1. the new cargo and industry mechanics - i was a little concerned about this but it's an improvment. 

 towns requiring specific goods makes for a greater challenge (good).

 raw goods such as crude or grain are processed at 2:1 ratio - making it more challenging to have trains run full both directions (but still possible through some clever routing).

2. ui got a big improvement. line-management and vehicle-management take a bit of getting used to but are very useful once you do.

3. feedback to player about town and industry is a *huge* improvement - you can now actually tell (not just guess) what the industry is doing and why.

4. overlays are cool but not too useful - except the terrain tool which is a must when laying tracks; also don't like the white color the overlays have.

5. configuring the stations is cool - and very useful when you need to connect a road just right.

6. you can look around in 1st person mode now - really cool.

7. graphics are an obvious improvement as can be seen in any youtube video.

8. performance is not. runs fairly well and very playable for me but at 30fps or less most of the time and doesn't feel smooth. (game does close much faster though - used to freeze up my pc for 10-20 secs not it takes less than a second)

9. terrain and map tools took a huge upgrade. the map generation tool will put my map making days out to pasture - it's very good.

10. i think the hard mode (sandbox) is bugged - you get 5m to start and it feels too easy.

note: my cpu quite fast bat is an older fx-8370 - so maybe with newer cpus performance is better.

title: Transport Fever 2

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
Much anticipated and so pleased at this new release!!!

Running with good graphics performance and beautiful scenery - I have only played on a small map so far. No stuttering or graphics issues for me so far ( i7-7700 16GB ram  GTX1070 - 5 hours gameplay).

Previously playing Transport Fever 1 I had finally got my head around delivery frequency in the old game and worked out why factories used to shut down or reduce productivity due to over-delivery etc. But it was complex. - Working with this was way too distracting and didn't allow me to develop my maps very far as I concentrated on calculations and fluctuations in delivery yields.
Transport Fever 2 has improved on this dramatically and is much more intuitive. New information graphics now show me exactly how much I am delivering. This has also been helped enormously with the introduction of being able to stop time without pausing the game. This feature means I can get my network efficient before I have to concentrate on the introduction of updated vehicles disrupting all my previous work.  Awesome!!!!

I haven't played enough to fully experience each town only accepting two types of freight. And I must admit when I first heard about this change I did wonder why it was necessary - but in gameplay so far, the reality is that it has allowed me to focus and develop my map. As it turns out I think the old game just gave me too much choice. Another awesome addition!!!

Not played about much with the new modular stations. But I can say this has also improved the gameplay. It now allows the mix of both passenger/freight and in addition has also improved functionality by adding more entrance/exits. Plus there is the new Cargo drop-off points. So much better than using a bus stop as a cargo drop that was in TF1!!!

I sense that so much time must have been spent developing the new map generation tools and use of height maps. This is a feature that adds a huge amount gameplay and options that I am looking forward to playing with. 

So a big thumbs up from me and a hearty well done to the development teams involved!!!!
=======================================================================

Also - the new indication of how a train will perform depending on how many wagons I add is excellent too

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
A great sequel to TF1. A great improvement in graphics, UI, vehicles, stations, economy, etc. 

People complaining about it not being an upgrade from TF1, I don't see that. Urban Games isn't a AAA developer with the capabilities to deliver vast leaps forward, they have listened to the feedback from TF1 and taken it all on board. They've greatly improved the content and design. They've also provided great new opportunities to the fantastic community of modders.

Mods always make games like this, the devs can't create 1000's of specialist vehicles or themes for certain countries as they won't be relevant to most people but talented modders hopefully will. 

Of course there are other things I would have loved to have included, more biome options, larger maps, even more vehicles, building types, etc but these can all be tweaked with mods .Overall, very pleased indeed.

100% new game, 30% new gameplay.

The aestherics change is huge! Games looks lovely, runs relatevily good for day 1 (it definitely needs optimization though), new tropical biome is just stunning.

Gameplay changes on the other hand are marginal. On the plus side is the semi-randomized cargo needs which pleasantly adds a fresh dynamic, but other than that nothing groudbreaking except minor (much needed - but still minor) improvements.

If this game was a napping cat, it just woke, turned around on the same spot and slept again:)

Totally recommended though, i just wish it would (or will?) have delivered more.

title: Transport Fever 2
review: I agree with many of the comments related to the lack of new features over the original game.  This feels more like Transport Fever 1.5 instead of 2.0.  If you liked the original and played it for hundreds of hours, this is will feel more like a graphical improvement and a few new game mechanics thrown in.  They changed a few colors, updated some buttons and menus, added some new models and copy and pasted the rest of the code.  It's disappointing to spend another ~$30-$40 for somewhat of a re-skin to Transport Fever.  With all of the mods available for Transport Fever, this is sort of a step sideways, than a step up.  Considering there was more than three years between games, I was expecting a larger set of updates.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
The UI and graphics improvements over TF1 are very welcome. The simulation model for transportation inside towns/cities also seem to be better. But for the most part, it doesn't seem to be a lot different than TF1.

Overall, Transport Fever is not my favorite style of train tycoon game (I like the Sid Meier's Railroads / Railway Empire style of a more gamey approach with opponents and tightly timed objectives and such). Still, it's enjoyable to see your network coming to life and following your vehicles (or the people too) around.

One aspect I really wish they had improved compared to the first game is the sound design. Better music, ambient sounds and sound effects could really help with the atmosphere.

title: Transport Fever 2
review:
[b]Transport Fever 2[/b] is a nice update to the transport and logistics simulation genre of games, and more specificly a nice improvement on Transport Fever 1.
I have currently as of writing this review 2 hours in TF2, but I have around 110 hours in TF1.
The new UI is fresh and clean although it suffers from not being the most intuitive UI but not the worst I've used.
The graphical improvement is massive, with this though comes set backs, and one big one which I've seen from other reviews is linked to performance. Currently at 2 hours och gameplay and trying it out it runs well on my rig, but my rig is arguably more on the very high end.

Intel i7 6700k @ 4GHz
RTX 2070 16GB
16GB DDR4 RAM
Game is installed on a new 7200RPM HDD

And the game runs well for me, but you might want to be a little more cautious with an older/cheaper rig, but since it runs well for me at 50-60fps most of the time I can't complain (VSYNC on).
There are dips to about 40fps though when building certain things just like in TF1.

A lot of new vehicles, and they're so much more detailed.
Terrain tools are a lightyear ahead of the first installment of this game series.
The new modular station system and other improvement such as being able to connect a train station to a bus stop without needing to have a road in between is a great change and makes it easier to make a clean looking bigger transport hub in a city.


[b]Closing thoughts and reminders. (TL;DR)[/b]

The game is a massive improvement in various ways from TF1 and it does these improvements well including the UI, it's not the best UI but it is better than the one in TF1.
The game runs at an average 50 fps, there are dips even for me in the fps when building tracks, just like in TF1. People with older and/or cheaper rigs should try it and see how hteir performance is, because your mileage may vary.
The tools, vehicles and buildings look a lot better than in TF1.
More vehicles to choose from and a lot prettier and more detailed.

I do recommend this game for anyone interested in the transport management/simulation genre of games.
Buy it, try it, see if you like it before the 2 hours are up.
I know I'm gonna keep playing like crazy.
